author: admire
review: The most beautiful looking Forza Horizon, or any racing game for that matter, the graphics are insanely good that even still i load into the game and just have to sit and admire them for a minute before getting into it, but it still has its problems. The story is pretty average, you dont really care about what you're doing or the characters you're doing it for its more of a turn your brain off and try out the different kinds of races and cars. I love the landscape of mexico and its a big step up from FH4's map. The selection of cars is huge, though it is missing some pretty big brands we've seen in previous games that I used a lot . the creative hub is still pretty much the same and i do wish they would make it easier for things that arent from content creators to get the recognition some of them deserve. (such as a search for new, though i do understand it can be difficult with a big player base.) I bought the premium edition of the game and i can say that i think it was well worth getting to play the game early plus not have to worry about paying for future dlc, but i think that its a little buggy for now and would recommend waiting for a sale or buying just the normal edition if you cant wait. the game is really inconsistent with how it runs. I am using an rtx 3080 and ryzen 5800x, and i can get up to 60-70 fps with almost everything maxed at 4k, my problem with it is that the game will start to use less and less of your gpu/cpu and end up dropping your framerate significantly while also causing stuttering. i haven't had it crash on me but it definitely gets annoying playing for a few hours and having 20-30fps lower than what i had earlier. overall id probably give this game a 7.5-8/10 and would highly consider making it higher whenever they decide to fix all the bugs and the problem with gpu usage.

author: weathergirl eve
review: I spent hundreds of hours playing Forza Horizon 4 on the microsoft store since the start but I can't seem to find the same charm with Forza Horizon 5. Don't get me wrong it's a really good game with amazing graphics, but it just felt like a letdown compared to the previous games. I found the map and it's landmarks/races a lot less memorable then those in Forza Horizon 4 and the selection of cars felt lacking.You really want the game? I'd recommend getting it on sale. The Deluxe edition is really nothing right now, so if you aren't patient i wouldn't suggest getting it.

author: kerf
review: No important innovations over the previous installment. Game feels more centered around Mexico than driving & racing. Dropped right into the shoes of a "superstar," got a free GT, Centenario, Senna, among other things and got very little sense of achievement or satisfaction.

author: CunkFeatures
review: After deep reflection its a big no from me... 6/10Horizon on the 360 was remarkable, it set the tone for a game of simple graphics but with HD textures and tons of effects that really worked in making a gob smacking game, the devs are masters of this. Same art going on now, see ^ pics. Motion blur turned to 11. Look close, see the decade old assets, poorly met textures etc etc.Those who voted for Outstanding Visuals need to open their eyes, throw some god rays and some DoF and these people orgasm. The map is naff. Its like the Forza 4000 just spat out another random map. Mexico apparently has the same sorta junctions/intersections ( + y ) /corners and sweeping roads as Scotland and Australia. TBH I'd expect Mexico to be more open with long roads and straight roads, not the curvy stuff you'd expect from a hilly place. Which brings me to...Location, it's rubbish. Mexico is boring, Mexico has no real motor industry, Mexico has huge rates of poverty so Horizons a bit of a kick in the face. Mexico is another arid map.Wanted Japan, huge cities to push our consoles and PCs along with rolling hills to drift some of Japans finest. But the devs went with Mexico? The Mecca of nout.MP is a huge step back, like HUGE! You connect randomly to people around your map location, sounds great but nope. Meet someone on a drive, take a wrong turn and gone. Looking for curse meets, good luck as not on the map. The game didn't build on play styles in the last titles? It made it worse. What is the point on openworld MP in this game? It doesn't work! Take 4 and the way people played in freeroam and build on that, not take away? I would love an active world with meet points for cruses, drifts, top speeds. But in this its pointless, its temporary, its BS.Racing. Racing is much the same, testosterone fueled teens using you to corner cus the cant brake due to the latter. You miss checkpoint flags, you see no point. This is a franchise with a Lego DLC, aim low in driving standards.Cars. Usual line up we have had for years which is a shame, they keep dropping cars, even cars they have charged for, while adding others like those China cars.I mean, throw the old cars into a 2nd hand bin, make them available at least! 2CV, Tuscan. Why not? Just expand the game FFS! From EA to now I give it 6/10. A cheap map pack in my books. Nothing new, much the same, different map, worse MP experience. My hearts not pumping in races, my brains not interested in bland environments when the MB turned off. Try harder for Â£90.

author: BavGod
review: Playground Game's beloved arcade-styled open world celebration of cars and insufferable festival dialogue written by middle aged people desperately trying to find the pulse of youth culture is back, trading the damp back roads of the UK for the volcanic mountains, swamps and deserts of Mexico. Forza Horizon 5 has taken everything Playground Games learned over the continuous development of Forza Horizon 4 and has remixed the flow of the game, in some ways for the better while in others the game falters.  Playground Games has eschewed fans demands for a Horizon game set in Japan, instead crafting an open world inspired by the varied terrain of Mexico. This game world is larger and more varied than  Forza Horizon 4's, offering the long stretches of highway, twisty mountain passes, long straight drag strips and plenty of water, mud and sand for players to plow through. It's richly detailed and gorgeous, which makes hunting down the fast travel and experience granting collectibles less of a chore than it may seem like on paper. In somewhat of a departure from previous Horizon games, there isn't really a traditional major metro urban area in the game, instead the game features a small city with labyrinthine streets and tunnels which is an interesting change and allows for some really interesting more technical races. Progression in Forza Horizon 5 is a remix of previous games, allowing players to ultimately construct multiple horizon outposts that represent each style of racing present in the game (road races, street races, offroad races, cross country races and PR Stunts) and within each outpost there are a handful of unlockable activities. In order to unlock these outposts and their activities, players must obtain accolades. Accolades are available for almost any activity in the game: online races, creating liveries and tunes, taking photos, free roam driving and of course winning races. No matter how you choose to spend your time in Horizon, you will make forward progress which allows any type of player to see the entirety of the main game. Unfortunately this is a two edged sword, the game doens't really feel like it builds to much of anything. Unlocking everything means entering the hall of fame and unlocking a new series of accolades as well as Trial challenges. If you are one of those players that wishes Horizon would force you to start with a clapped out hooptie and climb the economic ladder, your prayers haven't been answered here. Horizon 5 throws cars and credits at it's players constantly, but with so much content, completionists will appreciate this fact.The driving in FH5 feels much the same as previous games and that is fine by me. Each car feels distinct based on it's drivetrain layout: mid engine cars handle differently than front engine cars, front wheel drive cars tend to understeer, all wheel drive cars launch incredibly and hold traction well in a variety of terrain but understeer, rear wheel drive cars are prone to spinning if proper care isn't exercised. It's the perfect balance of realism and arcade, whereas cars Need for Speed and The Crew feel roughly the same with some cars simply being faster than others, you will fall in love with specific cars in Forza Horizon basewd on the way they compliment your strengths and weaknesses behind the wheel. The faint tinge of realism also makes the game world more compelling to navigate. The biggest shortcoming with FH5 comes in the changes made to arcade mode. In FH4, arcade events would spring up on the map at the top of the hour, and all players would receive notifications with a fast travel option to participate. In FH5, arcade events happen every ten minutes and two pop up at  atime fracturing the server's population; assuming anyone is paying attention in the first place. The requirements to complete these events is also irritatingly challenging. Assuming you can get a full crew in place, some challenges require top tier play while the arcade events in FH4 generally set  a lower bar and didn't foment tension between participants. Arcade mode being a mess wouldn't be a big deal if it wasn't the best  way to earn Forzathon Points (FP) which can be used in a special marketplace to buy exclusive and high value items. The rest of FH5's online robust offerings fall prey to the same headaches as they always have: cooperative modes as plagued by drivers who don't understand that they are on a team and will ram you, playground games are usually spoiled by half of one team dropping out as soon as they feel they won't win, etc. The Eliminator modes returns, it was a late addition to FH4 and is a car based battle royale which is interesting but I don't feel terribly compelled to endure the long match making times in order to continually play it.With over 500 cars (the team at Playground Games is continually adding more), a wide variety of races and challenges, custom livery design, custom tuning and plenty of online modes, Forza Horizon 5 is a very strong package that remixes the elements of previous games in a way that is largely a step forward and keeps the experience fresh. There is simply no substitute for Horizon. It's imperfect, a little cheesy at times and is not breaking new ground, but for a fan like me, it hasn't grown stale either... If you love cars and can't be bothered with the technical demands of sim racers, you can't do any better than Forza Horizon 5.

author: mTs
review: Its the first Forza Horizon for me and i really want to like this game but it falls short so quickly that i have to give it a thumbs down. The positive things like graphics, amount of cars etc. were mentioned enough and i agree.BUT if you care mostly for an Online Racing Game you will be hugley disappointed.The Online Races are a joke.You cant choose which car in which class you want to drive against other people. The only option you have is to select Online Race and see what random class the game chooses. That just frustrating. Ive spent half an hour with hopping in and out Lobbys just to get the class i want to drive in, only to have a lobby where 4 of 5 races are already completed. What kind of Concept is this?Also the vareity of Tracks is very limited, there is no ranked mode, you cant modify your car between races, the loading times are sometimes beyond 5 Minutes (even after the patch)The Seasonal Event Playlist was refreshing at first, but got boring aready because you will always do the same Challenges just to get a Wheelspin or a "Hard to find" Car which you just can buy from the Auction House with the Money the Game throws at you.I get that this Game might not be about havig the best Online Race experience and is fun for people who just want to do pointless offline races here and there. But thats not for me.

author: Nickelodeon
review: I've been a huge fan of the Forza series ever since I played Forza Motorsports 4 years and years ago. This is the most fun I've had in a Forza game ever. They improved so much over FH4, the Online services/netcode have improved greatly which isn't saying much but I'm glad to see they've done something. The UI is super clean and much easier to understand. The car selection isn't great but here's hoping they add even more great cars, but mainly more Lotus'. Sadly with most games these days you are buying a project and not a product but FH5 is by far the most polished multiplayer game this year.

author: Hisao Nakaii
review: Not the best racing game in existence, but by god does it come close to that!Played practically every Forza title on xbox and having them coming to PC only made it much easier to handle and to play with 60 FPS! with full wheel support and controller support being an obvious thing to note, though the game does have a few things that detract from its experience.- 60 FPS ftw!- full controller support including and not limited to: xbox 360, xbox One, PS3, PS4, PS5, Switch Pro, that one plastic controller i bought ten years ago because i needed a controller for racing games but didn't have the money for a proper one... the list goes on, and the same goes with wheels too, been playing with my Logitech G29 that was meant for Playstation and it works flawlessly.- Graphics are sometimes too realistic, makes for amazing photos and renders.- Performance is reasonably high even with high-ultra settings mix.- handling is very great, especially if you're using a wheel instead of a controller.- the new customization kits for certain cars are just... glorious... have you seen the bodykits on the RX-7 FD?- music selection is great, though it could use a built-in radio that detects music in your library.- event variety is amazing, the amount of races and events are just monumental. - Loading times are atrocious on HDDs, compacted by the extremely large size of the game, it wouldn't be too far of a stretch to say that you need a dedicated SSD just for it.- i can't import any of my designs from FH4 to FH5 because i have FH4 on the microsoft marketplace and have FH5 on steam... shame...- Microstutters when starting a race and mid-driving sometimes makes me lose my footing and ends up with me french kissing a wall.- certain electric cars on launch date dominated the speed zones due to the infinite horsepower buildup glitch, so all the speed zones are nearly impossible to reach high enough legitimately since 30% of the top are just electric cars.- many of the modifications that were majorly requested didn't make it like custom exhaust tips, window stickers, different wheel sets front and back, neons, interior modification (at the very least make weight reduction remove seats and change the driver seat & steering wheel to a racing set instead).Overall, it's a really great package that is both visually and physically appealing, with the usual Playground Games polish and work being put in it constantly to help build the perfect open-world racing game. No game is perfect and especially racing games too, but this one scratched an itch i had for a long time after obtaining every singe car including Horizon edition cars in FH3 and FH4, and i know that Playground Games are going to be perfecting and adding more to the game as it goes on!

author: Kai
review: It's good! It's more Forza Horizon! If you want that then yay, if you dont then give it a miss! I'll say its a 9/10 and easily the best game in the franchise so far! I really hope that Forza Motorsport 8 can match it. I miss closed circuit racing q.qon a more specific note, there have been a number of pleasant changes to the formula this time around which I feel will give the game more of a shelf life for players that enjoy the sense of progression that was somewhat lacking in Forza Horizon 4.Personally for me, the new Car Collection view (and it's associated rewards system, sort of like getting five stickers and getting a free cup of coffee but for collecting cars) and the transition away from a fixed "Do races, unlock more races, repeat" progression system for the various towards the new Adventure system has certainly helped me stay glued to the game after 20 hours and counting! The new core progression system involves you being able to select which sorts of events you want to prioritise, and allows you to spend "Accolade" points that you accrue by completing events, beating challenges (sort of like the progression system from FH4's Lego DLC) and playing through the various storylines that the game has scattered throughout the world which unlock as you level up the festival sites. The festival sites are once again in the multiples this time around after the (imo disappointing) single festival site in FH4, and you unlock these sites by spending accolade points, and you can expand them and their associated events by activating "Adventures" which are mini-showcase events, and provide a pretty fun variety of gameplay.There have also been a number of quality of life improvements to the tuning and upgrading of cars, including the ability to rev the engine during the upgrade/customization process to sample the impact of components on the sound of the various parts. It was always frustrating to make changes to a car only to have no idea how it would sound anymore, so its very nice to be able to  sample these things before actually driving off with a glorified vacuum cleaner.Sound in general in the game is a very strong point with a very pleasing selection of tunes on the various radio stations (Pulse and Hospital are my favs this time around), and some very good engine recordings for the all new cars. I've also been extremely impressed with the foley work that went into all of the environmental noise, and i've found it weirdly enjoyable to just drive around a rocky, gravel strewn mountainside in a slow fashion just to listen closely to the sounds of dirt being kicked up and flicking the side of the car. Its certainly a joy to listen to on headphones like the HD 660S so I'm sure that if you're an audiophile like me, you will have a lot to be happy about with this game.Graphics are an undeniable strong suit of this game, and I think the screenshots and video on the steam page do it justice so I wont ramble on about it too much, other than to say the all new Volumetric Fog system is one of the best I've seen in a modern game, and the addition of adaptive resolution in the PC release will certainly be welcome for low-spec gamers who want to run as close to their native resolution as possible. On my personal rig, I've been running the game on a Ryzen 5800X with 32GB RAM, and an RTX 3080 which is connected to a G7 240hz 1440p monitor, and the lowest frame rate that I have seen at the suggested "Extreme" settings (Xbox Series X preset) has been around 90fps in the dense jungle environments, such as to say that the game is supremely well optimized. Right now there are a few visual bugs with things like super low resolution distant terrain being well within the visible range, as well as a GPU related crash when changing Tyre Rims too frequently in a single customization session, but I am absolutely certain that these issues will be cleared up following the official launch.Those of you with low end rigs or old laptops will be happy to know that the game plays nicely even on a Ryzen Athlon 3000G with Vega 3 graphics and Intel HD630 integrated graphics on the low preset at 1080p, and looks about as nice as GTAV looked on the Xbox 360 which is pretty high praise in my opinion.The game also has a 10/10 accessibility system, with many audio and visual tweaks to help those who need it. It also allowes you to slow game speed in offline play for those who need more time to react to thinksIf you aren't tired of the Horizon open world format just yet, I can wholeheartedly reccomend this as the best version of that experience so far, and thank you for taking the time to read my rambling thoughts! :D

author: N0xEterniS
review: I'm done with these developers, I just can't believe how incompetent they are. Played it for 521 hrs, bought the 99.99â‚¬ version, played its predecessor: FH4 for 600 hrs, made 37 videos showcasing different cars, rivals and online racing and today I'm uninstalling and will never buy a game from this company ever again.First and foremost, . It's been 4 months since the game came out, still hasn't been addressed. On the steam page under recommended specs, it says that you need 16GB RAM, not 32GB, not 64GB. Well if you have 'only' 16GB, you will have to restart the game every 1 to 2 hrs... it's not all tho.. WMI Provider Host will still run in the background and take up to 50-60% CPU.It .. a lot. I've had countless crashes, not joking! Sometimes the game crashed 3-4 times before I was even able to get out of the house and accelerate. especially in The Eliminator, but also after every loading screen and also sometimes in online racing.. You are going to randomly get disconnected while looking for an online adventure or when racing online, the message you get: ''you have been disconnected'', instead of ''Our servers are 2nd hand''. I think this bug was introduced in December, so it's been at least 2 months since we had to race in pitch dark and if you also add some very bad track designs, you get a very unenjoyable experience. Sometimes you get no vibration at all, which is very important while trying to drive a powerbuild or a RWD properly and also if you don't use ABS. To resolve this, sometimes all you have to do is press a key on your keyboard, sometimes that's not enough and you have to unplug ur controller and sometimes nothing works and you have to restart the game.All of the above are technical issues, what about the racing portion?Well you can check out my videos, I won't be uploading anymore tho, decide for yourself if I was good or not. since day 1. They haven't done anything to ban and delete the impossible leaderboard times. It's been 4 months guys.. 4. You do see them online too, but not that often. So let's say you want to do only road/street racing. Well the game will present to you a random lobby, if you get Cross Country - though luck, try again, if you get Dirt - though luck, try again. But the game has multiple classes so you could get B-Class Dirt/Cross Country or A-Class or S1 or S2 Dirt, if you really want to get a specific lobby, say A-Class Road/Street it can take up to 20 min, I've had this happen lots of times because I wanted to try out a car in A class. This whole issue would be resolved by telling the game to only give A-Class Road/Street lobbies.  I'm decent enough to beat 99% of the bone shaker users, but that doesn't negate the fact that the car is basically a cheat, like a god item in skyrim, it's too powerful for A-Class. Lots of players complained about this car, , yet it's still alive in FH5. . We don't have it in FH5 because apparently it hurts some feelings... I'm literally speachless about this one. We don't get a game mode because it hurts some noobs feelings. Some tracks, mainly the city ones are poorly designed and generally too short. You literally wait more in the lobby while the game is loading the new race/track and getting everybody there than actually racing.It's a bannable offence, lots of people do this, especially bone shaker users, yet the devs don't do anything about it. ''Going out of your way to intentionally cause wrecking in multiplayer races goes against the spirit of the game and can result in enforcement action''. are still too long. It's not unusual in an online adventure to wait for the next race to start for 5 to 10 mins.What are the devs actually doing to improve your experience and the state of the game?They banned and proably still ban 'offensive' liveries. What's offensive? Whatever they want, they'll ban you permanently, but not those who cheat and post impossible leaderboard times.They nerfed the wheelspins. I, personally don't care about this at all, BUT for the casual player this made the game so much more grindier for no reason. Why did they do this? Because people were doing AFK races to earn mastery points and then buy super wheelspins, it's a really dumb decision.They release 'patches' to fix things but add new bugs instead. Like the 'no headlights' bug which was introduced in december, now they're trying to stop people from adding liveries into the game, but make the game super laggy in the tuning menu and it now crashes while painting.They don't listen to the community at all to the point where sometimes you ask yourself if these devs actually test and play thier own game.We need to abandon ship, otherwise they'll never learn. The game sits at 86% positive on steam, which is a complete joke.

author: KatNip
review: So.......a real look at Forza Horizon 5, whilst it is a car game that its not entirely simulation, it's not entirely arcade either, so on the regard of how your car will handle, you can spin out, get under and oversteer, etc, it is a game that celebrates car tunning, not in the cosmetic aspect for most cars, but in the performance aspect, weight reduction engine swaps etc. I would say it's a specific game on how you have to give it some time, it's not a brake to drift sort of engine, but it has the best graphics I have seen on a current game, so I can give it a 9/10, it needs a bit of fleshing out and there are noticeable bugs in game but nothing gamebreaking

This game got my hooked right away with its accurate schematics, and most of all, the drifting aspect. I have never played a game with drifting this good.

I came a long way from Horizon 2 on the Xbox 360 to the 5th on my average gaming PC. I love this game every single bit. The cars selection are magnificent, taking place in mexico just makes it close to home for me, graphics are as beautiful as ever, even on low settings. Please get this game from every cent of your pocket you won't regret it.

author: Sparky
review: I'm more of a sim racing guy, but Horizon 5 is the best arcade/simcade ever developed so far. They even fixed the MUCH REQUESTED wheel support! It feels fantastic with my Fanatec wheel, all assists off and simulation steering. Graphically, it's jaw-dropping, the sound is bliss, the gameplay is phenomenal. Forza Horizon 5 is a masterpiece.But the voice acting is really ruining this game for me. I wish there were a way to turn off the obnoxious â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ they have to say.I'm loving the game so far. Graphics are lovely at 4k, everything maxed out, with Ray-Tracing on the best quality and proper HDR. It runs very smoothly for me. Framerates are rock solid with no stutters or crashes (the game, not the cars, lol).The HDR is slightly more realistic in this game than in FH4. It's a pity that the cutscenes can't be skipped, though.Unfortunately, the game has always suffered from a lack of a proper career path. This makes it a shallower experience. Even so, I'm really enjoying the game so far. Well done, Playground Games, on yet another excellent driving game. My PC experience has been excellent.(For the badge.)

author: Blushing Boo
review: Cant really recommend this game even though i will keep playing it after passing the refunding window for it.Basically this game is a complete trainwreck in terms of online modes to the point where it makes you think that even nintendo mightve made a smarter decision with their nintendo switch online expansion. Aside from the glacial servers that keep you hostage for 10+ minutes if someone disconnects during a race, giving you ample time to take a shower between each and every one of them, playground has removed beloved staples from the feature list of this game like matchmaking for team PvP and the entirety of ranked mode (and as an extension of those two, team ranked as well). Im not even sure why they are parading the word "unranked" in their reworked online adventure tab when it just serves as a means to confuse the player into thinking that, if there is an "unranked" mode, there must be a ranked mode somewhere as well, except there isnt.Their argument is that scrubs have the capacity to feel emotions which makes them angry when they get smoked by anyone with two intact hands and a turned on monitor, so ranked had to go. Why they removed team PvP though is kind of beyond me since it has always been a populated mode in FH4 so why get rid of it?Singleplayer is fun but ultimately nothing to keep your attention for too long once you did all the races.There is a slew of things to add that will definitely tick anyone off (gonna be updated as i remember things):-) The game textures are incredibly unoptimized, eventually memory leaking your GPU so hard youll be required to restart the game unless you want constant stuttering-) Not every car has access to the pickup truck offroad tires for whatever reason-) The walls in this game are well placed in order to discourage people from wallriding like they did in early FH4. Too bad the game still applies a slowdown for you when you hit them even though its practically impossible to get any advantage from hitting the walls in the first place except for very fringe situations that are really not worth the risk in most cases-) Quick rewinds are gone in online, making you waste a lot of additional seconds for rewinding from a crash-) You cannot really add stuff to your controls on a controller because every useless button on it (like ANNA or changing radio stations, or switching cameras) is treated as essential, giving you practically zero leeway in adding stuff like telemetry to your button layout.-) The offroad physics have been cleaned up by not making every patch of offroad a complete bumpfest despite seemingly being smooth. However, the jumping and landing physics in this game seem to be overall a big downgrade from FH4. Expect up to 2 frontflips out of nowhere on straight paths in cross country in this game just because the game decided its time for some pirouettes and there is nothing you can do to really prevent it.-) The game doesnt always ghost you from high speed crashes quickly enough, making you collide and then applying the ghosting effect to you (as if it would still be of any use at that point)-) The game has so little snow that it took me 50 hours to actually drive over my first patch of snow in a race. Did i even need the (now separate) snow tires for that fringe occasion? No.-) Street Scene races in general dont have neutral traffic. Its basically just road racing without corner walls and no circuits.-) Compared to FH4, the racing line indicator is much more inaccurate both in routing as well as actual braking zone recommendations. It was okay back then when only a couple cars had too strong/too weak brakes compared to what the game thought would be the case but in FH5 this issue is extremely common for many cars to the point where i'd honestly just tell you, the potential buyer/player to learn each cars braking zones individually rather than trusting whatever false information youre being fed by the game.

author: Finzy
review: I wasn't a huge racing game fan but Forza 5 has me sold. It's imo a great mix of more arcade chill driving while still having realistic aspects. It looks great and it's just fun to play, there's an open world where you gradually unlock more events and you're never pressured to do thing X asap, you can pretty much play it in any order you like (+ load times for events are pretty fast, you can just drive nonstop around the world map and unlock stuff as you go). The car painter is great and it's basically a weeb's wet dream. Unlocking more cars and stuff is fast, and you don't have to grind long to get the cars you like apart from the more monster class ones. There's a variety of different driving styles for offroad as well. It's also well optimized and my laptop can even handle it at 4K Extreme settings at 60 FPS. Creating your own driver is also pretty fun, especially when you get to call him/her whatever you want, plus the story events add a nice touch imo.I would recommend staying away from the Xbox game pass version though, because it didn't recognize my PS4 controller and it also had a permanently disappearing mouse cursor, Steam version has been working way better for me. And I would definitely recommend playing this on a controller either way, or even a wheel if you have one.

Is it normal to have an extremely detailed map, simulated weather and high quality particle effects, whilst we ride in mostly cars, models of which are from games that match the average rammer in online racing? How long do we have to stare at cars with wrong proportions, broken reflections? Not to mention, a lot of these re-used cars are presented as "new" content. This game is honestly such a weird one, I don't even know what to say at this point, the series was degrading since two and, so far, this is the lowest â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ point

I'll be refunding but really, the game is amazing, this is just a warning to anyone wanting to do the same thing I did.

author: Rubat
review: I haven't played a racing game in years and was looking to try one, and my god was this a disappointment. it's fine if you just want to do all the singleplayer activities once and be done with it, or to grind the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ weekly challenges, but as soon as you touch multiplayer, the entire game just falls apart.It is very obviously a console port so a lot of UX issues and the keyboard controls are quite terrible.* You cannot look around the car vertically, and the sensitivity is so high is unusable, and it cannot be changed.* The Windows mouse cursor is always on screen* No easy way to switch UI tabs from keyboard (like keys Q/E or 1/3 in many games, or just being able to select tabs via arrow keys)* Menus are laid out very confusingly* Sometimes selecting something with mouse works, sometimes it doesn'tThe game is very buggy, even after the first hotfix:* For some reason I couldn't change map filters after some unknown trigger* I had multiple races against other players where I would spawn outside of the race circuit (Horizon Open), completely ruining any chances at winning* Certain things just do not work like certain accolades (in game mini-achievements), daily challenges, etc.The game also has extreme connectivity issues:* The game seems to have no dedicated servers and use Peer to Peer systems. As a result the game has huge amount of connection and sync issues. â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ GTA Online has better netcode than this game. And this game only has â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ cars.* Sometimes people in races just stay still and then win first place midrace.* Sometimes you will be racing around alone in the battle royale mode, get challenged by invisible players, and lose to them without ever seeing them. ????Some other very baffling decisions on developer's side:* You cannot preview community created liveries when installing them on already owned cars. You can when buying a car, but not when you already own the car. They also take too long to (down)load.* You cannot stop/abort the benchmark after it has been started* There's this very stupid behavior with reversing cars on keyboard where the car will completely stop when pressing S while already going backwards before starting to go backwards again* You cannot skip cutscenes in Horizon Stories* You cannot modify/recolor your car while not in a house. I.e. you can't just do it anywhere in free roam.Other issues/nitpicks I encountered:* Rewind system lacks any sort of granularity, making it frustrating to use* Horizon Arcade is unbeatable and therefore pointless, and suffers greatly from connectivity issues* Too many loading screens, one before and after each race. Want to change a car? loading screen* Coop races are also infuriating and pointless. One mistake and you are dead last with no chance of gaining ground. You also frequently get idiot teammates who push you out of the racetrack/away from checkpoints* There is no time popups (in seconds) about how far behind or ahead the closest to you driver is, or a lap time difference readout like in many other racing games* No radio wheel, only next/previous buttons, so you cannot see current track without switching radio stations 2 times* Breakable things are sometimes inconsistent. Things you might expect to not break fly away like paper (steel guardrails for example), other times you hit a small bump on the side of a bigger rock/tree and come to an instant stop. Sometimes you do get indestructible guardrails in races, sometimes you don't* Graphics look very bad in some cases, namely when its cloudy or when its wet and daytime* Photomode is very slow with its animations/loading. In general game has a lot of animations to sit through with is always frustrating. For example speed trap scores, you cannot score a speed trap while you have animations from previous attempt not finished.* Radar doesn't show the direction of a map pin at the radar's edge which would've been useful for off road cars to cut through the map* Excessive day one monetization in a full priced game - You can buy cars (packs) for real money, VIP status, a map for hidden collectives FOR REAL MONEY* It has loot boxes but you can't buy them (with real money OR in game money)* The world does feel quite dead, with barely any traffic or people around* Has weekly grind which is becoming very tiresome trend in new games* The "Horizon Stories" dialogue is cringe to the extreme* Airborne/collision physics feel very unnatural/unrealistic. I had a car just do flips on its hood for no reason after a crash. And yes, you will be expected to do jumps, which will break your car on landing if you have car damage simulation enabled.* There is no any sort of sharp corner call outs so if you turn off the race line helper you end up looking at the radar more than at the damn game just so you wont miss a sharp corner.Some good notes:* Plenty of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ to do, even if a lot of it is good for a single completion* The game has detailed car physics simulation with a bunch of overlays that display all the simulated values* Different weather conditions affects your driving. Fog, dust storms, rain, etc. Sometimes to a detriment when the road becomes slippery and you don't want that, but still.* Plenty of User Generated Content systems* Very detailed tuning system to the point of being intimidating, but has user generated presets* The grind is weekly, not daily. It has daily challenges, but they don't go away after 1 or 3 days, they open each day end 7 days after opening* A lot of difficulty options, albeit some of the settings do not give you monetary benefits

author: BANANASACK
review: This is arguably one of the best open world racing games on the market currently. Beautiful visuals and a large variety of cars to drive make this game a must-have for any fan of the racing genre. At the time of this review I only have about 10 hours played in the game but judging by the sheer amount of content on offer here out of the box I can see myself putting many more into it. Only hitches I have had personally revolve around co-op where the syncing issues can sometimes make it tough to cruise with friends but I'm almost certain these issues can get ironed out in a patch of some sort. Seriously, if you're on the fence about this game; GET IT. You wont regret it.

review: This game never works constant crashes. This game is more stable on linux. Every loading screen is like a game of russian roulette. I have never seen a game that didn't work until now. If I do on the rare occasion get in I am always in the stupid hot wheels map reguardless of whether or not I actually shut the game off there and I can't leave because ONE loading screen is a 30% shot to not crash. If I could take back my money I absolutely would. Thanks microsoft!

author: Himura
review: I bought this game when my friends level over 200 something, then they ask me to play together but they used truck instead of a racing car on a street race. They ram me with their isekai truck, 10/10 a wholesome racing experience. now im in isekai.

author: sho
review: This outstanding masterpiece keeps its charm after 72 hours spent before even an official release! A well-thought-out title with endless driving fun. I haven't played any racing-type of games for a long time (last one was some Need For Speed) Very entertaining IP! The studio has undoubtedly succeeded, with beautifully re-created Mexico, PLENTY very realistic car models, season pass, and all content likely to come regularly, Level 156 already and I'm for sure looking forward to having some more free time to come back asap and play the game more.

author: Excalibur
review: A Car Paradise Crafted to Perfection. This Game has a sense freedom that not many others have it has just about everything a Car / Racing game can have.Upgrade, mod, paint you can truly customize your car to be exactly how you want it be. Participate in Road, Rally, Offroad, and Street Races with tons of other activities as well like Horizon Arcade which is a fun party type mode played in multiplayer or just explore the amazing detailed open world of mexico the choice is up to you. it improves on basically every aspect from the previous horizon games and truly feels like a true successor to the previous horizon title.10/10 A must play imo

author: Yonge Streetâ„¢
review: So... New Forza! God I've been waiting for this for too long. I've been playing Forza from way back Forza Motorsport 4 on Xbox.I've seen the improvements along the way in both the Horizon and the Motorsport series, and let me tell you this, Forza Horizon 5 is going to be the biggest hit in the franchise so far! I have gotten a new PC and what better place to start! Graphics, sounds, animations, the attention to details and more are all better and amazing and most importantly, MORE CARS!Definitely more to come over time as well in both paid and free event format. If you want to play a car game this is it, it can't get any better than this. The emergence is unreal and unmatched to any other game in its category by a long shot.With Forza coming to Steam there is no better time to start than their newest and most advanced game on your PC.

author: D1SRUP7ER
review: Its Forza, Arcade style racing that's handed to you, it is in no way challenging. Can be fun driving around for no reason to kill time but that's about it as there doesn't seem to be any real feeling of progression and or a meaningful story.Some custom tuning etc but the novelty wares off fast, Its a good game if you don't want to think and or try to win.

author: SKOH
review: Original review was negative because of the technical disaster this game was on release. I have to give it a positive review now for the time I have spent on it and the good sessions I have had customising cars and testing them. I'm still disappointed by many aspects of the game, mainly due to its major focus on casual players, if not kids.

author: Overpowered Rogueâ„¢
review: I've been a Forza fan since Motorsport 3 on the Xbox 360, I've been playing every Forza for the past decade and honestly this has been the Horizon series at its best for me.Its a joy to play in every sense of the word, if your a hardcore car person, or just a casual, its a very easy and enjoyable game to get into, it caters to everyone, and you can do nearly everything to a huge collage of 500+ cars, which is an amazing amount of cars with more promising and somewhat convincing DLC coming out in the future. Mexico had me skeptical for the next map but they did nearly everything perfect on this map, my only slight complaint is theres no true quarter mile drag strip, but the insanely long highway and other drag strips make up for it. The map is really diverse and introduced things we haven't seen in the previous games, like a soccer field, a truly big bridge overseas, a volcano with hill climb like roads that are on it that are great for drifting, I can go on. I want to touch on about the story because its pretty solid, I was hoping that your character would talk more considering they implemented voices for your characters, but the new characters, races, acolade system, and barn finds are insane, it reminds me about Horizon 3. Car customization is near perfect for Horizon, its not NFS or GTA level but the new body kits and aero parts are a massive step up from Horizon 4, I do however dislike that Rocket Bunny kits didn't return, but these new body kits from TJ Hunt, KRC Japan, etc. Are amazing. Engine sounds are on point, the 2JZ engine sounds realistic, and same applies for most cars, and the car drops are sick too.Now to the bad, because no game is perfect no matter how good it is, its been a week since this game came out, and Horizon Online and Horizon Life is horrendous, online is nearly unplayable which is a shame, me and my friends we're looking forward to do so much online and the servers just barely work, you only get in a convoy if your insanely lucky or have a stronger wifi connection than usual, this causes the festival playlist and forzathon shop to not work, oh also cosmetic damage still sucks, exhaust backfire and sounds suck, and can be buggy, racing wheel integration is rocky, and load times are choppy on Xbox One. Despite all the cons, the game is phenomenal and is a must play for Game Pass owners, I recommend paying full price for it, and I'm looking forward for all the memories I'm gonna make on this game in the future11 people found this helpful.

author: NoWayNick
review: Lets just say MS/ Turn 10 Studios is ruining their own game. Update after update, nerf after nerf. This game has no replay value anymore. When 1st launched it had many ways to get cars, credits and wheel spins. Now all of that came to a halt with a super slow progression rate. Seems like Turn 10 Studios hooked up with 343 on how to ruin a games progression system. The Event Lab is poorly designed, not just that but a lot of aspects of the game were poorly deigned to the point it seems the game was rushed out to market because it just looks good on high graphic settings. There are better racing games out that offer the player a game based on how they want to play, not like how Turn 10 Studios that wants to dictate how you play. Ill be highly upset if the new Forza Motor sports game is this bad and or how long it will take for them to ruin that game too.

author: Shinigami
review: Lots of fun. A polished racing game, similar to FH4, just more of it. Took some ideas from Lego addon (accolades - challenges you can do) and added them into the main game. Loving it overall, although it isn't free of issues. I found workarounds for my issues, so for me all is good. The game is stable (doesn't crash much, other than at startup), performance is good (1080ti, 2560, Ultra quality with extreme geometry and textures). Hopefully, issues will be fixed over time, meanwhile I'll enjoy my weekly racing.Update: after 358 hours I believe Ultimate edition was totally worth the full price, at least for me. Definitely get it on a discount. Because you can! :D

In conclusion: Good content. Unplayable game

review: Just like Land Rover drivers, Froza Horizon 5 owners never greet each other in public. They've already had a thorough chat earlier at support forums.Srsly though, while the game is great (though it feels a lot like FH4.5), the current state of the release is appalling. Corrupted textures on roads and surfaces, memory leaks, low FPS on RTX 3080 even in 1440p, online issues, huge input problems (game constantly hit brakes on your car without any reason), terrible online, long loading times on an SSD... And I've payed extra from the most premium edition.Wheel support is just a hot mess. On T150 even 4wd cars just go crazy during braking after an hour of gameplay or so.In current state, avoid it and wait for the patches.

author: Forpatril
review: The scenery is colourful, clearly a lot of effort went to make the game visually appealing... But it's not appealing to me. The issue is not with the bugs or techincal dificulties or the poor optimisation, the whole game just isn't clicking with me. I loved driving the streets of Britain in FH4, I loved totally different seasons which were very distinctive in colours and overall feeling. I loved Britain.One can respect and admire the culture and nature of Mexico, but it's just not for me. I don't really like it.Leaving the location aside, we don't really have anything to point as a step forward from FH4. Basically we have the same game with another map, slightly different physics and awful sound. Sounds in FH4 were bad, but here I'd say it's another level of bad. Every car sounds plain and boring, Lexus LFA doesn't have the amazing scream anymore. The car sounds are pinned to front or back and there are times when you don't hear anything, like for example your friend's horn.AI in races... In short it's ridiculous. I can't get its level at all. It isn't consistent at all. Even during one race. Some races are just pure pain and frustration. And I wouldn't call myself not skilled enough.Visually not much has changed from previous version, but there's an increased load on the GPU and a resulting drop in FPS. And on top of that various glitches, like pixelated smoke. Maybe it's like this only on my system, but at this point I don't really care anymore.Much advertised accessibility... Well, okay, good, but can I turn it off? Completely? Without it screaming at me which key to press to start every time I launch the game?On the final note we have a lot of bugs, some of which were present in previous games. So... No improvement here as well.In conclusion: if you like cozy little villages of Britain like myself, this game is nor really for you. If you prefer frustration and sand with a touch of spanish word every second sentence, you're welcome in Mexico, I guess.

author: Eudaimonikos

author: Mhorrioghain
review: Long story short: Forza Horizon 4 is better. Literally. Everything FH5 does, FH4 does better.Now. There'll be rant.Yeah, graphics is great, but Mexico is pretty meh. Landscapes itself are very mediocre, there's nothing you would want to see here. Pyramids? I saw them once during story expedition and that's really enough. Volcano? Most of the time it doesn't even have lava lake, just ordinary lake. And all of this different zones feels the same. I saw all 4 seasons and they all look pretty much the same (no, some wind and rain don't make any difference). Radio... Uh. Better think that there's no radio. My favourite XS rock-station sounds more like pop-station. There's only a couple of good tracks on all of the radio stations. The rest are simply bad and/or unremarkable.The higher AI difficulty, the more broken it is. Drivatards blatantly cheat, launch like a f*cking rocket and never bother to slow down at corners. If you let them to drive too far away, you'll never ever catch them up. Even when you're happily sit at first position with drivatards far behind you, do not relax, at least one of them will suddenly appear right before the finish line breathing heavily down your neck and waiting for a moment to pass you as swiftly as transcontinental missile.Expeditions are okay-ish, showcases are good, and story missions... well, they exist. V10 and Born fast was pretty neat, El Camino would be cooler if NPC would shut her mouth for a minute, and the rest are just annoying and irritating. Let's be clear, no one plays Forza for decent dialogs, but here they're plainly bad. And voice acting... Jaysus... I prefer to shut my ears and not to hear them (but not for you, Alex, you're great, I love your thick Scottish accent; and Jaimin, I just like the sound of his voice). Spanglish is infuriating, as well as their over-excited manner of speech."Main story" - I don't see why it exists. I've unlocked all final races without doing any races at all, I was too busy discovering roads, smashing boards, earning skill points and wondering where're all the POIs. And this nerve-racking festival upgrade screen appears all the time interrupting whatever you did at the moment (I drifted peacefully performing skill chains to later unlock wheelspins and xp boosts in car masteries, leave me alone godd*mned upgrade screen!). For almost your every action you'll get accolade points. At first they're used to progress through "main quest", but once it's completed, the accolades are became completely useless. Like seriously, accolades are only needed for a global leaderboard. That's all. Just a pissing contest. FH3 had quite similar progression system with fans, unlike you actually needed to do races, stunts and stuff and earn fans to upgrade existing and unlock new festival sites, which added new races and stunts on the map little by little, not all of them at once. And it took a fairly amount of time to fully upgrade Horizon Australia Festival, not a half an hour.And now to my favourite part. Online. "You've been disconnected" - "Retry" five times in a row. "Alert! [x] OK". Isn't it amazing? Other players in freeroam disappear right before your eyes just to reappear half a minute later somewhere down the road. Astonishing, isn't it? And on top of that PG broke Forzaton Live. Now it's called Horizon Arcade and there's actually two of them: one for drift and the other for everything else. For every Arcade you still have to do 3 rounds, but now you have to do them in 10 minutes. It happens too often and without any announcement, the only way to find out that there's Arcade somewhere is to open a map and intentionally search for it. Objectives are too high and don't scale to the amount of attended players. It takes at least 5 players to complete the Arcade. But at best there'll be only one or two players with you. And sometimes other players in Arcade disappear too while still contributing their score to the objective. 'Cause the new server layer feature is absolute sh*t. I personally never saw a lobby with more then 6-10 players.However FH5 has good sides too. Cars look and sound awesome. More than five hundred cars at a launch day and even more to come. Race tracks are fine, some better, some worse. Community is nice in general (except you, rammers, with your small d*ck energy, feic you). And despite all its flaws I still recommend FH5, 'cause it's still a vey good and solid simcade racing game. But the more I play FH5, the more I want to go back to FH4. That's sad.Oh, I almost forgot. Where's my racing suit, PGG? Lock helmet behind a full collection one of the most expensive cars - Pagani? Do you really think that was a great idea, PGG? You disappoint me.

author: PolkaDotPrincess
review: EDIT: The loading times have gotten a lot worse since the Hot Wheels DLC release, sometimes taking 15 minutes to get the game loaded. Borderline unplayable. I can't, in good conscience, recommend this game in its current state. When everything is working fine, it is a masterpiece. Extremely well optimised graphics and miles of fun, but when I can't connect to a server, which can happen every other minute, it will freeze up for minutes at a time. This effects anything from browsing Auction House to multiplayer, to simply driving around. Playing offline works, but defeats the community aspect which is a large portion of this games content. Yes, I will keep playing because I want to complete the seasonal events, but no I won't recommend others do the same.

author: Arremera
review: TL;DR: The game has several problems that are more because of the developers' hypocrisy and ignorance than the game design. Just because I enjoy it doesn't mean you will.So, where do I start? Well, the leaderboards and multiplayer events alike are dominated by cheaters; in the former case, the devs have done very little to solve the problem, and in the latter, they have done practically nothing. There's also the absurd bans that are handed out seemingly at random, where people will find that their account has been banned for miniscule and sometimes even completely fraudulent causes (while people who actually DO violate TOS are still running free). While it is true that the game has been continuously been receiving content since launch, the majority of it has been lack-luster car additions that should have been in the game to begin with. Honestly, the only "proper" content drop we've gotten is the Hot Wheels DLC - here's hoping the Rally Adventure lives up to expectations.

It looks good enough and performs well enough for me which should both improve over time.Ultrawides still have that graphical issue that needs sorting, everyone including me, keeps thinking its my monitor or GPU.... lolOther reviews will cover it more in depth, for me its a simple thumbs up to new and returning players.

author: MiSF1T
review: A game where you don't want to press enter in the main menu. Somehow, the soundtrack with the visuals feels so soothing. This is all before even getting into the game.Even if racing games are not your forte, just free roaming with the car of your choice can feel so relaxing. Combine that with next-gen visual quality and the impressive soundtracks, you have a game of the year candidate on your hand.I personally don't even do the races; just choose a car that I haven't played with and just go, wherever the road takes. Play it for the races, play it for the racing sim feel, play it for the relaxing feeling of a long drive, play it for the cars. Oh and did I mention the super-realistic car sounds?

author: BlackFox
review: If you own a Fanatec CSL Elite and plan to use it on FH5 as of this review (10/21/21), be warned that you will likely encounter a lot of crashes...I literally crashed to desktop three times within 60 mins of playing. First time was on the AMG One intro race and the other two times were on the (Into The Storm) intro photo event. The game will literally crash EVERY time you do that mission using the CSL Elite so the only work around is to play on keyboard - save - plug your CSL back in - restart the game...but then the CSL will have a 50/50 chance cause other missions to have the exact same issue. Before anyone asks...yes- I ran the game as Admin- I disabled my antivirus/firewallI don't know how FH5 got released without reasonable testing for literally one of the most popular mid range sim racing wheel/pedal set...but apparently they didn't...so unless you're playing on a controller or keyboard I wouldn't waste your money on this game until this is resolved.

review: It's everything FH4 had but better, scenery is a breath of fresh air.For the people with entire wheel setups the force feedback feels alot better as wellOverall improvement, granted there are a couple of bugs AND online isnt incredibly stable just yet.But the game is also in it's first week of releasing and it's already a solid product so far.8.5/10 from me.

author: Andrew Jackson
review: Single player = It's OK, can get repetitive after you have experienced all the event types and story races.Multi player = You will struggle to have a single good race, possibly never having one. I have not found a single online match in 100 hours that I wasn't forced to use 3rd person camera to defend myself from rammers and people not even trying to race, but just ruin the race for others. There is no option to report unless you have video evidence, and so no penalties for these players since you will run into rammers EVERY race, so you will never escape them. This game direly needs a radar feature similar to Gran Turismo so that you can actually use driver/dash/hood cams without being handicapped by rammers, or at the very least some type of ranking system, or better yet, an option to race with collision turned off.Also, if you wanted to focus on rally or street races, then good luck: The online matchmaking does not let you pick, and simply rolls the dice on what type of race it matches you in.Steer clear of this game unless that sounds fun to you.

author: Hot Single Trains In Your Area
review: Buncha bull this game is. Not worth full price. Buy it at least 50 percent off otherwise it is not worth the money.NPCs everywhere ruining your jumps. You fail jumps for the most benign reasons, and then you have to drive way too far back around just to even reattempt the jump. The swamp is the worst place in the game, trees everywhere and they will stop you 200 to 0 if you so much as clip anything that cant be destroyed, which is the whole damn jungle. Races are RIGGED. Drivatars drive on a straight line at a set speed. Drivatars ignore all physics and cannot be knocked around. They will always get a speed boost when you get near them and they will always try to knock you off the road. If you make it to the finish line the game takes over and stops all your acceleration before you even make it to the finish, while all drivatars get to accelerate past you and take 1st place away from you. 4/10 do not reccomend go play gta instead.

author: Poopfeels
review: I'm a simple man. I like to drift through every single turn and I never,  touch the brakes. I enjoy the Need for Speeds and the Burnouts, and as such I never got on with any Forzas, or anything that even remotely approaches what could be called a simulator.Horizon 5 is the exception. I'm not sure why. I hated the previous entry like I hate every other sim type racer. Like its predecessor, Horizon 5 has a multitude of settings you can tweak to get your ideal experience, but while I never got a good feeling out of 4, the fifth is one kick ass game. It helps that this is also one of the best looking car games. Performance is great, with everything maxed (except for ray tracing) my 6800xt averages around 100 FPS. Most importantly of all, the game is so much fun. It just throws everything at you all at once all the time. So much cool â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ going on I can barely decide what to do, but whatever I end up doing is consistently thrilling. I can appreciate that. The sheer variety and quantity of awesome driving based activities here is mind boggling.For anyone thinking of a purchase, do it. I first played it on game pass, so that could be a decent way to try it without committing too much money. If you're looking at all the separate purchases and editions / DLCs and whatnot, you can very safely ignore all that and just get the base edition. It's already got way too much â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, and you won't feel like you miss out on anything.

author: Dusklite
review: Wow, now this is a hard one to write.On the one hand, there's a great looking game with so much potential. Even more so than Forza Horizon 4. They really went all out with cars, environment, sounds and so on.Now what's on the other hand is just really sad in my opinion.First off, there's the things that were bad in its predecessor and haven't got improved at all. Take the online connectivity for example. The removal of any ranked game mode also hints at a hearty "well, f- it" in regard to make it work fair and stable.Then there's the odd technical issues of which there a quite a bit right now from crashes to collision issues. However, I expect them to get fixed, eventually so... yeah, let's be fair and let them slide for now.The not-so-soft nudge with the FOMO gun to have to play something like playground for rewards I could stomach with minor pain.The very strange "A.I." that sometimes defies all rules of physics and becomes unbeatable with tires glued onto the road and some strange bubbling atomic liquid in the fuel injection is even harder to stomach, but let's also put that into the category of bugs to be fixed for the sake of being nice here.However!Currently, this is "repetitive tasks, the game" to improve the fastest. Grinding skill points to buy the classical failure of a British offroad vehicle, expend these skillpoints to get a roll at the "totally-not-a-lootbox" wheel, just to hand the poor thing off to someone else as a "gift"... just to profit massivly from the payout - that's completely destroying any sense of accomplishment. It's also not clear right now if that will be a bannable use of an exploit or just a major blunder what will be ignored. No official statement about the issue - all the while even granny's little gaming blog writes about it and advises people how to maximize your gains with this method.Also and not less infuriating: if you pretend to be a gamer with heavy disabilities and let the game drive itself which for some reason is something you can actually configure, it turns into an AFK XP and credit farm, completely making an XP system or buying anything with the earnable in-game currency a joke I don't seem to get and thus, cannot enjoy. There are highly rated versions of The Goliath, the longest circuit race, that go for 50 laps which lets you net stupendous amounts if you let the game just run overnight or while you do something like work from home or go out or on vacation or whatever...To add insult to injury, for a developer that does so much to make a game playable for people with disabilities (which I greatly respect by the by), the most optimal way to earn something is to act as if you are disabled and just go AFK with something taped on the accelerator or something... urgh.I know some people with disabilities and I will not even presume to talk for any person that has them, but those I know would feel very negative about this if they were into this game. They want to be able to play a game as normally as they can with what they are able to, not have it completely on autopilot and then call it "assistance". Having some things optional is alright, activating them in a combination to create a self-driving demo mode would only be fine with me if it is just that: a demo mode and not something to progress the game in.I might revise or remove the review in the future if things improve, since the game has so much potential that the current state of it almost physically sickens me with anger and sadness. I'm completely baffled that this went through any QA the way it is designed in some areas. It almost strikes me as if it was very well tested in parts, but never as a working whole.edit:The first patch for the game made the Willy farm exploit less prevalent - you can still get fast XP and thus, normal wheelspins from spending one skill point on it, so it's a meh fix if you ask me.AFK racing has been nerfed but not removed, making it not realyy viable at least compared to normal play - you can still AFK your way if you want to. Meh fix again.Then there are still cars out there that make the super wheelspin exploit still a thing. For example the Mazda RX-7 for 14 skill points. This makes the exploit harder, but given the normal rarity of super wheelspins some people will definitely go for it. Meh fix once more.Still on the fence if I should recommend the game after the "fix". Leaving it as not recommended for now since this was a really half-hearted attempt on fixing an issue. Bonus points for realizing this needed a fix in the first place, though.

author: AÌµÍ†Ì¡ Ì·ÍLÌ·ÍÌº iÌ¶Ì‘v ?
review: 12 December Update: Since christmas is coming here's an update:Should you buy the game at 60$/â‚¬ for christmas ?Depends.Do you like empty world void of NPC 50% of the time when you play online ?Do you like empty convoys where you can't see half the player ?Do you like beeing unable to see your friend's car since convoys doesn't work properly ?Do you like busted matchmaking that give you new player against level 300+ player ?Do you like broken PlayGround mode where the game can't match even team, giving you 8v4 match (yes yes ! , can't do a 6v6 !) ? Do you like scuffed respaw systme letting you wait stuck on rock hoping the game decide to respawn you ?Do you like Online Race where you can't decide which class you want to play ?Do you like do wait long period of time because the matchmaking spawned you in a race that barely started (25% complete) ? Up to you decide if this worth 60 buck or not.I hope you will enjoy your stay in Scuffed Horizon 5 :) Cheers._____________________________________________Original:So we have a game in 2021 , made by a multi billion company (even if it is not the studio per say, Microsoft is still heavily backing this) , with experienced dev (I mean that's the 5th game in the horizon serie...) and 3 year or so development. A. Triple. A. Game. -Game Pad issue accross the board-Headphone Bluetooth ? Will not work buddy-Steering Wheel issue reported multiple time-Server issue-Crash-Some object in the map will STUCK you, as in you can't move anymore, it happen in multiplayer battleground, so you're f*cked.-Matchmaking is bad, you can be matched against team of 100+level (so lot of hours) , + you can litterarly start a match in a team of 3 people, against 7 people. Still counting the other bug will edit if I catch others =) Microsoft, the company that MADE the Operating System you are on.Microsoft, the company that invented Console Online multiplayer. (original xbox)Microsoft, the company that also create gamepad, steering whell and such (i.e they hecking know how drivers works, the variety of software and  they have BILLION to invest into R&D with , at least, popular brand... we have LG steering wheel issue. LG.)60 buck for this. Meanwhile you got 5$ buck game from indy devs that  manage to never run into these issue.Yeah, modern game are amazing.If you are not concerned by the above issue, and/or you have 60 buck to spare, the game has great potential and is fun in itself, with hopefully more content released over the years to come.But if you use/expected to use one the above and/or 60 buck is your semestrial own-gift ? Buddy, you better wait for a sale (christmas soon ?) , a friend gift, or check out all the popular issue reported (on forum or in review), buy the game, test all those thing in 2 hours to check if YOU have the same issue, and then decide to keep it or refund it. Not trying to be a troll or a ranting teenager hereJust trying to warn people about the "impressive quality" of a Triple A multi-billion company's game that cost 60$/â‚¬ in the current day and age. At any rate, hope you're having fun online. Maybe we'll meet each other on a drift session.Cheers.PS:You probably won't read this since it's at the bottom of the post but...If you're a chiller , and If you're having fun with the game, great for you, the game is fun on some aspect. But try to understand not everybody can throw 60$ on something that half-work half the time , with issue that shouldn't exist in 2021. We're not on Windows XP, those above mentioned device are very comon nowadays.

author: Aexer
review: If you liked Forza Horizon 4's gameplay but couldn't help but cringe from the stupid voice lines and hated swimming through 6 menu tabs just to tweak a tune on the track, then this is the game for you. Most of the gripes that I had with the previous game have been fixed here. Most of the core gameplay and tuning is the same as the last game, so I'll only talk about improvements from the last game and things that weren't improved:* Smoother steering inputs. The steering inputs have been smoothed are adjustable, so less jerky movements with a controller. * Haptic feedback.  Vibration is applied independently to the left and right motors in your controller. This means that when you hit the brakes, the vibration intensity ramps up as you increase brake pressure and will shake when you begin to lose grip. You can also feel vibrations in the drivetrain through the gas pedal (right side). This gives the player more important information that is important for improving times and for good immersion.* Progression rewards, You get to choose what kind of events you unlock through the Adventure tab, Any event can contribute to this progression system, so you are free to play around with dirt racing a bit, but still make progress to unlocking more street races if that's your preference.* Dialogue is still bad but better than before. * The menu has been really cleaned up so it doesn't take as much time to navigate. * Raytracing gives high quality reflection effects on cars and makes the lighting more immersive (anyone that has done photoshop knows that lighting is the best way to make your editing believable)* Cosmetics are no longer walled behind roulette rolls. You can outright buy most normal cosmetics if you want, but special cosmetics are locked behind events and roulette rolls. This is a more enjoyable system in my opinion.* Microphone is now off by default, so no more hearing creepy breathing during your multiplayer race unless it's intentional.The bad:* Aggressive monetization model- DLC is really expensive and most of it hasn't been released yet so there is no way of knowing if it is a good value or not.* The map is still messy* Too many cars, not enough variety. I felt that there isn't as much visual variety of car types in this game compared to the previous game.* You basically need to look up how to play multiplayer modes because the game never adequately explains how to join up with friends or even game rules for online multiplayer games.

author: yar2000
review: I liked Horizon 4 but it never gave me the same "Horizon feeling" that Horizon 3 did. This game has that, and lots of it. Probably mainly because of the map (the map is great in this game).Don't go into this game thinking its a game like TDU2 with an emphasis on progession. The progression in this game may as well not exist, its not the focus of the game. Cars  be handed to you, and you will unlock a lot of things very fast. Again, its not the point of the game. This game is more focussed on completion than progression - and in my opinion, the completion is fun.Graphically not much needs to be said, it looks insane. There's still some issues with the graphics and framerate, but I'm sure these will get fixed in the not-too-distant future. However, as of right now, expect some blurry textures and GPU-usage drops in online (leading to massive framelag).The biggest downside of the game right now is the amount of bugs. Connection issues, freezes in upgrade menus, etc. Its just annoying. Again, it probably will get fixed, but just keep it in mind.All in all most definitely worth it imo.

author: mcs
review: Forza Horizon 5 is the racing game for everyone, which takes outsiders from the racing genre and turns them into followers of the speed, and for those who are already fans, it offers an almost endless variety of activities and challenges. Also very remarkable is the representation of Mexico, which offers vibrant landscapes full of incredible details that only those who live in Mexico will recognize. It is an indispensable game and highly recommended.

author: StrayCat
review: Basically a forza horizon 4 expansion dlc with a bit of tone down feature compare to FH4:Feature removed in FH5 compare to FH4:- No drag strip light at the drag lanes - The PI score does not update at the top of the screen after placing upgrade (not yet install/ in basket) unlike FH4 - User interface at custom upgrade menu (choosing component upgrade) is worst compare to FH4 UI- Does not give any notification right after searching/finding online race especially in joined friend's convoy- No team adventure in open horizon (online pvp)- Cannot pick specific class or race type in open horizon pvp unlike in FH4  (advanced search menu) - No Rocket Bunny widebody kit Bug encountered in FH5:- Dark map/enviroment in online open horizon after finished online street race - Stuck at rewind animation (car does not move) when initialing rewind in online race- Black headlight when choosing car (car icon) in change car/auction/autoshow- AI rubberbanding in unbeatable difficulty (but hey its unbeatable...so..yeah)- Player teleporting in online match (maybe due to poor connection but if they having poor connection, make their car ghosted) - After exiting house/horizon festival, there a freezing for a couple a second before the car could move (FH4 exit are seamless compare to these)So far performance wise is good, i got solid 60fps on high setting (vsync on) in 1080p resolution. My rig:- Ryzen 3 3300X- GTX 1070 8GB- 16 GB RAM- Installed at HDD Western Digital Blue

author: baad
review: A serious downgrade from Forza Horizon 4.I had over 800 hours in FH4, about half of it in Ranked races; if not racing, then tuning and testing cars for Ranked.In FH5 they removed Ranked.They kept the Eliminator which is bugged. It freezes when challenging an opponent, sometimes giving them a huge advantage. It also disconnects randomly. I got disconnected just when I reached the final point of the Eliminator (I was in the first place).Rubber banding for Drivatars; and it's terrible.I rarely get teammates in the Arcade (former Forzathon); 90% of these events, I play them solo. And even if I get teammates, it's mostly one other, two max.Most of the custom races are plain annoying, but they are forced onto us through seasonal events.Some races with car restrictions don't show what the restrictions are. You tune a car only to find out it's not eligible. This is especially bad when you're in a convoy and can not check the eligibility list yourself.Patches seem to break things rather than fix them. After the last patch, I have very long waiting times when starting the game. Even going into photo mode takes ridiculously long.The Boneshaker is still overpowered...These are just a few of the problems that this game has. There are more that you will encounter here and there, making the entire experience just...annoying.PRO: nice map...In conclusion:Buy only the standard version of the game and that too only if it's heavily discounted.
