author: ZeroTacTiX
review: Such a quality game! I think if you go into Forza thinking it's a NFS-competitor, you might actually be disappointed, yet I'm stumped these 2 games are compared closely by many online, and many seem to prefer Forza.. I really don't get it.Here's the thing... NFS is pure arcade, Forza is NOT, at least not if you play with all assists off, Simulation steering, and enable Manual Shifting with Clutch. Forza is a SIMCADE. Fight me all you want on it, it's the definition of a SIMCADE. I'll explain why.I haven't driven a real car on the road in 20 years. I remember nothing of my brief experience driving my dad's car. But I actually learnt how to drive on Forza Horizon 5 using a Logitech G29 wheel + Shifter. Now I can drive just fine on Automobilista 2, and if I could do THAT, I know the MECHANICS of how to drive a real car. Though following traffic rules n stuff might be a challenge to come in the future. My point being, this game strikes a great balance between arcade and sim - it allows driving with all assists on, using your handbrakes in every corner like a NFS player, but it also appeals to those who want to experience SIM racing at its basic form - hence it's SIMCADE. Also, in order to win in Forza, you need to follow racing lines, manage throttle pressure, actually brake in corners etc etc, which don't really apply for NFS. So I feel comparing these two together, only makes sense if you choose to play Forza with all assists on. Even then, if that's what you prefer doing, you lack cop chases in Forza, a story and progression that's meaningful, like you have in NFS. I feel NFS wins that battle.But if you're a person who just likes cars, and wants to experience driving 100s of cars, listening to how each one sounds, and experience how they all handle differently, Forza is AMAZING on that front. And especially if you own a wheel, this is a very chill experience, because driving between points is actually relaxing fun - on a controller I just want to skip to the next race.Conclusion: If you like cars and nice graphics, this is the game to get. If you simply want a more action packed game, get NFS.

author: itsokmydadisrich
review: I do not have a very good opinion of this game and Steam. This is the first racing game I ever purchased. I figured I have a controller, a Razer controller, mainstream company shouldn't be an issue. Get in game, I cant move left or right.I can't steer the car. I can accelerate and I can break....that's it. The controller works in every other way in the menu and other UIs but when in a race I cannot change my direction. So I start checking out Youtube tutorial and steam forums for a solution, and apparently this is an actual issue with others also. So I try everything, doesn't work, and give up and request Steam for a refund. DENIED. "You have played more than 2-hr max limit." Okay. So I tried to just get a wallet refund and use the $60 to buy another game, which actually works. DENIED. I was in game for 4-hrs. I bought the game less than 12 hrs ago, spent all of the 4-hrs trying to get the game to work on my controller, have zero achievements or anything, but I exceeded the 2-hr limit. This is such a scam. Had I actually played the game, I would accept my fate. I am just letting others know to be careful with Steam. They are scamming people out here. To not even give credit so a person can buy a game they can play is just not fair practice in my humble opinion. Gaming industry is becoming very toxic and scammy. Enjoy.

author: Bragne
review: Forza Horizon 5 is the best arcade racing game right now. Graphics, gameplay and engine sounds are tremendous. But virtual customizations are so restricted when compared to Need for Speed series and The Crew 2. Also this game is not much different from Forza Horizon 4. I think the game needs new modes and events. However, it is really fun to play FH5 despite everything.

author: Snowfern_
review: I'll start off by saying this is an excellent game.The graphics, the optimisation, the driving physics, the car roster - all very good.But sadly I'll have to give it a "not recommended" due to how the devs treat this game.They have gotten complacent and put in zero effort to make actual content for players. The 10th anniversary update is enough of a joke and you wouldn't think they can lower the bar any further, but oh boy they manage. The Donut Media update - the latest one, is absolutely awful. Recycled events, recycled character models instead of modelling them after actual people they're based from, and a bunch of recycled car from Horizon 4 treated as "new". All the while a lot of QoL changes that people have been asking since the 3rd game have been continuously ignored. Not to mention the absolute lack of support for single player content, if you don't plan to race in multiplayer expect to get bored quick (although my 400hr playtime might have lowered the credibility of that claim a bit).If you're going to buy a Horizon game at this time, buy 4. It's got smaller, less varied map, and much worse sound but they're basically the same game - and cheaper and more completed.I'll update the review once they actually improve the game.For now, I don't recommend it especially not at full price.EDIT 1 (2023/01/09): Horizon 4 is crashing like crazy now and I don't think anyone can actually play it with stable performance at the moment, so don't buy Horizon 4 either lol

author: Dub-Funk
review: Easy review this time around.   This game is the first game I have ever spent $90 on.  I will start by saying it was worth every single dollar.  This is the most gorgeous racing game I have ever played, and the car count is not only insane, but the sheer level detail into everything down to the engine sounds is staggering.It's not perfect, but my gripes are minor.  I wish there was underglow, just for sake of making your cars more personalized.  Also, the multiplayer aspect is utter trash (read the discussion section of the game page, as I don't feel like getting that in-depth about it).  You should also be able to sell cars straight-up instead of having to auction them, FFS.I would recommend the hell out of this game, more for single player ripping...  Bombing through Tropical Storms or Sandstorms in multi-million dollar rides is breathtaking. I will play this game for a LONG time.Oh yea... It's still being updated all the time, and they keep fixing things and adding more cars, so it may end up being the perfect game...  Time will tell.

author: ð”¸qua
review: Forza 5 is a fantastic racing game that delivers an immersive and thrilling experience for players. The graphics are top-notch, with stunningly realistic environments and car models that truly bring the racing world to life. The gameplay is smooth and intuitive, with a wide variety of cars and tracks to choose from and customizable options that allow you to tailor your experience to your liking. The AI opponents are challenging but fair, providing a satisfying sense of competition. Overall, Forza 5 is a must-have for any racing game fan, and a joy to play for anyone looking for an adrenaline-pumping adventure on the virtual track.

author: Petch
review: I have played the game for 30h and the core game play is great, I like driving the cars, I like the map and so on.I have been playing a lot of co-op, and that is grate. There are some small problems with updating positions over the network men in general both players see approximately that same thing at the same time. (but it is not a competitive FPS experience)The things that I do not like.1. After the "Donut" update the game will not start at all. (I hope this will get fixed)2. You need a windows online login and you need to find your friends through xbox game bar and it is a bit of a hassle to start a convoy. I do not understand way this is not handled through steam.3. When you play a race and you would like to play the race again but with another car or another setup, you need to exit the race go back to the open world back up like 10 m and start the event/race again. This takes way too much time and there is way too much loading involved.4. The menu system is way to complicated, and you need to load in another menu if you would like to tune your car or just see the 0-60 time. Things that you only use one or two times doing a gaming session is impossible to remember the location of. Also a menu should be intuitive you should not need to remember anything.Update: 55 hours 22-11-22 (dd-mm-yy)After the Donot update I have to shot a python program that I am running on my pc, otherwise the game will not start. and as soon as I open the python program the game shuts down. I guess it is some anti cheat thing.But the only thing the python program do is logging and plotting my CPU temperature, water temperature, CPU power and frequency.After the Donot update there was a small 2GB update, and that update have made my game crash in the middle of the game.Now I also have much more trouble getting into a race with my convoy, and the load times before starting a race is even longer.It feels like you spend 50% of the time dealing with crashes and loading the game, 25% racing and 25% driving around in the open world.

author: Fklife
review: The First Thing is This game needs a Good pc you can't Play it on older systems Why?  Let me tell you you need to have at least 4gb vram the game eats VRAM like crazy if u have under 4 gb vram  u can't play it.  actually, u can but u get stutters, lags, and errors you can play stable  with  more  ram more than 8gb because optimization is  nice but  not great  and u cant  get  60 plus or 60  fps  because of the limitations of  vram anyway After Forza Horizon 4 Forza horizon is evolved with this game everything about it (well not everything..) it's better than Forza Horizon 4 the map is  huge  Ä± mean  its  huge  Ä± have never seen a bigger map  on  any  Forza game it has more activities on the map more story things, etc and u can play any race or mission coop and it is great  the only problem is fewer cars than  Forza horizon 4 but they gonna add more Ä± am sureand the car engine sounds are more realistic than FH4  u can feel the car u are driving not like the same engine in all cars if you love Forza horizon 3 and 4  u are  gonna enjoy this more than FH3 And Fh4 but u need a good pc -------------------------------------------------------------------------------And Let's compare the Forza Horizon 5 with previous games---------Good Things About the game :+Optimizaton is very nice+ map is bigger than any Forza game and lots of stuff to do + engine sounds are godlike every time you hear the sounds ohh god ...+ more realistic than Forza Horizon 4+ Better multiplayer + gameplay better than any racing game ---------------------------------------------------------------------------Bad Things About The game :- There are Still Lots of bugs's in the game an advice stay away from the rocks- server problems, crashes- seasons are a big disappointment after  Forza Horizon 4 there is no winter and seasons are just gone Ä± mean they're here in the game but you can't say there is a difference between seasons they are all the same- It is less fun than Forza Horizon 4 You need to grind more the get rewards, etc and wheelspins are nerfed you 7/10 u get money instead of a car. and fewer forza edition cars than Forza horizon 4 and that's a big lose- The Wheelspins aren't the only one is Nerfed The Car Speeds Are too you Can't do 500 kmph anymore even with Jesko and kinda ruins the game's fun. I don't know it is a - but the 2021 Cars are Dlc not All Of them but Nice ones are--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall Forza Horizon 5 is more realistic game than fh4 and 3 you can't do broken engine swaps you won't get more wheelspins or cars or Cr You need to grind more to earn rewards etc  but. there is one thing that hasn't changed FUN YES it is Still an Fun And Enjoyable Game Ä± recommend without questioning  if you love racing games and cars it definitely worth a try

author: AngryGirl
review: Driving is great, cars are beautiful and customization options are vast and varied. Which is what I bought the game for. That said... many gripes:- the menus are a mess, there's so many random things to click to claim and unlock that it's just a pain - alt- tabbing out of the game won't let you get out of the menu, until you toggle the fullscreen option- GPS just breaks sometimes, had it chirping at me constantly throughout an entire 20 min race - loading times are long- when you play in a convoy, if one person misses the invite (because they're stuck in a loading menu or still stuck leaving the last race) you have to leave and remake the convoy and repeat the whole process to get the race set up- the story / voices are annoying, just let me drive !  - one time, I spawned on top of a highway tunnel on the side of the cliff- probably spend more time driving to a race and more time loading into the race, than racingBut all in all, the driving and racing part is great, so it does what it needs to. Just wish the rest could be tightened up a little.

author: Naruto
review: This game, hmm,,, In short : TAKE THE GAME IF U DON"T HAVE FH4. I took this this cause I bought FH4 relatively recently and had not done much grinding in it and didn't want to do it again for the FH5, so bought FH5 to do the grind in this instead. BTW I highly recommend the premium edition to save some of your time in the grinding part in case you don't have much free / playing time like me.what this youtube video to understand better: PROS:1) Great Open world with different zones ex. forest, desert, arid etc. to do a freeroam around.2) Great variety of cars3) Good driving experience 4) Great communitySo far it looks good RIGHT!!!! Well ironically the good points are somewhat bad. WHY?CONS:1 and 2 combined) As I said the Open world has different zones so that means that u only have a section of map if u want to play only a particular climate and even in that the SNOW is a very small area. Personally I am not a fan of snow but coming from FH4 the decrease in size of the play area hits me hard as I don't like the SAND and DESERT part much which greatly reduces the map size.If this was not all the second point of PROS will make it a bit WORSE that is Great Variety of CARS. People coming with the thoughtthat you will drive in 10 different hyper cars to chill out after working hard for hours. LOL!! WAKE UP FROM YOUR FAIRY TAIL!!until and unless you have spent hours farming for credits you can't buy those Hyper-Cars. Let's make a rough estimate of the grindingLONGEST RACE: GOLIATH (54 KM) which takes about 10-12 min. with a BUGATTI DIVO on average difficulty gives the followingrewards:a) 30-35K experience (basically 2 lvl ups) which in turn gives u 2 wheel spins which can give you an average credit of 100K.b) 150K direct credit.c) some other extra stuff such as car mastery points which don't have any credit value but let's say worth 10KThis takes the total to: 260K BUT a decent hyper car can cost you anywhere from 1MIL to 4MIL easy and hence you will spent at least your starting hours (may be around 30ish) just to get a couple of decent hyper-cars.What this essentially does is takes away the joyful experience of riding your vehicle across the enormous open world.I know you get some good cars with the premium edition but that's not even nearly good.SO although this is a huge open world and great variety of cars it doesn't allow you to completely leverage it.3) GOOD driving experience....... CORRECT. Good driving experience -- CORRECT again. BUT DRIVING != RACING. The racing element is complete â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. Do I even need to explain it?-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------BOTTOM LINE: TAKE THE GAME IF U DON"T HAVE FH4. I took this this cause I bought FH4 relatively recently and had not grind done in it and didn't want to do it again for the FH5 so bought FH5 to do the grind in this instead.At this point I think that this series is better to be bought in rotation for even next to next title. like FH, FH3, FH5 and FH2, FH4, FH6 (when it comes).COMMUNITY is the only good part of this.

review: good game

author: Hiukuss
review: Buy Horizon 4 instead. This may have more, newer cars but honestly not worth it for the frustrationWay too many bugs to justify paying full price for this game.Rewind glitches a lot, textures disappear often, courses sometimes don't have objects placed properly thus can't be finished, crashes every first game startup, pause menu randomly opens, memory leaks, progress doesn't always save--my airport drag strip jump is still complete but all the roads around it became undiscovered in the last week. May have been due to an update though, but still.. c'mon. 4/10 just for visuals (when they work) and new cars.

author: Jagged
review: The cars and general driving mechanics of this game are some of the best-in-class for racing games. Everything you might want in a driving game is in Forza Horizon 5, with two negative exceptions:The soundtrack is not very good at all, especially compared to other titles like The Crew 2 (which has an amazing soundtrack, but is otherwise inferior to FH5 in just about every way). This includes low track variety and quality.The game doesn't have much, if any, of a progression arc. You get access to basically all different kinds of races and car classes almost immediately, from minivans straight to supercars. While I feel like this was definitely a significant missed opportunity, you should still play FH5 if you're looking for a really solid driving experience with a diverse set of tracks, race types, and cars.The game has great in-depth tuning options that you can take advantage of, or not if you prefer to simply get a car, upgrade it to a standard racing preset, and get to racing.

author: niohiki
review: The driving is fun, the map is nice, the car models very nice. The AI rubberbanding not so much. And mostly, having "normal" cars behind playlist events (I can buy a Koenissegg from the autoshow, but not a bunch of Audis?) is just there to promote grind, and arguably inflate their concurrent player number for stonks. The way they've setup the auction house (and its absurd buyouts) goes in this direction too.I guess I could enjoy the game as-is, what with the Autoshow selection of cars being more than decent - but the game's insistence on displaying FOMO-like messages has worn me out. Do not recommend.

author: Master Beast
review: Although this game is meant to be an arcade racing game, it is one of the most realistic driving games I have ever played. Sure, things like jumping and crashes might not be realistic, but driving, racing, braking, acceleration, traction theory, steering, AI racing opponents, cars, everything is almost as realistic as it gets. The scenery and graphics are outstanding. This isn't just a game for the average gamer, as a car enthusiast, this game contains many iconic cars from all around history. Cars such as the AC Shelby Cobra to the early iconic C1 corvettes, name a car and this game will probably have it. The stories and missions this game features are amazing. This would be the number one game I would recommend to anyone.

author: ã‚¿ã‚¤ãªã¿
review: Forza Horizon 5 is a fun game with great graphics and hours of entertainment, FH5 really offers a great driving experience as the sounds and feel of the car is amazing.BUT.... This game has a problem with performance, I'm running pretty decent hardware yet since launch I am still having problems to this date with crashing on start up. If I do some how manage to get pass the first loading screen after about 30 minutes the game starts having massive lag spikes and environment textures start flickering! For example, roads flicker to a all black colour and trees, grass and etc flickers to tiny CYMK coloured squares. Honestly, ray traced Cyberpunk 2077 runs 100x better than Horizon 5 at the moment!19th of January 2023 update:So turns out that my computer was the problem, had to use a DDU program to uninstall old driver updates from an old graphics card I had. Turns out this fixed all crashing issues, and the texture issue was fixed sometime August last year.  So now that I have had time to enjoy the game properly, I can say this is probably one of my favourite Forza's to date. Its addictive!

author: Cody Furlong
review: The game is ok if you like racing cars, or are a fan of the series. But for what I paid I was expecting more. Long loading times, unskipable cut scenes, frequent bugs and crashes, is just the start. Along with cars that are locked behind special event walls you will never get,  The only way to sell cars you don't want is through a live action house, no used car dealer. Which means most of the time you will be left giving your duplicate cars away for free when they don;t sell at the action. When it comes to visual customization of the cars, 90% of them will only have the same bland body kit option. The list goes on.

author: TombstoneRecon
review: I have almost 350 hours.  When the game is not plagued by bugs, its great.  Sadly, since the hot wheels DLC came out, bugs, crashing, game freezing, is CONSTANT.  Itâ€™s annoyingâ€¦ I have kids and when I want to come on quickly for an hour or so, my entire hour is spent constantly restarting the game and hoping it does not freeze again.  I have had enoughâ€¦ we as gamers deserve better than this.  The PC version through steam is now complete garbage since Hot Wheels came out.  I cannot even get back to Mexico as that loading screen freezes.  I am stuck in Hot Wheels world and cannot do anything because god forbid I start a race and it freezes.

author: Rozzzzzzzz
review: The game is good, but its been 8 months since its release and you can still often experince different bugs in the game, i.e. connectivity issues, unable to join a convoy, going invisible while in a convoy and most notably CONSTANT game crashes. When starting the game it crashes, while it's loading it crashes, and sometimes while driving it just freezes.For unknown reasons the crashing problem only seems to occur on AMD graphics cards. Although the 2 PC's on which this problem occurs are quite high-end as well as being well above the recommended specs and have absolutely no problem running the game on max settings,but even when lowering the graphics settings to the lowest the game still manages to crash. The game has had many updates but to no avail. Everything we have tried to resolve this issue hasn't seemed to work. I have notified Playground Games but i've had no response and nothing has changed for now.So to sum it all up the game is great the graphics are beautiful and it's fun, but the only bad thing is that it crashes :)

review: I have just started to get into racing games with a bit more realism than Need for Speed, and I am having a blast! author: Unclothed Serpent
review: It's a pretty fun game all things considered, the main problem I experience is really bad pop-in, even after doing things to help improve it. The ultra settings for textures and world geometry are bugged, after playing for about 30 minutes you'll get rainbow textures or foliage will have a missingno-esque texture. The game runs fine, it looks fantastic when everything works properly. The racing feels like a forza game, if you played 4, it's basically the same game new area. The reason for not recommending the game is because of the issues that haven't been fixed since the game came out. Looking for solutions or other people experiencing these bugs and you'll see it all the way back to when it launched. It breaks the immersion and sometimes ruins the game. If you have ray tracing on there's a chance the game will crash while in the garage because of a bad texture. The courses that they release for the timed events are cool enough, however, they have a lot of issues, they tend to be these long and winding tracks that go up into the air and do tight turns and what not, it's cool in concept, but it feels like it was put together by an amateur because there are huge seems in the tracks where you'll hit it and you'll lose all speed and can't make the turn requiring you to rewind and hope you don't lose too much speed. That's not the only issue though, it seems there are a lot of graphical issues with these tracks too, causing huge pieces of geometry to disappear, for example, I did one that was really cool, but the mountain was disappearing at certain angles and it looked really bad. The base game races are quite fun though. If they can get better seasonal track design and fix the graphical issues, I think that it would be worth the $60, but as of right now, get it one sale for cheaper, or just wait until you see an update to the bugs.I should mention my specs before people call them out for the game being poorly optimized.RTX 3070 OCI9-10850K32gb 3200Mhz raminstalled on an SSD, 1tb, only about 200gb of storage used. windows 11 installed on NVmeand most importantly, have a nice day :)

author: Your_Pal_Sasquatch
review: The game is great.  There is lots of customization for tuning and paint jobs etc.  Its even better with friends.  Except for when the game crashes.  Online racing is fun except for when people who have an extra chromosome decide to do nothing but ram.  Brainlets like them ruin the online racing.  If that is not for you there is Rivals which is posting time trials on a leader board for a sprint race route  or circuit.  Monthly and weekly challenges fell a bit grindy considering that's the only real way to earn most of the new cars that get added into the game.  It would be nice if they added more new cars even if they were just regular cars that aren't sporty, and give them  crazy engine swaps.  Who wouldn't want to put a 1700HP Twin Turbo V8 in a toyota corolla  with  offroad suspension and fly through the baja portion of the map or put drag slicks on it and shame every trust fund kid in a lambo ont the road.  Anyways now that im done with this probably useless review the TLDR is Game Gud but people who can't drive at all will ruin it regardless.  Anyways back to my regular scheduled existential crisis.

author: âœªSeltrA
review: I don't feel alive when playing this game. Like, it reminds me Forza Horizon 3 so much. Some of the roads are just got copy pasted from Forza Horizon 4. I had so much more fun in FH4 when I first downloaded that game. I played the game (FH4) for 10hrs straight in one day. FH5 didn't gave me that hype and vibe. Cities felt ghost, we had that rainforest feeling back in FH3 so its not a new taste, coast roads are like... meh. Overall: I didn't like this game as much as I did when FH4 came out. I know there are people that who liked this game but I didn't and here is why. If you want to drive these new cars and other ones that will added to the game in the future, buy this game. 6.5/10. No offense.

review: Great graphics, the cars sound great, the story-line can be finished in 30 hrs but there is a downside. The game needs heavy optimizing because (in my case) when I play for 3 hrs. + the game starts to have lots of lag and I get heavy frame-drops (even tho I don't have a potato pc) and when I play online after some time the textures go crazy (the road is rainbow, the mountains change color and so on). Update : Recently I saw Forza has optimized their game like there are no more frame-drops and personally I didn't experience the rainbow glitch. And for people that have Rtx graphics card (including me) the only place that the game has ray-tracing is in the garage. Overall its a great game, stunning map and beautiful sights.

author: gillg06
review: EDIT: I just logged into this game for the first time in a month or so, and the experience I had changed my mind on recommending this game. Everything said below still applies, but...well, hear me out.Today I was so excited when I logged in to see that there's a new expansion! Upon opening the game, I was brought to a loading page that showed the cool new Hotwheels tracks. I loved Hotwheels as a kid, and these cool, mid-air tracks looked really impressive and fun. I immediately set my GPS for the location. It looks really cool and I got really excited. I drove basically all the way across the map over about 5 minutes, got to the event, and watched the really exciting video describing the Hotwheels expansion, which really got me amped for the experience. I was ready to purchase the new Formula 1 style car and give it a go. I hadn't seen F1 style cars in the game before, and was really excited to try them on the new tracks.After the hype video, I was brought to a landing page that described all of the perks I could get if I buy the expansion. Since it brought me right into the event when I loaded the game, I had assumed it was just part of the game, and felt a bit led on, but was kind of relieved to see I would get a bunch of other perks for buying the expansion....until I saw that the expansion pack I had been sold on was FIFTY DOLLARS?! The Hotwheels on its own is only $20 - about double what I had expected to pay - but I was a bit relieved seeing I would get extra perks with my purchase...until I saw how much the extra perks cost!I just feel like I've been duped. I thought I bought the full game. I thought maybe I'd need to pay to get certain cars early etc, but I didn't realize I'd get hyped up about cool new content and perks, only to learn I'd need to pay almost the full cost of the game *again* to get them.You lost me. I will get my money's worth out of the game, but I'll probably never buy another Forza game unless they really change the way they do business.------Original Review------I have really mixed feelings about this game. I have enjoyed it quite a bit, but nonetheless I am left feeling disappointed with my purchase.This was my first major racing game in a long time. I've played loads of Need for Speed and Gran Tourismo games, but never Forza. On one hand, it's definitely a very complete racing game that has the "real feel," ie it's not insanely unrealistic in terms of driving physics, like, say, Need for Speed games. That said, it's also not incredibly punishing; my car doesn't get wrecked when I drive through the desert, so it's still a fun, casual play. The car customization is deep and thorough, with rather realistic performance upgrades and just tons of visual options. The car selection is second to none -  all of the classics are here, plus tons of awesome new stuff, and a bunch of obscure cars I'd never even heard of before. The graphics are great. The true open world approach is really cool as well - I love just roaming the map and enjoying the beautiful scenery, while also racing in the open world (albeit on confined tracks).Despite all this, I've gotten bored really quickly. I maxed out my car in under 20 hours of gameplay, and I've already gotten enough credits to buy insane high end vehicles. There's no real story content. Despite offering loads of customization and a huge selection of cars, the game feels incredibly shallow. I don't feel very invested in the game world, or my car. With maybe a few dozen races under my belt, I feel like I'm already just kind of polishing off content to 100% the game.  I don't think I've ever thought of any game this way before, but somehow this game isn't linear enough - you just earn credits, upgrade your car, and do whatever you want. It sounds nice, but it got boring way too fast for a game at this price.If you want a fairly realistic racing sim that isn't *too* realistic, with lots of car choice, an open world feel, and deep customization, this is it. If you just want to do some casual racing with relatively quick access to all of your favorite cars, that's what you'll get here.But if you want a game you can sink hundreds of hours into that will give some sense of accomplishment or investment when you are finally able to fully upgrade your favorite ride, or unlock that crazy high end car you've been dreaming about it...as much as I hate to say it, and as much as I hate EA...I think the Need for Speed games still have it beat.Overall I love this game, and I still recommend it, but I can't say it's as enjoyable as some of my other favorite NFS or GT favorites.

author: Wheelie Gamer
review: ive had FORZA horizon 4 and 5 and i will say they both have their negatives and their positives.as im reviewing no.5 i will start with the positives- its had a heck of a lot better optimisation for all computer setups- not just super powered gaming rigs but also gaming laptops and dare i say it high powered regular laptops may get a look in to.whenever i launched no.4 it gave me an error about my gaming laptop being to below par to run it and i had to run it in windowed mode-i dont think laptop architecture were really given much of a look in when it came to testing.however....i do not get that with no.5 and i even manage to get a lot of my settings on high. my laptop uses a ryzen 7 4000 CPU and a RTX 2060 GPU, and 32GB of added kingston fury sodimm RAM,runs on a western digital P50 SSD game drive as my internel WD SSD is only 256GB.the ray tracing capabilitys of this GPU are ignored by the game and itll crash if you try and run it with ray tracing,its probably not seen in the same light as the PC RTX 2060 nor does it deserve to be as it wont have the same power. however without ray tracing if you tinker with your settings and work out what doesnt make it unstable you can get it looking very fine without the need for RT.purely out of testing,i find for about half an hour to an hour i get almost no problem maxing out most of my settings and playing normaly until the screen starts flickering and itl screen burn if left to its own devices. i get tell tale micro delays in the cars controls that the CPU isnt keeping up with the game.putting everything on medium noticibly helps with my setup,but obviously it doesnt look as good so you have to balance between what you want the most.i only wish there was tons of snow like the winter season in no.4,that was my only downer about no.5.it was great to explore the new map though people shoud be aware that not everyone on the server wants to do convoys or racing,some of us just want to drive around and take it easy.a lot of its drivers have social anxiety and/or some form of autism,or they may just want to chill and drive to recover from a rubbish day theyve had.id say get both 4 and 5,while they do feature common things,theyre both also different and a worthwhile play,id still be playing no.4 if i hadnt of got locked out of my account.

author: Sgt. FosFor
review: Forza Horizon 5  is a racing game. But its heart isnâ€™t really about just racing at all. For my money, this spin-off series has built its reputation and quality around different foundations. Itâ€™s a series about culture. Itâ€™s about the mood, the tone, the feel.Part of all that is how each vehicle literally feels as it cruises around its open world map, but a bigger part of it is that nebulous, difficult-to-describe thing the game activates within you. Many things activate this bit of the brain, like over-the-top set-pieces and silly motoring stunts - but an enormous chunk of it is about one thing: the gameâ€™s world. I love this game!

author: xJSerpent
review: My updated review for Forza Horizon 5. It is a long one so be prepared to read.PROS:-FH5 offers a wide variety of cars to choose from. There's almost always a car you are bound to enjoy driving and building. -Driving physics has improved since the previous game. RWD and FWD cars now feel much more usable in races, rather than always having to AWD swap a car. I sincerely enjoy racing in online lobbies in my RWD car, even if it requires more skill to drive. But that feeling of winning or gaining a podium finish felt more satisfying than a 'cheesed' win.Now for CONS, and this is a big one:For one, the difficulty balance is horribly designed. In most races, the AI in first place will almost always be too far to catch up to that getting a first place finish is impossible. The way that the AI are structured in races is this: hard to catch up to but once you overtake first place, then the AI backs off. There's no level of consistency in races. The wins just don't feel satisfactory at all if the competition backs off when you take first position. Worst of all, the AI can be really cruel in cross-country or dirt races, where they will harness an unworldly amounts of grip on dirt. It makes lower class races impossible to win because your car is too underpowered and lacking that grip, or S2 races feel like chaos. Second, the Horizon story and characters. The story missions feel lackluster and the dialogue is just unappealing. Everything just feels 'safe' so it's not pushing any sort of creativity. Showcase events are too scripted where the AI will always stay ahead and drastically slow down so you'd win to get that 'photo finish' win. Also, some of the story missions that requires you to get to a destination on time to get the 3 star rating just feels awfully written. The game pretty much wants you to cheat and not stick to the route suggested, otherwise you won't make the 3 star time. Third, the balance of performance for cars. This game does emphasize on being able to use any car in races, but NOT in online racing though. Because of "meta" cars existing in this game, almost everyone will just stick to what's the best to win races without ever venturing in using whatever car they want to drive. 9/10 times someone just uses a meta car and outright wins the race with no sweat. How's that fun? Also with online racing, the ghosting system NEEDS to be improved. Ghosting only works if they detect your car about to slam into the other driver from behind, NOT from the side. Because of this, everyone will just stick to the 'Fast and Furious' tactic of driving: shunt your opponent from the side and ram them off course so they crash or miss a checkpoint. Other than the flawed ghosting system, there really is no punishment for unethical behavior. Fourth, the atmosphere of Horizon 5 feels empty. Everyone crowds around the main festival site whereas the other sites feel small or bleak. The large, open world of Mexico is not great, but not terrible. I love the variety of desert, rain forest, the coast; but something just feels off about it, mostly the lack of depth or population that fills these areas. Fifth, and this one is more of a nitpicky one. The customization is bad. Livery editing feels off and the amount of official sponsored liveries is not enough to satisfy my scope of creativity. It's not Need For Speed Heat I can tell you that. The game also feels like it lacks customization options: from the spoiler options to the wheels. Plus the lack of widebody kits also hurts this game's scope of creativeness. Hopefully they'll add more customization options soon. Sixth is another small nitpick. Why did they get rid of Alfa Romeo and Lancia? Plus a few other cars missing from the roster that were in FH4 really makes this game feel like a downgrade rather than an upgrade from the previous game. Again, I can only hope they bring the missing cars back in future updates and add new cars that people are aching to see in the game. Seventh, the wheelspin rewards are uninspiring and outright an insult. There's no easy way to make money since everything is almost made by wheelspin rewards: credits, cars, etc. Getting socks and cringy emotes are certainly the worst. Lastly, the game doesn't have a great progression system. In previous titles, you had to work for the cars. But now everything is handed to you on a silver platter. You don't start with one car, you start with three cars, plus you get free gifted cars at the start, including two supercars. Where's the sense of progression and knowing you worked hard to grind races if everything is given to you? It feels more satisfying to save up those credits or maybe win a ton of credits from wheelspins to buy the car you want. Despite these criticisms, I still do enjoy Forza Horizon 5. I would ultimately give this game a 7/10. Even though I had a lot of cons to point out, it's not to say this game is bad. I just wanted this game to be better than what it is.

review: I'm not far into this game, but I have played the past FH games. Right out of the box you get hit with the pronouns at the avatar creation screen which is very off-putting. Next, because this is MEXICO you instantly get hit with a BLACK British woman which again is very telling that this game is woke. Why is there not a Mexican woman/man to greet me? This is a disgrace. The forced diversity is awful. Thank goodness the player can turn off her voice and not see her too often. Aside from the vomit inducing, woke nonsense, the title runs excellent on my laptop using a 1660ti, i7 w/ 32 gb of ram on High settings. My cars from previous games are transferred over which is nice. All the world icons started to litter the world screen with all the familiar activities. The game is not as fun as Forza Horizon 3 which is a perfect arcade racing game. I encourage anyone to check out that game before buying this one. The graphics are identical and the gameplay is better on FH3.Don't buy this boring wokefest. Buy Forza Horizon 3 instead.

author: Olat
review: One of the best racing games I've ever had a chance to play.Easily in my top 3, right up there with Burnout 3 and Burnout Paradise.Forza Horizon 5 is a true masterpiece of a racing game that offers players an immersive and thrilling experience. From the stunning world, to the engaging gameplay, and the incredible sound design, this game has it all.The setting of Mexico is breathtaking and truly captures the essence of the country. From the lush tropical forests to the sprawling deserts, each location is meticulously crafted and feels truly alive. The attention to detail is impressive, and the graphics are some of the best in any racing game to date.The gameplay is smooth, fast-paced and offers a wide range of activities to keep players entertained. From high-speed races to intense off-road events, the action is non-stop and always thrilling. The driving mechanics are tight and responsive, and the cars are diverse and offer a great mix of speed, handling and power.One of the standout features of Forza Horizon 5 is the incredible sound design. From the roar of the engines to the crunch of gravel under the tires, the sound effects are spot-on and truly bring the game to life. The soundtrack is also fantastic, with a wide range of music that perfectly sets the mood for each event.However, despite all the fantastic aspects of Forza Horizon 5, there are a few issues that need to be addressed. The AI can be incredibly difficult and almost unbeatable, especially when playing using a wheel controller. The AI doesn't appear to respect the laws of physics and this can cause a lot of frustration for players. This issue can detract from the overall enjoyment of the game and needs to be addressed in future updates.In conclusion, Forza Horizon 5 is a true masterpiece of a racing game that offers players an immersive and thrilling experience. From the breathtaking world, to the engaging gameplay and incredible sound design, this game has it all. While the AI can be a bit of a challenge, it does not detract from the overall fantastic experience that this game provides. Whether you're a fan of racing games or just looking for a great gaming experience, Forza Horizon 5 is a must-play.

author: BloodRush
review: Alright. This is going to be a weird one.I am in love with this game and was in love with Forza Horizon 4 as well. This is one of my favourites and I can spend 10 hours a day easily just enjoying the music and driving around, drifting, racing, doing showcases, etc.The good:- Music. This is the ONLY game that I enjoy while listening to the in game radio. It is beautiful, the radio feels live, changes according to your progress and the song collection is one of the best. I even ended up saving the Spotify playlist. The audio transitioning is amazing, one of the best I have seen.- It knows how to create the perfect environment, the perfect vibe for you to enjoy it. This is one of those games in which you will spend hours just roaming around, vibing with the music. The game feels like a party all the time.- Unlike all the other games where you "start from the bottom" and achieve something, here you don't. You already are a superstar, the main attraction of the event and the one everybody cheers for.- It doesn't need any grind for you to unlock stuff, you get plenty very easily, even for multiplayer. Oh and the multiplayer, there is so much to do there. You can go co-op or play PvP and I have tried both, if you got friends it is hella fun.Now the bad part. The game is HORRIBLE for PC users. As good of a game Forza Horizon 4 was in this department, this doesn't even come close. - Random FPS drops to single digit are pretty common.- Any time the podium shows up, there will be stutters during the car showcase, every single time.- The game always freezes after a couple of hours of playtime and has to be force closed.- If you are able to play for a long duration or just stay in the menu AFK for a few hours and come back, the game will start to run terribly. The FPS will keep fluctuating between 25-60 every few seconds until you restart the game.I have a decent build and able to run most of the games maxed out on 1080p and still reach 80+ FPS. Even Battlefield 2042 gave me less issues regarding FPS and I was able to enjoy that, but this just seems such a bad one. I never buy games for the full price, especially AAA titles that aren't solely multiplayer and wait for a couple of years.I still highly recommend it though, so much worth the full price. I can easily see myself putting in a few hundred hours before the next one comes out.

author: ASS SNIFFA
review: I want to start with if this is your first horizon game, this is a great game and i would give it a good review, however I will be writing this review based on returning players.I have always been a big fan of the horizon games, pouring over several hundred hours on fh3 fh4 and fh5. The game is a great arcade racer, nothing can compare to this franchise. However the transition from fh4 to fh5 has become stale very quickly. Most cars are just copied and pasted over and it feels like there is a genuine lack of content. I preordered this game with the dlc's and now I have very little hope that something good will come out of it. If you are a seasoned horizon player looking to buy the latest installment to the franchise, i would highly recommend waiting for a sale or until they provide more content. Overall i would give this game a 6 or 7 out of 10.Update: A lot of people seem to like the hotwheels dlc while i do also hear that a lot of people dont, I personally had played several hours into the new dlc and have quickly gotten bored of it. Already have experienced in FH3 and reusing the dlc seems very lazy. Was really hoping for a new map that would add more "race track" areas instead of the lackluster one we get at the horizon festival back in mexico, or some more mountain passes or larger cities that have more enjoyable routes rather than the long open stretches of road that get repetitive quickly. Still also awaiting current generation cars to come like the gr86, yaris, g80 m3, i20/i30/elantra n, and the nissan z. Even if they brought back more older gen cars like they did with the celica that would be great.

author: Lil Crusty Dick
review: Really want to like this and continue to put more hours into it, but simply can't bring myself to do it. Its too casual :/To be fair, the sole driving and racing experience is done very well for what this game is trying to do. FH5 really nails the arcade racer experience while being grounded with simulation racing elements sprinkled here and there. That balance is what makes this a real joy to play, not to mention the further expansion of the off-road /  rally gameplay. Its like the game tries to tap into a bunch of good elements from other racing titles, but doesn't ever dive too far into any one thing to please a hardcore fan. For a casual racing experience its worth the money. I'd imagine my 14 year-old self would play the crap out of this.However, if you look past the flashy stylized triple-A package that this game brings forth, there's not a lot of depth. Like I mentioned before, this game is not for a hardcore racing fan. When playing, I get the sense the developers were like, "How can we get the most people to play this game, even if its just for 20 hours". Which sucks, because if it did double down and flesh out the various mechanics instead of the surface level "appeal to the casual player", then this would be one of the greatest racing games ever really.Then again, I can't really be mad at the game for doing this because that is exactly what the Horizon franchise sets out to be. Getting the casual gamer to come out and enjoy a racing game.I guess I'll just what for the upcoming Forza Motorsport title to be truly satisfied.P.S. - The fact there's not a ranked competitive multiplayer is a damn shame. That's ultimately why I stopped playing. I get why they would get rid of it from the previous entry, but seriously? Like that's such a good way to get replay-ability out of a game but they tossed it. Coulda squeezed a few more hours out of me but I guess not.

SERVERS ARE REALLY, I MEAN REALLY, ASS.So cringy you'll want to run through the entire Singleplayer with Spotify running on the side to avoid all the brain damage from the dialogues.If you can look past all that, game is fun to play. Having friends to play with is even better. 8/10

author: Vor
review: The physics and graphics are an upgrade from FH4, but the actual gameplay is a huge downgrade. The server issues are the same as FH4, but if you can't connect to a server, the NPC's kamakazi you from every direction in free roam. I spent 10 minutes just trying to make it through a speed trap and couldn't get through without being smashed by several cars. In races, the AI actively try to ram you off the road and don't follow the laws of physics whatsoever.

author: Geronimo Crushwasher
review: Being a long time fan of the Horizon series as a whole it's truly sad to see what this game has come to. I'm not necessarily saying that this game is worse than its predecessors, however there are many key elements that they had (ranked online racing) that are no longer present in this game. I think the biggest underlying problem with Forza Horizon 5 is that it is not at all a new title. Apart from a new map there is little to nothing to differentiate this game from the one that came before it; pretty much everything in it has been done some way before in a previous title. There's nothing wrong with sticking to a similar formula, that formula has created an incredibly successful franchise, however there is a problem with releasing a brand new Forza Horizon title with no new innovations or intent to innovate.I noticed this pretty early on when the game launched a few months ago, however ultimately ignored this giving playground the benefit of the doubt and to let the game get settled for a bit before major content updates. About a week ago I chose to return to the game to see what has changed, and to my surprise little to nothing was different. Many of the bugs that were present at launch still exist, not so much of the game breaking ones, but little errors in the textures of embarrassingly outdated car models are still plentiful. A couple story missions have been added which both myself and I believe the vast majority of the player base do not care for; there is nothing interesting in the re-hashing of boring and cheesy story missions like the last game with a cast of characters I cant even try to care about. Ultimately I could over look the previously mentioned things on top of the lack of new content, they weren't what compelled me to write this review. It was the "new content" that was being added that really gave me a feeling of Playground just phoning in the launch of their most recent title.Even when there was little to nothing to do in Horizon 4 I would still come back for the new and exiting cars added weekly in the festival playlist. This is also what I was planning on doing for this game, until realizing that at least 95% of the "new" cars being added for the entire month are recycled from Horizon 4's previous car list. For me, that alone just made one of the only reasons to actually get on and play this game pointless. If Playground wanted these cars in the game, then why weren't they present in the roster at launch? This re-releasing of old cars is just a way to artificially inflate the lifespan of this game without adding any actual new content. The same thing is true for the non-car addition in this update, the drift club, which is again a re-hashing of what already has been done in Horizon 4. It's things like this that really make me question why I should even bother to play this game, there are no worthwhile rewards to chase and everything skill based has been numbed to the point of nonexistence in the pursuit of broad appeal. Its sad to see a franchise that once pushed to boundaries of what we thought was possible for a Forza title to go down this road of mediocrity and lack of effort. If you don't give me a reason to invest time into a game then why should I? At many points in the lifespan of Horizon 4 I found myself getting bored with the state of the game and going back to play horizon 2 and Motorsport 4, which are two games I always have fun with despite having played over time and time again. With the release of this new game I hoped that the flaws of the previous game would have been dealt with, and we would have the best horizon title to date. Instead it looks like all we got was what should have been a dlc for horizon 4 with what little new it brought to the table. Unfortunately I think this is due to the fact that this game has little to no competition for its place in the market between NFS and The Crew 2; Playground have just gotten lazy with their cash cow. At this point all I hope for is that Test Drive Unlimited Solar Crown is amazing, so that Playground will have to get off its ass and innovate again so stay relevant, as well as to have an actual worthwhile modern racing game in this segment to play.

author: TunZ04
review: I initially thought this game would be boring as I don't usually like racing games. However I was pleasantly surprised by the enjoyment this game brought me. Despite having to sign in with xbox account this game has truly given me a worthwhile experience.I have dislike all racing games I've played in the past but this game is special. It allows you to chill out and play and immerse yourself in the vast open world.While at first I was reluctant to purchase the game, my friends peer pressured me to buy it. After some months I did and wow, this game has been great from the start. I have developed a keen interest in cars as a whole from this game and it's many customisation possibilities has taught me a little engineering.I cannot wait to see what the game has to further offer me beyond my current time playing.In terms of system requirements. I have a pc with a 3090 and 5950X as well as a laptop with a 1650 and i5-9300H. The game runs at a solid 60fps at 1080p on my laptop with medium settings and 120+ maxed out on my pc. It is well optimised for sure, however the menu lags by an eighth of a second on my laptop.Playing online requires Microsoft Xbox app which sucks and I often cannot even join convoys, which sucks.Overall, I recommend this game for those who want to cruise around without worrying about not being good at driving games.

author: Valanar
review: This is a really bad game, the opponent AI cars rubber band back for no good reason. It is literally the exact same game as Forza 4, just a different area. The reality of this game is pretty much non-existent. Force feedback is mediocre at best. You can't chat with people. The maps have clunky UI elements (page down to filter, backspace to filter, what the...?), the game has a habit of crashing so much that you come to expect it at some point. Especially frustrating during a 3-race competition and you're in the last race. Tuning cars makes absolutely no sense. And since I own or owned a few of them, I know for a fact that some cars in reality are extremely different from the ingame version. Sometimes far worse, not better.

author: HP OfficeJet Pro 9015 All-in-One
review: The changes they made to the wheelspin system make being a new player a frustrating grind. Gone are the "endless dopamine surprises" as one reviewer said; now it's "surprise â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ here's 2000 credits for the tenth time in a row". If the wheelspins didn't exist it would be fine, and if they were balanced in the player's favor it would be fine, but the combination adds a layer of rng tedium over what should be a relaxing experience.Update: the game is still a piece of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥I'm gonna keep playing it, and it is a fun game, but that decision was so shortsighted (on a primarily singleplayer game too!) that if I had any integrity I'd uninstall it on principle.

author: Sid
review: I LOOOVEEE paying for cars that should've been included in the game, but were removed and added in these â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ "PACKS" for extra cost just so these â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ car nerds could charge us for unnecessary â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. Other than that it's basically any other horizon game with semi-realistic driving physics and filled with cheaters who min-max their cars to get on the leaderboards. Also they removed the Ranked system which was the main driving factor for the longevity of FH4 and the main reason that i kept playing the game.Would recommend if you're like cars but cant buy one because you're too broke7.8/10 (Add back ranked you sweaty car nut devs)

author: Off To Warm Up The Jag
review: FH5 is both amazing and right on the mark, as well as an outstanding swing and a miss for me. What i mean by this is the game play and map are amazing, the visuals are Great and the overall fun factor and amount of content for the game is outstanding. With this being said the Musical choices, Understanding of Car Culture and certain aspects of the open world miss the mark entirely. The positives outweigh the negatives here by a large margin however the negatives are annoying enough to be spoken about first and foremostCON; #1 the soundtrack;though music is subjective i feel that the entire soundtrack in this game is literally the worst licensed soundtrack in a game possibly ever. its full of generic bass, screatcing, "Goingingingnging" and other obnoxious music made up entirely of compilations of sounds that should not be used to make the music of a car game. Gone are the days of the GOD teir soundtracks of old midnight clubs and Need For Speeds. and even worse it has no way to turn off all in game music :( CON; #2 Car People;I cant talk for the games accuracy with the Mexican Culture but i can for the car culture.... WRONG.... I would count myself as an intermediate car enthusiast, i work on my own car a bit, ive been to lots of car meets and one or two track days and this game does not at all in the slightest get any of the street racing or legal racing or enthusiast culture or lingo even close to correct. THIS IS FINE how ever in their attempts to reflect real car culture it comes across cringe. CON; #3 - The big oneFORZATHON LIVE NEEDS TO BE DELETED. it pops up infront of you out of nowhere and takes you out of gameplay and you cant opt out. it pops up literally on the most popular roads on the map and you cannot avoid it so you have to do different events. it pops up everywhere and if your car so much as skimms the bubble of it the game forces you to participate in the event and it is the worst aspect of this game by far. there is also other issues with the monthly events such as championships not allowing you to compete in single races that month if those are championship racesIf you can deal with the above issues i would highly recommend this game as it is one of the best arcade driving experiences youll have; Even at 99.95NZD this is an absolute must have even though itll make you deaf, cringe and pull your hair out.

author: Jacques
review: Excellent game for someone who wants a fun and somewhat realistic experience. My only gripe regarding the game is that the multiplayer almost never works between friends but online still works fine with randoms. All things considered its still a great game and worth the money.

A brilliant game and I get why critics are giving 9/10s, but this is possibly the most invasive game I have ever played. Constant pop ups about stuff I don't care about. A broken A.I system and Online infrastructure that can't keep up with Halo 2 from 2004. Also why the hell is there digital rarity?? AE86's ARE GOING FOR 10,000,000 CREDITS in the auction house, and the absolute fact that I have to wait x amount of days just to unlock a certain car I really want to use is completely unfair for someone who can't play 24/7. Don't hate the game, just expect better after 10 years and 5 iterations of the same game.

author: ShowdownRowin
review: Switched from Ps4 to PC gaming last month. This game is my first triple A on PC and it has been amazing. The graphics are stunning if you have a capable PC, even on medium and high. And Mexico is a beautiful location for the game. The physics are decent for an arcade racer and realistic enough for sim racers to have some fun as well. I use a PS4 controller to play the game. Luckily Steam supports this, however do note that the game itself will only recognize Xbox controller inputs, so you many see some differences. Luckily, the location of the buttons is the only thing that matters and you can memorize it in less than a hour. There seems to be enough replayability and the end game seems to be immense. I am only a few hours in and there are so many races to complete, i can keep driving for ages. TDU Solar Crown may have a harsh come up end of year of FH5 keeps active and the developers show up consistenly with decent car packs and potential DLC content. Good luck drivers and enjoy!

author: josh
review: It's beautiful, relaxing, and fun to drive around, but beyond that, what's the point? Progression in this game is essentially non-existent... I've only played 7 hours and I have a 999X car and have placed first in every single race I've done. I know I can turn up the difficulty, but that just seems artificial... There's zero excitement associated with winning (Maybe because of the rewind component? I'm a fan of the concept, but it just makes the game too easy). Also agree on the "Notification Overload" point. There are like 75 different menus with 1000 different sub-menus, and it's not really clear what any of them do and/or if any of them are important. I'm not sure what I expected, but I used to love racing games. The whole open-world concept is cool, but it feels like they just dropped the ball on the progression component. Maybe I'm too old for these sorts of games.

review: f you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

author: Mister Snizz
review: Forza Horizon 4 and 5 are two of the most addicting, entertaining, and 'easy to pick up and play' games I've ever experienced. Apart from staggering through Gran Turismo and the like when I was 12 (because they were the only non-linear games that you could easily return to, even if you sucked at playing them and could never advance) I had barely ever played a racing game, and wasn't a racing fan before I came across Forza Horizon 4. It's gorgeous combination of 'easy to learn-hard to master' racing, beautiful visuals, well-realised fictional UK, entertaining activities, week-long 'seasons' in which the entire game world changes climate, and outstanding roster of fully-customisable cars kept me going for 100 straight hours over a period of about 2 weeks (a good effort for someone with ADHD). Forza Horizon 5 bit me the same way, and some small but impactful quality of life improvements to the online matchmaking and Forzathon group events meant that the entire game from beginning to end is incredible fun that is as difficult or accessible as you want it to be. FH5, however, does also feel like a meaningful step back in certain ways. Mexico is beautiful, but unlike the UK's starkly unique seasons of weather, 'hot', 'wet', 'storm', and 'dry' season have little meaningful differences. Entire races would change in their requirements of the driver in the UK's rainy spring and snowy winter, but in FH5 the differences amount to little more than 'there's occasionally some water where there wasn't before'. I spent the entire storm season chasing storms that would disappear before I could reach them just trying to see what they were like. In short, the gameworld barely changes. There's a distinct roughness in the visuals that FH4 lacks - pixelation, particularly of the foliage that is everywhere - is noticeable in a way that it wasn't in the older game. Bugs are pretty rife, from the game-breaking to the annoying lack of attention to detail, and while I didn't encounter anything that closed my progress down for good, it does leave the game feeling unpolished in a way its predecessor isn't. It's 4 months since release and no update is in sight. Lastly, and most importantly for me - the soundtrack is just...not good when compared to FH4. This is entirely subjective of course, but there are some bangers on the FH4 soundtrack that have made my permanent playlist: excellent songs whose pulsing rhythms and great, catchy melodies complimented the momentum of the game's systems and kept you feeling like your heart was pumping to the beat. I can point to maybe 1 or 2 songs out of the dozens in FH5 that spark any emotion in me, and so many are tedious, repetitive, annoying, lack a hook that makes them memorable, or simply just don't *drive* like so many in the previous games' soundtrack did. Egregiously, many of the tracks are simply less-interesting deep cuts from the same artists who contributed to the previous game. It feels like a soundtrack full of cheap b-sides. So I spend most of my time driving with the soundtrack off and a podcast on my phone. It's not the same. I find the game surprisingly hampered by the lack of quality in the music. All in all, yeah, it's a good game. The cars drive better, sound better, and the activities have been tweaked in functionality to be more fun and less time-wasting. But I don't prefer it to FH4, as it feels like it's a mildly inferior copy of its predecessor. It's not a generational step-forward - it's a replication of what worked with some minor positive tweaks, but its soul is missing. FH4 is more expensive than FH5 now though, despite being 3 years older, because the game is technically a 'live service', so the company is likely trying to incentivise people to move towards the new one because that's the way this sh*t works. You'll get your money's worth either way, but I'd recommend getting either of them on sale if you can.

author: GeeBee
review: I tried guys, I tried to adapt, I tried to Improvise, I tried to overcome but this has gotten to the point of not being able to ignore. I failed to fully enjoy this game to its potential.Yes its beautiful. The cars handle unique and believable and there is so much to do.So why the downvote?The presentation... maybe I'm just a boring adult who does not go with the new generation, but damn, it frustrates me so much that everything has to be so overhyped. Tucked away in TikTok dances, confetti, Fortnite style color coded cars you get by spinning reels wtf the whole game is designed for obvious maximum dopamine overdose. And it does not work for me. even after turning off all the constant messaging the likes of; AWESOME YOU AVOIDED CRASHING +100 into AWESOME YOU CRASHED +100 into AWESOME your back end slid into a cactus SMACKTUS! +100. Even with that turned off it just feels so wasted driving a gorgeous looking and sounding car with very believable handling only to finish with a plethora of fireworks in the end, DJ's playing the most mainstream soundtrack in front of the full LGBT crowd (no hate) and race drivers dancing in TikTok fashion and afterwards being phonecalled by some over caffeinated mexicanguy challenging me for some cliffjumping. Another example I get a japanese iconic oldtimer, but the game decided for me its a green common car. Cant you just leave the color coding alone, just get the specs out there and make people decide what its worth. With that common car I win some race which makes me spin 3 WHEELS AT THE SAME TIME congratulating me with a golden legendary or epic car which i just dont give a SH** about.If you've read this far and are willing to tolerate this kind of presentation here's some more in depth analysis.The map is gorgeous south american styled with amazonian humid jungle biome, dry desert biome, mountain biome with plenty of shortcutting (offroad) roads besides the main roads. There are some small villages you drive through within seconds and one place that has the size of a small town. The cars sound great and the sound scales with the amount of tuning you do. They all handle unique based on their power to weight ratio and drivetrain placement and overall build. Very believable the reason this game is not considered a sim is not because the cars aren't believable but more because road surfaces give you a very predictive feedback. Surfaces are predictable and generally feel the same. Normally missing a turn slightly with one wheel in the grass should drag you into the green hell but here it's very forgivable. Matter of fact grass grip feels like a 2nd rated tar-gravel surface rather than true wet slippery grass but thats okay I believe because it would otherwise be a bit too hardcore. Remembering every nook and cranny of the nurburgring is hard enough already for professional racedrivers so a complete multi biome region with hundreds of miles of roads would be a bit too hardcore (I wouldnt mind though).A great driving game should at its core have believable handling, many car options and a varied track selection. In this case an open world. It ticks off all these boxes but some form of progression should definitely be included as well. Progression here is basically a gotta catch em all mentality with the aforementioned presentation. I would have been fine with a linear start from the bottom now we Ferrari mentality. Coupled with some money grinding but now it's basically here's 2 Lambos a Corvette and a pair of pink socks when you haven't even properly introduced yourself yet.Cheers.GameBos

author: Suspect
review: I'm glad this game was gifted to me otherwise I would have refunded my money when it refused to launch on Microsoft's most expensive operating system, has to be the junk Win10 / 11 or no go.  THE ONLY GAME out of 250 games I have that forced me to redesign my rig to run a dual boot os just in order to play.  The game itself is just OK.  The unique old rare cars are nice, what you can do with them is nice, racing your friends ghost is nice, the rest not good.  The Auction would be nice if you bids were actually reliable, I get bid not accepted over and over again, then lose the auction because the bid wasn't accepted.  The racing, difficulty settings vs AI is terrible.  If you win too often, game asked you if you want to increase the difficulty, so I do.  All the difficulty for the AI seems too do is make the AI cars faster, and makes them slam into you, pushing you out of bounds of the checkpoints.  If you look behind you after you pass all the AI cars, they just line up single file behind you about a second back, and if you make a mistake, they fly by like a train in a row.  If you miss a checkpoint and the game resets you in 5 seconds, 1/2 the train of AI cars pass you while the other half slam into you when your ghost time expires.  I can live with all that, and I have for 93 hrs so far only because some of the game is rather enjoyable.  THE WORST part about the game is when you are trying to push a car to its limits racing a friends ghost time is the game has Festivals with blaring loud music that never shut up.  The festival music over powers everything else, its stupid annoying, distracting, you can't hear your car, you can't hear tires being stressed, its just horrid.  There is races that pass by what seems like 10-15+ different festivals blaring...  that pretty much ruins the very little good about this game that there is.

review: Overall good game, a huge improvement compared to FH4. Cars sound like. CARS.Graphics are way better, driving physics feel much better, the game is a little more HDD friendly than fh4 from what I saw from my friends (since I have the game on nvme)I do also have my complaints about the game, and oh boy there we go.- Night is way too shortMost of the car community would appreciate a way longer night or simply a slider for the convoy leader to change it for all convoy members. Who thought that was a good idea for the night to be 4 minutes? cmon you can do better.- Rain lasts shorter than my depressionRain is super satisfying to drift in. We all would appreciate having a slider for that or simply maybe a new game mode for only the convoy members when we can change the environment.- Photo mode lacks options:~ Option to change time~ Weather ~ Disable driver while driving- Game treats stock engines underpowered as heck.- There's a huge bias between carsEdit:nerfing wheelspins is going to cause new players to lose interest and since most of the player base is kids this will result in the game slowly losing players since kids have a short attention span.Maybe try focusing on the cheaters. Plus the recent update brings a lot of cheaters to the game again.. Online racing is useless at this point.And let's be honest, car pass is a joke and it just shows how greedy the devs areThis is going to be EA 2.0

author: InMind02
review: --PROLOGUE--I Started the franchise with Horizon 3 back in 2017. I had to choose 3 since I didn't (and still don't) actually own a Xbox. I saw it as an amazing sandbox racer unfortunately plagued by major instability and same-y type event customization. And to be honest, going into this installment I had expected to find more of the same.I couldn't have been more wrong.--PROS--The representation of Mexico for this game is, to put simply, fantastic. Lush jungles and beautiful coastlines in the south, with rugged forests and mountains up north, Filled in with deserts and plains in the middle, not to mention one of the best urban areas in any Horizon game to date.The base lineup of cars this time around is excellent in terms of both variety and performance, comprising of everyday sedans and classic muscle cars to racing trucks and Warthogs, even full-on Formula Drift cars, with the best hypercars reserved for the wealthiest and best of drivers. Each vehicle you choose can be customized extensively for performance and looks.I'm also glad to see character customization continues to expand in new and unique ways. Do wish more hairstyles and racesuits would be added though (Stig suit when).Online multiplayer no longer requires Xbox Live on the Steam version, meaning all the best Horizon races are available to play free from day one, as well as custom gamemodes such as Survivor, Flag Rush, Eliminator, and more. Online also allows access to thousands of custom blueprints and races, which in some cases completely transform the enviroment into a different place entirely. You can also build your own blueprints and race events as well.There also seems to be very few bugs and no crashes, a vast improvement compared to FH3.--CONS--It is EXPENSIVE to even get into the game, getting to $45 - $50 on sale at BEST, even during the giant Winter Sale, which is when I purchased it.The AI does seem unstable at times, with difficulty increases suddenly finding your majorly upgraded vehicle left behind by miles. I personally recommend starting at Highly Skilled to counter this, only moving up to Expert if you feel comfortable or when prompted.Personally, my only big complaint is that having certain cars locked to online events and challenges does create problems when trying for a complete collection, especially when these events are time limited.I also have concerns that lower end computers may struggle to run this at a decent framerate, but can be remedied by lowering graphics settings appropriately.--SUMMARY--There's simply no other arcade racer out there that competes with the level of detail and control that Forza Horizon 5 provides. With it's extensive personalization and vehicle lineup, not to mention a massive open world rivaling those of the best RPGs, this game definitely wins top trumps for pure size and ambition. It's a wonderful achievement that will surely go down as one the best racing games ever created.It might even be there already.
