author: The Fallen
review: Forza Horizon 5 is a good game when playing by yourself, however it becomes a great game when you have a group of friends to play with and you introduce fun ideas for possible freemode challenges and builds. The issue with FH5's solo play is that in the end of the day it is still a Horizon game where once you have done every race and own every car there isn't a great deal of content left. Sure there is the weekly festival events where you will do races and PR stunts to get wheelspins and cars, but in the end it starts to feel repetitive. The real fun in FH5 in my opinion is when it is played with friends, preferably in a voice call, where as a group you can just ignore any 'challenges' set by Playground Games and begin to set your own challenges. In one instance me and a group of 3 others set out to ourselves to use certain car types within a certain performance index while leaving the cars stock and then perform challenges such as a sound test to see who's car sounds the best followed by events such as a hill climb sprint, drag race, top speed test and then finished with a breaking test to see whose car would score highest. There was no prize, only entertainment value for having fun in different cars as a group. In the end I would recommend this game, as for the first 50-100 hours the game can be played solo with a plentiful amount of content to entertain yourself quite fruitfully. However if you wish to play this game for the long term, I would only recommend it to those who have a friendship group that also play.

author: dom
review: I'm divided. Compared to Forza Horizon 4 it does have great additions to the game, the sound improved massively, but some features I'd wish are still missing. (f.ex. duplicated vehicles filter). The map is big, and very well made, but in terms of cars it feels like it's just a copy & paste of the the FH4 car park. New cars are still missing in this game, there are no new BMW models. Alfa Romeo got removed completely! Forza Horizon 5 doesn't feel like it deserves the 5. It feels like a Forza Horizon 4.5 Although I'm quite happy with the game in overall, I can't recommend it right now.There are still so many bugs, even after two months of the release. We haven't seen a patch since 3rd of December and my game crashes at least every hour.

author: Barge
review: An excellent and fun arcade racing game, with a couple of downsides that knock it down one peg.Pros:-Large open world with a ton of variation. Very good attention to detail. The different regions of the map feel distinct and fun to drive through-Beautiful near-photorealistic visuals-The driving feels excellent on an Xbox controller-The sound design of the cars is very authentic and punchy-Generally all-around fun gameplay-An insane amount of cars (over 500)-Tons of ways to fine tune the difficultyCons:-Customisation of cars (mechanical, not cosmetic) feels almost pointless. All the upgrades are ridiculously cheap and have minimal effect on your cars performance. It would be cool if you could mod your cars more than just adding an interior roll cage that you can't see, or wider tires that you can't notice-The AI doesn't play by the same rules as you, and "cheats" in certain ways. For example, if you turn on "tire wear and damage" simulation, during some of the longer races your tires will wear out and you'll be slowed down as you barely keep control of your worn-out tires. The AI, however, will not be slowed at all, and will leave you in their dust with nothing you can do about it. It's hardly a difficulty option if it guarantees that you cannot win any of the longer races. As a result, I'm forced to turn off that option for any of the longer races.-The weekly and seasonal events, their points system, and their challenges are absolutely horribly explained. It took a lot of looking around and figuring out before I learned how any of the weekly or special events worked. That whole interface needs a significant tweak, and generally a bunch of the UI is a bit shoddy due to this being a console game.Overall, however, I do recommend this game. It's a lot of mindless fun to race around the Mexican countryside and streets, and I've been enjoying it so far.

author: Ivan2496
review: Really disappointed with FH5 :(. The map is beautiful and the cars sound better and the progression and story line have been improved but apart from that it's the same game as FH4. They said they updated a few car models but they are the same, even the ones that weren't good (Nissan Skyline R32, Silvia etc..), the handling has been updated, but still doesn't handle great, even for an arcade. They said they improved wheel support but the game is still not that enjoyable on a wheel as it isn't much better. Everything else about this game is just the same as FH4 but on a new map, with a new story. And don't even get me started with online! Most people buy this game to play online with friends in a convoy and race together and cruise together. However, it simply does not work, you invite friends to a convoy and it says they are in your convoy but they never connect to your session. You can do a race together sometimes as it loads you both into a race but then afterwards you won't be able to join each others online session again. This has been going on for over 2 months now and through several updates, nothing has been fixed. The online in this game is an absolute joke and it takes away a huge aspect of what makes this game fun, playing with friends. Overall, very disappointing game and I hope they fix at least the online issues and bugs soon.

author: DiggerDog
review: I like the game mostly because I got it to work well with my very, very old racing wheel. Iâ€™d say the gameâ€™s best quality is: it just works. After itâ€™s set up properly.I would have returned the game for a refund if the wheel or pedals did not work. My Logitech Momo wheel (May 2007) has been in a closet for over a decade (was there a super sale in 2007?) and this is easily the most (only?) fun Iâ€™ve had with it. I donâ€™t recall the exact hold-up back in 2007, except that I got all worried while running a madly vibrating force feedback wheel on a desk with several spinning hard-drives. I meant to get my computer onto a cabinet beside my desk, but never did. I have to do all the following to get my wheel and Horizon 5 to work:Spend about 10 minutes physically clearing stuff away and setting up the wheelClean boot into my Microsoft account associated with my XBox account that is now associated with my Steam accountStart my Logitech profiler software (set to a persistent profile)Plug in a PC (XBox-style)  game controller (controller might be needed for the game to boot at all)Start XBox (MS XBox for PC) automatically signs me into my XBox account (or the game will not boot)Start SteamStart Forza Horizon 5Set aside 10 minutes to remove the wheel and restore my deskApparently, the original release of Horizon 5 was slightly different from the MS Game Store than on Steamâ€™s store, and the MOMO wheel is still listed online as being incompatible with the Steam version of the game. Itâ€™s worked fine for me. If you want more assurance of continuing compatibility, buy directly from MS? (I am not that worried because I recently learned there now exist 3rd party utilities to allow most common racing wheels to mimic game controllersâ€¦but Iâ€™m hoping I never need to find and figure them out.)I havenâ€™t re-checked earlier versions, but in Forza 5 there are many sliders to fine-tune the driving settings; I suspect I could get the wheel to exactly mimic the wheel shown for the internal driverâ€™s view, but I never got around to fine tuning the adjustments that closely, because I rarely use the driverâ€™s view.I just like driving down the roads in Forza. Using the wheel, I can drive quite fast without going off the roadway, although the game is kind of boring if I drive so slowly that Iâ€™m able to confidently stay in my lane. I can slow a bit, drive one-handed, and take a sip from a drink. Canâ€™t do that with a controller. If I set the difficulty to the lowest setting, I can win every race too (unless I wipe out on in the last quarter mileâ€¦and thereâ€™s always the rewind function if one really needs to win all the time.) Mostly I just like to drive around.Horizon 5 is better than Horizon 4 in that thereâ€™s no recurrent winter season that one has to deal with. As well, Horizon 5â€™s graphics are probably better than version 3 or 4â€¦but not thereâ€™s not enough improvement to stand out against my year-old memories of the earlier games.Iâ€™m still nowhere near as good with a wheel as I was with a joystick playing back in 1998-99 with games like Need for Speed III: Hot Pursuit and Need For Speed: High Stakes. But I think that eventually Iâ€™ll get there.Last year, I got pissed off while trying to play Tom Clancyâ€™s Ghost Recon Wildlands. Driving the  Wildlands vehicles or controlling the drones with the WASD keys was very frustrating so I decided to learn how to use a controller by practicing Forza Horizon 3 and 4. I put in about 40 hours and never learned to use the controller very well. I could sort of get thereâ€¦win some races. But the controller never felt relaxed and natural. This year, when I tried the controller again, I was always very tense. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll ever put in the hours to become comfortable with controllers.New racing wheels are over-priced right now. And any wheelâ€™s setup, at least temporarily, takes over a desk. This driving game is fun, but itâ€™s a pain to set up.

author: Alex Ong
review: Forza killed it again with FH5. Absolutely loving it.Pros+ Great graphics even though I play at low settings+ Diverse gameplay (a bit of everything for everyone like offroad or track & etc.)+ Great selection of cars+ Lots of things to do + Lots of story chaptersCons- My 1650ti struggles after 2~3hrs + of playing :):( hopefully better optimization- AI can be a pain sometimes - Customization is definitely a step-up compared to previous Forza titles. However, if NFS customization level can be achieved, Forza will beat its competition by a far margin.- Price. Yes it's a new game but it's costly for my broke wallet. I suggest buying it during steam sales.Overall, 9/10. SOLID game. I have 0 regrets buying FH5.

Due to the amount of time I have wasted with installing/uninstalling of software and programs for fault finding to prove that the issues are caused by this game.I am not sure when the next update is coming, I do hope that this is tested properly before just rolling this out.

author: ThiccDaddyLOAF
review: I never understood why people liked Forza.It's like need for speed, but less fun. This game appeals to the mainstream and to car fanatics. I claim to be neither.The day it came out, I bought it because I said I'd buy a Forza game when the next one comes out. I played the intro, and the game looks great. Stunning. Took a couple screenshots, albeit in the definite obvious screenshot sections of the intro level. Then I put the game down and didn't touch it for a month.Normally for these good-looking-but-I-don't-see-the-point games, I use them as a benchmark. That's the reason I picked it up again; I was testing steam's remote streaming by driving around in free roam. The game controls very well, but the missions that the game forces you into aren't fun. Horizon arcade is terrible, that multiplayer crab game esque minigames are an interesting concept, but are a chore to do in actuality, and the story missions range from fun races to terrible objective checklists. I only found the value the game held by doing boring standard races.My friends always said that need for speed was the terrible game because it had arcadey driving mechanics. That implies that this game has the more realistic driving. So instead of playing it like an arcadey racer (Need for speed's bonus missions were probably the best missions in the whole game. They made taking down cars fun, and that's something this game doesn't have) I just started playing it as a racing simulator. Boring standard races are boring, but there's nothing like the spice of challenge to make a boring game fun. Turing up the difficulty makes you stay competitive (against bots, yeah, but need for speed is mostly against bots too) and turns on that speed running part of my brain.This game does have realistic driving, even more than asseto corsa. The cars will drift realistically, even at the speeds they would do in real life. Rear wheel drive cars will spin out easier. Drifting isn't always the best option because you lose force through traction, but you can do the crazy strats that asseto corsa lets you do, like turning your car completely sideways to slow down on a big turn. You can also drift to make the back of your car stick out so it hits a checkpoint. With street racing cars, they can't accelerate on the ground as fast, so you start to make strats like staying on the road for longer to build up speed. If one side of your car is on road and the other is on dirt, it'll make your car turn due to the difference in traction. It's basically like dirt rally but if it was an open world game and had less restrictive maps, and less of a rally sim.To play this game, you have to fundamentally change how you think. In need for speed, if you had a good enough car, you can take wicked turns at just about any speed you wanted, provided you were skilled enough to take them. In garfield kart, if you hit a wall with a boost, it could even be beneficial. In this game, they put penalties on these things. If you hit a wall, it'll slow you down, or even stop you dead. If you hit obstacles like poles and trees, you can break them, but they will slow you down. There are some turns that you just can't take at 100mph, or even 60, and that is what required me to change my thinking. What let me win in garfield kart was my primative "press gas go fast" thinking, which worked a lot better than other strategies people had. I never understood why people would brake when they could just drift. In this game, there is certain turns where it's just plain better to to a standard boring brake before a turn. Tough you can avoid going too fast for the turn by putting your car into a sideways drift like I mentioned before, it doesn't slow you down as fast as the breaks, and when you come out of it you need to regain traction for a second before you can accelerate again.Forza isn't a battle royale Dominic Toretto one direction fan fic simulator, it's a standard racing game with racing sim controls and real life cars. It's just fun, and by trying to do more than that, it distracts from the solid core gameplay it has.7/10 Free roam multiplayer is broken

author: Brick n Wall
review: Just a gorgeous game. The overall experience is a great one with significant graphical and sound improvements over the previous installment. I'm frankly not sure if those that can't see the differences between FH4 and FH5 are just on older hardware and can't crank up the settings, or if there are some emotional blinders at work, but the textures, lighting and shadows are all significantly improved.The cars handle more toward the arcade than sim, but there are still some decent physics at work..... for players that is. More on the AI under cons.Tuning options are comprehensive for an arcade racer, with engine tunes changing the pitch and tones coming from your engine, You can even preview the engine notes from your garage. You'll have to keep an eye on your performance index as you tune for pvp and for certain challenges, but otherwise the AI will scale to your performance index.... sort of. More on this under cons.The livery customization is very fun. I have spent over a hundred hours playing with shapes to create my own liveries and share them with other racers and this is one of the best features of the game in my opinion. It's a great change of pace to go from competitive race mode to chill creative mode within the same game. It really makes this a game that can suit any mood for me.Now that I have showered this thing with praise, let me touch upon the warts that blemish an otherwise very good experience.1. The AI. It's completely immune to track physics to an immersion breaking degree. You can be racing in an off road event in an 1800 lb. vehicle designed for it and get blown past by an AI driver seemingly moving on rails through a hairpin in a 4000 lb. touring car while you slide like you are driving on actual dirt. This makes for some highly unpredictable difficulty levels in races dependent upon how much the in game physics model is going to effect YOU. It will NEVER affect the AI, so the greater the impact on your car, the higher the difficulty. This has NOTHING to do with selected difficulty level. That becomes almost irrelevant at expert difficulty and beyond. The AI also drives in ways that would get any player banned from any racing sim server. This is very bad because it teaches new players to drive in ways that are not acceptable in multiplayer matches, and in fact in ways that would be ban-able. This should be fixed.2. The match making in single player is laughable, with similar Performance Index scores producing wildly different results, and matches freely formed between different drive-trains and weight classes. Matchmaking would result in a much more consistent challenge level if FWD always raced against FWD and cars were matched to within 100 lbs. Aside from "open" class events I feel this is an area that could stand to be improved.  3. The Arcade blimp.... for the love of all that is pure and good, please, please, PLEASE allow me to turn it off. There are few things more annoying that getting auto enlisted in an event I don't want to take part in just because my last event dumped me parked under that infernal blimp.4. Hackers are killing the fun of the global records boards. Don't take me the wrong way. I am no Mario Andretti. I have no illusions as to being some elite sweaty sim racer. I don't own a wheel or foot pedals. Just a standard Xbox controller and the patience to compete in an event until I nail it at least once. But I still wonder when i complete a jump I am particularly happy with, how that might compare to the best out there. When I see my jump of 1200 ft and think "yeah that went well" and then look at the leader board and see distances of 30,000 ft.... yeah that kills the experience. I would love to see Playground Games find a way to curb this sort of thing as it is rampant.So aside from those blemishes, this game completely rocks. It's a blast, and you should come join the fun if you haven't already.

author: Tootsie
review: I haven't played a game involving cars since the GameCube. This game has re-awakened all those memories, has a wonderful learning curve, and I definitely respect a game about driving cars where it's not just racing. There's so much to do in so many different ways, even if you just want to relax and enjoy the car you're driving in. Also, tuning and upgrading a 1965 Mini into a tiny, 200+ MPH speeding beast is absolutely amazing and honestly is what won my heart about this game the most.

author: WattsPerKilo
review: Definitely a type of game that was missing from my library and I'm happy I purchased it. If you are not great at driving simulators, but just want to tinker with cars, discover a massive and beautiful map and race against AI's that are around your level (Although the AI's can be really weird at times in their race craft), this is the game for you. I originally bought this game to do races with my friend, but quickly realized, the fun thing about Forza Horizon 5 is just to drive around the map with whatever car you want and just switch off, which makes the replay ability of this game pretty high and is definitely worth the full price. Just keep in mind, this is an arcade game, and the racing should be considered serious by any means (even if you are extremely good and need Unbeatable AI's to race against).

author: TheMaster1
review: 10/10 the best car game I have ever played. This game should be game of the year. + Graphics: Looks BEAUTIFUL even on low graphics using a GTX1650 on 5120x1440 at 40-60fps. Very well optimized.+ Scenery is breathtaking. Night/day cycles, wet/dry weather and sand storms, racing on dirt, roads, forests, deserts, beaches, swamps, mountains, cities... + Different types of racing: road racing, dirt racing, drifting, stunts...+ Car Brands: All the official car brands you could ever think of.+ Huge car variety: buggies, supercars, dirt race cars, trucks, old school cars, etc etc.100% buy on full price.

author: TheSunIsFun
review: There used to be a huge issue with the game crashing while I was using a fanatec wheel, but it seems to have stopped crashing so I like this game. It feels great on the wheel, especially the drifting for me. I've been able to make some pretty fun cars that I actively enjoy using. I know a lot of people do not like the current state of the game and that's very fair. The cars people want to see or the customization people want, but if you want a forza game where you have the freedom of an open world and want something that feels great on wheel that isn't something like Assetto then I recommend this game.

Worth all the money.

author: NeonArtist
review: While I have always been a big fan of racing games in general due to my love of cars, I really have not touched a game since Forza Horizon 2/3. I switched to PC a bit ago but just never got a controller for racing game's, that is until now.For some reason the release of Forza Horizon 5 sparked my interest so I got a controller and bought the game. Since buying it I have not gone a full day without playing it at least once. While games like this aren't played for their story, Forza 5 in my opinion did a good job of trying to make the player feel a bit more involved by having your in game character actually talk and interact with others. While its not a focal point of any racing orientated game, I think it should be recognized and appreciated.Now, down to the game itself.... IT IS SO DAMN GOOD!!!First of all, the amount of effort that went into making the game look and sound as good as it does it just remarkable. I am so happy that it was not only nominated for multiple categories in the Game Awards but indeed won best audio design, innovation in accessibility, AND best sports/racing game. In general I feel like at these big award shows racing and sports game's kind of get swept under by bigger releases and story driven games but I am so happy to see them succeed this year! The game runs so smoothly on my PC and while there have been issues with online connectivity and online racing, I have seen nothing but progress since it was addressed to the developers. The wide range of cars, trucks, buggies, SUVs, hatchbacks, and many other models to choose from and customize is endless. Making money also is not a hair pulling ordeal so you are always able to make new cars and get creative. The customization is quite in depth, but I do think there are some things that would be nice if added, and I honestly think that slowly stuff will be added. While it may be added via DLC I do not know but nonetheless it will be cool to see what they do.And finally, the feeling of driving in this game tops any I have experienced before. The added tire smoke, the sounds of the different engines that you can swap, the turbo spools and whistles, they are all done just so well. Normally when I would play Forza game's I would always just max out the power in any car, but with this release I find myself building different cars for different purposes. Some cars I max out and just try to make it as fast as possible, but others I lessen the power and make a fun little cruising car for the beautiful cities located throughout this GIANT map. And of course I cant forget to mention drifting and how amazing that feels on controller. I can only imagine how great it must be with a wheel setup, and like I mentioned before, the added tire smoke is so satisfying when drifting. The possibilities are literally endless and I cant help but always make a new car every time I open the game up.I highly recommend this game to anyone that is either debating it or looking for a open world racing/driving game because Forza Horizon 5 knocks it right out of the park!!

author: Sparks
review: Massive open world, so many cars, so much customisation. Huge variety of races to do. Big upgrade graphically from 4. Lots more detail in the world overall. Super fun with friends and a nice laid back racing game where you find yourself driving around more than anything.

author: logane1102
review: The blueprint builder feature is such a disappointment!I was trying to make my own track, and I saw just how little I had to work with and how annoying it is to use, and I thought, "what were they thinking!?" "How did they not think that people would just want to make their own custom tracks?" "Why are there so few options and objects given to the player?"Clearly the developers didn't make this feature for this purpose, They meant for the player to sprinkle objects within the open world and be creative that way. But damn, they really missed a huge opportunity here. And it's so dumb because this issue could be mostly fixed if they just had more objects to choose from that supported the idea of creating a race track from scratch: more types of ramps, actual flat pieces of tarmac / dirt road / wet tarmac, and more ways of manipulating and morphing the objects, and added the ability to set the starting point and decide if you wanted to make a point-to-point or a multi-lap circuit race. But what's here just isn't cutting it. Frankly, in it's current state, it's pretty freaking lame.What they should have done is made a separate mode that focused on creating tracks, and having custom games where you can invite your friends and race them on your custom track, then race other people on other custom tracks that other people made, basically the forza version of Halo's forge mode, And yes, that is technically possible in some small capacity in this game, And I'm amazed at the stuff people have made in this game already from what I've seen on youtube, and at the fact that anyone even bothers with this feature at all considering how much effort and time and BS it takes just to make a simple track inside the coliseum. The lack of features and overall jankiness in the blueprint builder mode really highlights the developer's lack of understanding of what people would want out of a creative mode like this. To me, thinking that people want a more dedicated mode to just track-building like what I described earlier seems so obvious, and yet, we didn't really get that.We basically got the creative mode from Trials, that motorcycle game, inside of forza. But that level of depth in a creative mode isn't sufficient here because forza's gameplay is in 3D, and the tools we got only allow us to effectively work in 2 dimensions, while leaving the 3rd dimension basically impossible to make good use of. They didn't give the player enough tools to allow for effectively and efficiently creating an interesting play space for cars with any subtle characteristics of verticality from scratch, disconnected from the game's open world, when it relates to creating a track with banked corners, uphill and downhill sections, elevation changes, and subtle bumps in the track, which are key components to creating an interesting race track. Overall, I think the devs seriously missed out on creating an absolutely killer feature that would have blown everything else out of the water, because while yes, beamNG, trackmania and asseto corsa exist, and you can make your own tracks in those games, In my opinion they lack the foundation of a good driving game with a lot of licensed cars that has the best of both worlds: that being fun and refined driving gameplay with your favorite licensed cars, combined with a mode to create your own tracks from scratch, which could provide hours upon hours of fun. Asseto has much less of a problem making this possible in theory, but creating tracks for asseto and beamNG isn't exactly a go-to-creative-mode-and-make-a-new-track-all-without-putting-the-controller-down-type of experience that forza could have possibly nailed with the advantage of having a big list of licensed cars, unlike beamNG and trackmania.Aside from this majorly disappointing feature, there is actually a good bit to like here.Cars seem to have had their audio overhauled, and it's great.Cars shifting gears sounds better in this game than previous entries. Cars shift more like how a real person would shift a car; this subtle audio update makes a bigger difference than you might expect when it comes to moment-to-moment gameplay.Engine sounds are also good.Cars have very detailed interior views as always.Driving physics are good, it's what you would expect from the forza horizon games. Nothing crazy here.World design is also good, apart from the sandstorms which I absolutely hated and wondered why these are in the game at all. They do absolutely nothing to make the game more enjoyable, they just made me think of Need for Speed Most Wanted '05's yellow piss filter x1000. The game has a really good selection of settings to fine tune the game including advanced settings for controllers (Deadzone calibration, custom mappings, etc.), detailed graphics settings, good selection of audio volumes, Field of view sliders, among other things.Performance was pretty good on my PC equipped with a Ryzen 5 3600 and a GTX 1660 super. Over 100 fps almost all of the time on the high preset at 1080p. I did notice stuttering occasionally, but nothing to get upset about though.Now for what was NOT good.1. This game takes WAY too long to get all the way opened up to the point where you can go into the event lab mode where everyone seems to be at in this game. I legit took me about 2 hours just to bee-line it to unlocking the casa bella so I could get into the event lab mode, the whole time being utterly bored because this tutorial section feels so samey to previous entries.2. In typical forza fashion in recent entries, this game has no restraint on just rewarding you cars and throwing large amounts of money at you left and right with no effort put in to get these rewards.I'm not necessarily against this, but it's off-putting to be getting mixed signals where I'm restricted on what modes I can play because I need to progress the 'story', but the game is just giving me super fast cars and lots of money right from the beginning and all the whole way through that 2-hour process of completing the tutorial section.3. I encountered some audio-related issues, one being that even when muting all the audio channels related to voices / talking, I would still hear people talking (and ANNA specifically, which I have always hated in every entry so I wanted to make sure I didn't have hear her annoying ass). This really got on my nerves because I knew from the get-go that this game has obnoxiously G-rated dialogue and I just wanted to avoid as much of that as possible.Another more concerning audio issue I ran into was crackling audio and engine sounds having this up-and-down whooshing effect laid on top of them. The fix is to set your speaker's sample rate to 24 bit, 96,000hz.4. Custom bindings for gamepads seems to be broken. If I try to make a custom mapping profile, the game expects you to bind a button to the "Map" function, but there isn't actually a way to map this function to button that makes sense, or at all, considering that the default mappings don't even map this Map function to the controller in the first place. This is a really dumb thing and needs to be fixed asap.5. This game really doesn't seem any different than the last 3 games, I feel like I'm playing the same game over and over again. The most this game's got going for it is the graphics and sound, and the event lab mode, which, metaphorically, are all tiddies that will inevitably sag in due time. I feel like this game is better at being a tech demo than being a genuine fun game to play.Is this game fun to play? Yes. Was every other forza horizon game fun to play? Yes. Is this game any more fun to play than the previous entries? Yes, but only by a bit. Is this game worth paying sixty dollars to play? I say, not quite.

author: FrostOps07
review: If you don't like racing games, but you love getting to drive cars in other games (GTA and the like), this is the type of game you can lose literal hours in.  With a massive open world map and no need to complete quest objectives to unlock cars, I've found myself just driving around and tuning cars to make them EXACTLY what I want.  Was on the fence if I'd enjoy it and I'm happy to say I find myself coming back and playing it daily because I get to drive around and do silly things like jump cliffs at 200 MPH and not get penalized for it.  This game scratches the itch of going on a long drive without having to spend money on gas to go on one.  Don't want to drive fast because you'd rather do some off-roading or drifting? You can.Don't want to stay on the roads to get to the destination you set on the map? You don't have to.

author: Frost_Maverick
review: Honestly, the best Forza Horizon game. The flaws in this game are apparent at the time of writing this ( Dec. 19, 2021), but we got a very beautiful map, amazing cars and fun racing. We also get a more polished and refined handling system! RWD rally cars are now able to keep up to the FWD and AWD Rally cars if built right! The Power-All-Wheel-Drive-Meta isn't as strong. Finally, CROSS COUNTRY ISN'T AN OBSTACLE COURSE ANYMORE! (F$@! THOSE COBBLESTONE WALLS FROM FH4!!) If you are thinking about getting this game for a fun sim grounded arcade racer, I HIGHLY Recommend this game not just to Car Enthusiasts, but EVERYONE!

author: Asto
review: â€¢ Map design (really good job blending different environments together into a huge map)â€¢ Sound design (the game recycles sounds a lot but the quality is good)â€¢ Graphics quality and optimizationâ€¢ Weather (The views you get when rain or storms are present really boosts the game's visual satisfaction)â€¢ Including Suzuki and Å koda (I know there's agreements, contracts and a lot of money that must be present in order to make a deal, but the game already has the biggest supercompanies and the most expensive manufacturers)â€¢ Radio (arbitrary because of personal taste, but come on why would you include a song like "Teardrops" and censor it so hard to the point it's an instrumental)â€¢ Original soundtrack (feels very exaggerated and stereotypical, specially the opening and Adventures theme)For anyone considering purchasing this game it is better to play it with Xbox's Game Pass Ultimate, because currently it is not worth paying full price, until both expansions are present.

author: iSnagg
review: Alright, heres goes nothin! Thats the feeling this game gives you. You get in and think youre gonna be good immediately, then BAM! You did a PVP race against some dude that goes from 0 to 300mph in the time it takes for the sound of a fart to hit your ears. Personal experience has been amazing, however. This game has way more to offer than i originally thought. Dont want to race all day? Cool, go free-roam and practice your driving stlyle.OH! You wanna collect cars? Go for it! Over time (not that long) the server will send you a notification to go on a treasure hunt for Old Barn Finds, where you have a mechanic thatll repair the old find in to like new.Sure, theres other ways to get vehicles, but who cares about NPC races when you have a huge open world to practice on?OH! You DO care about NPC races and vehicles you unlock from them? Thats perfect then! Every town offers tons of races with new ones popping up daily, from Pre-loaded courses, to player created. The possibilities are near endless. The tuning of vehicles in this game is extraordinary, to say the least. You want your jeep to float like a boat when hitting tight corners? Go for it! You want your VW Bug to have a v10 Diesel, because **** you and your supercar? Go for it! You can fine tune every aspect of your ride to make it feel and react just as you want. You want to make a Shelby drift like a Dom Torreto? Go for it! Oh wait, you dont know how... right.. WELL YOURE IN LUCK! THERES TONS OF YOUTUBE VIDEOS! NOW!!!!... For the bad.... If you wanna drive insanely fast with amazing graphics.. you better hope you have a beefy system and harddrive. Otherwise, just chill, enjoy the tight corners this game has to offer, and just forget about life for awhile. Would i return this game even though i accidentally put 32hours in to it in the last 12 hours? Na... its too good of a game. Esspecially if youre looking for something with 0 stress and a great community.Good Luck, Gamers! Now.... ima go practice drifting and hope i dont slide off a mountain

author: Socrates
review: If you are playing simply for single player or do not care that a company asks people to pay extra to play the game early in essentially a Beta stage without stating its in Beta, then yes its fine.When Microsoft decided to say that you could pay extra to play early, to anyone with a logical mind that means that the game is ready to play with no major issues. On Day 1 of this early play, I could not get into Convoys with my friends to race around the map, nor did Multiplayer want to work properly. When a major part of the game is driving with your friends, this is unacceptable and should not be advertised as a finished product.Microsoft did not state that this was a Beta when it was quite clear that the game was not finished. While I know Microsoft will eventually fix this, it is poor form to continue business practice in this manner.Another two big problems that have yet to be addressed by Microsoft are the fact that the mouse pointer still appears on screen and that Discord overlay does not work.

author: CKojiro
review: I cannot wholeheartedly recommend this game unless you want a purely SINGLE PLAYER experience. Even the single player experience though... can get stale. I went into this game with some friends and the multiplayer is very janky. Random disconnects and having trouble connecting are far more common than uncommon. We aren't even in different countries so it makes no sense. The custom race builder is a good idea but it was executed very poorly. At least add an option to use pre-existing courses and switch the start and finish lines. I haven't even mentioned the worst part which for me was random crashes. I can't even play this game for more than 1 hour at a time because the game randomly crashes. In it's current state, I cannot recommend this game. It needs fixes and updates.

author: omki
review: Horizon is meant to be the fun and playful version of the Forza franchise from what I've been told. I wish I had that experience, racing with friends, exploring the map and collecting hidden cars sounds fun. Problem 1:Staying in a "convoy" or party for more than a single race is near impossible and if you want to mess around with your fiends while waiting for your other friend to accept the convoy invite, then good luck. 50% of the time your convoy is phased and wont be able to see you. Want to see your friends new car? Nope. Want to stay in a party for longer than five minutes? Nope. Want to explore the world by driving as fast as you can in a straight line? Nope.This game has a harder time loading the map than GTA Vice City did in 2002.While the game strives itself on "realism" the playful version of Horizon should be more playful. I get the impression that I'm being punished for wanting to drive unrealistically in this game that started off with dropping million dollar cars out of a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ plane. "Want to make this sharp turn by drifting around the corner? Don't you dare touch that e-brake. Don't you even get that finger near that â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ button. In fact, you were holding down the brake long enough that I think I'll pretend you hit that e-brake and toss your ass into the bushes." And good luck getting back onto the road. As punishment you are going to be doing involuntary donuts of defeat for the next 30 seconds. This seems like the type of game for someone that only owns a steering wheel controller or people that have completely played all of the Xbox gamepass already.

author: glurg
review: Mechanics are ok. AI really breaks any sort of enjoyment you could get from racing. Difficulty discussion aside, the races always follow the exact same pattern even if everyone is using the exact same car.Race starts: All of the AI immediately pass you. Odd since you are all driving the same car.........Middle of the first lap: Exactly 2 of the AI are well ahead of everyone. Its always 2, never more, never less. Middle of the second lap: the AI at the front slow down for you to pass them.That's FH5 AI.

author: Pablo
review: UPDATE JULY 2022:Sadly, i'm turning this review to negative, since it's been 10 months since the game's release, close to a year, and still multiplayer doesn't work for me. I know many people is able to play it online, but after months of trying , nothing working, but mostly, Microsoft support not being able to help telling me "this issue is being worked on" and closing the support ticket has weared me out. I played in the last two years at least half a dozen co op games with friends with no problems, Forza is the only one that is not working for some specific reason which i can not decipher (and i shouldn't) .For many games this wouldn't be that much of an issue, but since Forza has a strong online component which is constantly updating, with several seasons and series across all year, it is very noticeable (even if i'm able to play all offline content)The main game is still good, but after that all that remains is the constant online update which are a constant and periodic reminder of what i can not play.I'm writing this on ocassion on the release of the first expansion which comes 10 months after the game release (and there's still one more to go, who knows when) which in all honestly, at this point since i stopped playing the base game like half a year ago is half new content and half a reminder of all the frustration i had not being able to play any multiplayer co op content.At this point i'm more inclined to go back to Rider's Republic another sports game (on bikes, skying and flying) which, regardless of all the cheap comercial horrific tactics i was STILL able to ALWAYS play online with other players and ENJOY IT and have fun. And this is saying something coming from an ubisoft game...  This is the original review:I've just finished moments ago one of the big final races in the game, and this is as good moment as it will ever be to make a note about it.The race is called "The Colossus"and it's a road racing type of race (classic race, classic roads, inside and outside towns). This was the final road racing track which runs across the entirity of the map, spans 55 kilometers long, goes through most of the game landmarks and it took me, with a super fast car, the mercedes amg one (the cover car) 17 minutes  to finish, without pauses or loading screens, just 17 minutes of non stop racing. This game is probably one of the best racing game experiences i had in recent years. It looks great, it does have many controls and adjustments you can do to your car, but  at the same time it can be just as simple as you want (or something in between) it plays as an arcade racing game, and more importantly it does have several difficulty adjustment settings to make it accesible or as complex as other more serious games. But this game is just fun. It reminds me everytime i play it about going as a kid (many years ago) to the arcades and doing a race or two with friends or alone. You can play this game just like that, doing a 5 minute race and be gone or spend many hours. The game has road racing, closed circuit, dirt racing (off road rally style) cross country racing, and street racing too.  It has even rally cars, 4x4 jeeps, some trucks, lots of old cars. So far 500 cars of many kinds.The multiplayer on the other hand actually doesn't work, at least for me, which sucks, like it's been a month and im still not able to connect to the x box network at all, nor do any online content, but you can play offline and do all single player content.

review: Gameplays feels really well most of the time. However, the biggest feature of any Horizen game is Online. It's an absolutely abhorrent experience. -No way to play what you wanna play, you can just que up for a random event and hope that it actually starts (takes 5-10 minutes, and 50% chance it works). -Server stability is not good, and crashes are frequent (on newer hardware atleast). -Cars are fairly unbalanced, but the issue is not too great as people are still figuring out what is broken and what is not. -Every loadscreen takes ages, prepare to have some entertainment on another screen.

author: LiL10
review: Let me just say, this game is spectacular. Despite other peoples problems in the review section, I haven't had any sort of game ruining moments. Yes, the multiplayer is spotty, but I can live with that. The amount of fun I've had in this game is what makes it the best. Details on the cars, the sense of speed, flying off a cliff with a rally car, building the fastest car in the game is what this game was created for. Yes, there are more realistic simulators out there, but this game doesn't focus too much on making it like that. I think the Mexico map is perfect, with lots of diverse landscapes and picturesque moments. 10/10. Price was a bit high at first, but when you think about it, this game is a steal. The lines in the story mode can be a bit cheesy, but you get over it after a while. Great job Playground Games!

author: andrewandneil
review: Do you like cars? Do you like destruction? Do you like racing people, whether they be friend or stranger? Do you like to win? Do you like the feeling of being the fastest in the land?If your answer was yes to any of these questions I can highly recommend this game to you.The game has insane visuals, I'd personally say a solid 9/10/. The detail put into the cars and map are extraordinary. The map is incredible, ranging from soft white beaches to a literal volcano. The voice acting is very good, not amazing, but then again this is a racing game. My only real complaint is in cut scenes the body and mouth movement is awkward to say the least. But as I've said before, this is a racing game, you're not hear to be immersed in an amazing story and acting, you're hear to drive like there is no tomorrow.The other complaints I have are minor, pausing the game and stopping your car each time you are able to unlock a new festival site, a strange visual glitch on one side of the volcano (might be just me but the terrain flashes from black and white to full colour again), the bugs you'll encounter along the way (though most of them are rather hilarious and have laughed me through some tough races) and the strange difficulty scaling (on higher difficulties the top 2 or 3 cars rubber band away from you making it next to impossible for you to catch up).I implore you to purchase this game if you have the money, and I hope to see you in my next race! Happy racing (or drifting, whatever your style is ;) )

author: GanGuerrilla
review: Sure, the graphics look amazing and there are over 500  cars but what really makes Forza 5 a good game is more 'under the hood'. The controls are responsive and can be punishingly realistic. The delicate balance of accelerating, traction, top speed, your ability to turn or slide mixed with the difference in your two brakes intertwine to create a very responsive and skilled driving experience. The responsive controls become even more pronounced by realistic tuning. Too much Torque, on a car with too little weight and too low traction? It will actually start sliding on straight-a-ways. Like to power slide vs tight turning? Ive tuned and raced cars on and off for 20 years and this game manages to really simulate the experience of driving sports cars, rally, offroad, and street racing better than any title I played before while still incorporating an arcade like feel complete with scoring systems, seasonal games, arcade versions of play and 'wheelspin' giveaways.The games DLCs seem like pay to win. You can read plenty of comments on the DLCs about whether or not customers felt they got their perceived value. The game also has several bugs. Its an Xbox game that constantly wants to talk to its other server and as a result may disconnect you briefly. Its also difficult to find "Clubs" or friends because its all done through an Xbox companion app that launches in a second window.

author: Xyrax
review: It's Forza Horizon. They don't mess with the formula much on these games. If you've played any horizon game, especially 3 or 4 - you kind of know what you're in for on this one.However this rec comes with the following warning: The multiplayer is broken as hell and straight up does not work at the moment. They are working on it but the game has been out for almost a month and it's still a problem. I've played 95% of my time in singleplayer, 4% of it trying to play multiplayer with a friend, and 1% of it actually playing multiplayer.That being said these are great singleplayer games. They're really casual - can get quite difficult if you crank the settings up - good accessibility settings - and an absolute BOATLOAD of things to do in the world. Amazing amounts of cars, races, events, stunts, weekly challenges etc.One of my favourite things about this game too is, during regular singleplayer, you almost never are limited on what kind of car you want to drive. You want to take your Lamborghini on a rally race? Go ahead! So much room for experimentation.Great game. I've never really played multiplayer and I love this series. Looking forward to the DLC!

author: seaVvendZ
review: If you've played FH4, this is pretty much just more of that. Same car list with a few new ones. The map really is huge and amazing. Some of the features brought in the FH4 DLCs were brought into the main game here -  namely the lego stud challenges are renamed here. The game has you pick which types of races you want to unlock first as you progress. When you first unlock a new type you have to do a little scripted exploration mission which honestly so far has been fun. The main character is voiced now if you're into that.If you haven't played Forza Horizon 4 first of I'd say get that one if you can get it for cheap. This game isn't superior enough to warrant spending full price over. Forza Horizon 4 is an excellent game and having been out for some time now it will likely go on sale, before eventually they have to pull it from digital shelves due to licenses expiring similar to previous Forza games. The DLC of FH4 is also worth it - two new maps and all the challenges that come with it, plus you obtain way more cars and credits than you know what to do with. Forza Horizon 5 is all of that plus more, but its not more enough to justify purchasing if the pricing is different (future sales).

author: odindindin
review: Forza Horizon 5 is quite a special experience, despite me coming straight from its predecessor. Its version of Mexico brings so much variety to your, ahem, need for speed. Car controls strike a magnificent balance of arcade and sim (plus you can do impressive degrees of tuning and design), and the car sounds are SUPERB. Terrains ranging from sandy deserts to heavy forests and swamps to volcanic regions. You thought hypercars and classic racers cannot be used for dirt tracks? WRONG. You are allowed to do (almost) anything, while being rewarded for doing (almost) everything. Might be overwhelming for new players who had no experience with its predecessor(s) though. With a game of this scale, do expect troubles with online play. And try not to use offensive liveries. All in all, a massive joy of a game and a definite improvement from Horizon 4. HELL YEAH

author: DirtE99
review: Do not buy, this game is buggy and constantly crashes. When you open a ticket with support they do not read your inquiry and send you a templated email response with 3 other games (Forza 4, 5, Street) and also other platforms (xbox,steam, ms store) with saying they're looking into it and list out all the known issues  and then point you to a twitter support page  which doesn't answer support inquires and has another link  that points you back to support team making it a loop. Best of all they mark the ticket "solved" on you which will auto-close the ticket on you. I will change my review once they address the giant list of bugs: . TL/DR: Save your money and time.Update 12/3/2021 - New version 1.414.967.0Game still crashing, support ignoring the issue with more templated responses.They seem to have added crash reports, sent information off.

author: ExTwoZero
review: So far Horizon 5 has been great.Has the occasional crashing and network issues, but great game. Graphics look good, customisation is getting better; sad to see Rocket Bunny is no longer here, but I am impressed that they did a better job with the force feedback for wheels. It has better support for them as well.If they can solve the crashing and network de-sync issues, I will be fully satisfied with the game. Kinda sucks how at the moment you can see friends for a bit but then they just randomly disappear and the game crashing when plugging in a wheel some times but great game!I for the most part enjoyed it, the crashing pissed me off a bit though...I will say though, the stunning graphics, amazing map location and the wide variety of different vehicles and the sounds of the environment/cars is damn amazing haha.

author: PhilAnders
review: As of now I would  recommend this game.Some of the major bugs have been fixed, but if you want to play Forza just go play 4.Also this was the case in the previous game, but the game devs love unnecessary censorship.The story missions are pretty good and the game visually looks and sounds fantastic.The car selection is vast and still expanding, with infinite customization.If the bugs are fixed and the servers are stabilized, this would definitely be a positive review. But as of 11/29/2021 you're better off buying Forza Horizon 4 on sale for 65% off.EDIT: a week later and the game has been updated with major bugfixes. Dozens of accolades fixed and many issues with online functionality (especially convoys) has been fixed. Still a lot of small issues on their bug list, but have not come across anything game breaking. Devs are putting out major patches every couple weeks, so the amount of bugs will almost certainly decrease over time (maybe probably).The servers for online racing are still very slow, but I have not had any recent problems with disconnecting.Servers are about the same as Forza Horizon 4, except Horizon Life still appears fairly empty.And best of all, Horizon Arcade now scales the point requirement with number of participants, so it is actually possible to win. More variety of minigames compared to Forzathon Live, so it is actually superior now.

author: dbark
review: Exactly how a racing game should be. Forza Horizon 5 is the perfect balance of simulation and arcade that is needed for a racing game to be fun. On one hand you can alter and tune your car all and adjust sliders all day, or you can use your game currency to acquire tune setups created by other users. This allows a casual gamer with no extensive car knowledge to get out and play, and allows the car buffs to do their thing and build their perfect setup. Being able to just pick up and play and not spend all day in the menus is a bonus. Racing simulator games that are heavily focused on track rules and off track duties can be too slow and tedious to be fun.Huge car list, user created liveries and a variety of race modes and events all add to the excitement. Not to mention how beautiful the fictitious rendition of Mexico is. There are a few minor visual bugs, but I have not experienced anything game-breaking at the 60+ hour mark. Get out there and drive!

review: A surprisingly fun experience. It is very relaxing to drive in the world exploring while being intense when having a race.That being said, I'm taking a more neutral stance at the moment (despite the recommendation) because of all the bugs I'm experiencing. Missions sometimes are not registering, controls are being messy from time to time, all these are small things but add up to an annoying level. So buy the game if you are into racing games but be aware that bugs exist, a lot at that.

review: Update: Still wildly unbalanced driver AI at higher difficulties, practically all bugs have been fixed from what I've seen. Biggest complaint outside of the AI is the sheer volume of pushing online content in the weekly playlists when i know that it isn't everyone's cup of tea (specifically mine). This is especially true when the matchmaking still feels just bad. Overall I'd recommend the game even for 10% off but wont remove the dislike until my complaints are fixed.

author: Wh1t3r0s3
review: If you liked FH4, there is no reason why you should skip this one. The map is bigger and more diverse than Britain, the cars are grippier (sucks if you like drifting), and FWD and RWD cars are actually driveable on S2 and above.Unfortunately, AWD is still head and shoulders above the rest, which will probably result in the same meta has the last game, where AWDs are king for anything not involving straight line speed.There is a fair amount of bugs, frequent disconnects and batsh!t insane rubberbanding for AI cars. Hopefully, most of these are fixed sooner rather than later.

author: Yen
review: TL;DR - Don't buy it on Steam full price, buy it from Microsoft, or Xbox, or PS5 instead as it has better error support.The game had a rough start with many bugs and huge connectivity issues, which as time goes it seems that those issues dwindle.  Here and there the road won't render, people will disconnect (like in past games), and the game will fail to boot from access violation errors and conflicting software issues (like Discord and Wallpaper Engine!).  All of this with a 10th-gen i9 CPU and a RTX 3070, among other parts to my rather high spec build that should have little problem with render mismatching at all.This game does not seem very optimized when you play it with higher hardware installed, or as it would seem.  Many RAM dumps and memory leakage, many frame stutters, many times does the ground not render.  It happens a lot one day, and then none another.  It's hard to explain, but it happens.  It makes racing actually infuriating when it does happen, especially at harder difficulties.In terms of gameplay, all of the sounds are 110% better for every car, every engine, and every tire squeal in particular.  The weekly PR stunt challenges are car-restricted like the weekly race championships were in the last game, and that frankly sucks.  All of the cars feel they have a "specific purpose", like for example most retro sports cars feel like they aren't supposed to be tuned for S1 and higher when they clearly can be anyways.  It's hard to explain, but the cars' handling makes it feel like they aren't supposed to surpass some kind of specific driving use.A lot of my friends don't seem to have the same issues that I have with actually running the game, so I think it might just not pair well with high-spec PCs even if that shouldn't be a problem.  Even more friends who play the game all come to the same consensus that I have, being that despite all issues it has it's worth buying and playing.  It has a lot of errors that need permanent fixes, especially with the display drivers and Nvidia tech such as ray tracing.  A couple of times it thought I wasn't signed in and needed to be, preventing me from playing outright for a couple minutes.  Countless times it crashes to desktop because of a Windows 0xc0000005 error that no one on the internet knows the answer to but I recognize it to be a bad install that Steam can't really reverse, so the answer is to reinstall a 100 GB game.  The crashes from in-game render issues that are the result of the game and not one's own hardware wouldn't be so bad if the game didn't take 5 minutes to boot from main menu to actually playing the game.Over all, I'd say get it on sale just in case, but this certainly isn't worth more than $50 with how partially-functional the Steam version is.  Solid 70-75 out of 100 of a game because I still want to play it, but sometimes when playing and when any time there is an update the game just won't let me enjoy it the way I did Forza Horizon 4.

author: JxTechy
review: Okay so this is going to be a fairly long review. I've been a forza player since motorsport 3 and have played every game since then. I played on xbox 360 to xbox one and then made the switch to PC for Forza Horizon 4. Forza Horizon 4 also had its issues at launch but still performed really well and had no graphical issues from what I can remember. However for Forza Horizon 5 that is a different story.Firstly the game and story are great. You can tell the creators know what they are doing with these games now as every time they release they are perfect, story and gameplay wise. But with this forza this PC version as some serious issues. The launch release would crash frequently and would never load the forzathon shop. Another issue was that you will disconnect from the online servers every time you went into a race. But thankfully these issues have been fixed, but this has meant I have been able to find the other issues with the game.FH4 at High settings looked like the Xbox one version of the game near enough, so I expected that high settings for FH5 would be how the game looks on series S at least. However the game looks like a late xbox 360 to early xbox one game at the best at this preset. Customising the high preset by turning features from medium to high and putting up MSAA to x4 does make the game an xbox one to xbox one X game which I'm happy with. But there are massive frame timing issues where the game drops frames for no reason whatsoever, and the game is running between 55-70FPS most of the time, but these drops make the game annoying to play. Even capping the frame rate and/or turning on long motion blur don't help. So I hope this is something the devs can fix.Apart from that its a great game, its just a shame that PC version is not looked at in the same way the xbox version is.Also for anyone wondering I've got a Ryzen 7 3700X and a GTX 1060 6GB with 16GB of RAM, and yes I am running the game off an NVMe

Played with a 6800xt, i can lock to 120fps@1440p with every graphic setting set as high as they go. At best the Consoles can pull 60 fps at reduced quality settings. The Game is Fun as hell, the driving is addictive and i find myself just driving the roats with my Logitech G920 wheel and pedals while sight seeing. The sound track is awesome as well and i find myself humming the songs in the game when driving in real life now.

author: N-V US
review: (Need to preface by saying I'm in no way a car expert, so take this as a casual review. I also haven't played any other Forza game, so this is my first) (Scroll all the way down for the TL;DR)Bought this all the way back in the pre-order stage and anxiously waited for November 9th to roll around. I only really bought Forza Horizon 5 to play with friends, have a virtual garage of my dream cars (as well as collect 1 of every car in the game), and understand cars a little better seeing the dev's strives of reaching a peak equilibrium between realism and illogical fun. This game absolutely slammed it out of the park.--OVERWORLD--The landscape is really pretty objectively speaking. Of course the graphics are nice, but for me personally, I find the overwhelming orange tone really drab. That's of course a personal preference, but even with my disdain of warm color schemes, it still manages to look really nice because there are quite a few grassy/roady areas that make the landscape not feel so warm and sandy. The balance is definitely there. The mountains are also a pretty fun climb, but after a few days of playing, the mountains start to feel underwhelming with what they have to offer. Score: 8/10--EXPLORATION--Gotta say- after exploring all 100% of the map (yes, even the little roads that get overlooked leaving you at 99.7% for a week which drives you nuts trying to find it and then accidentally stumbling into the last .3% and feeling relieved you can unpin that stupid challenge) getting all XP/Fast Travel boards, Houses, Barns and 3-starring all speedzones, speedtraps, trailblazers, drift zones, danger zones, and all festival drivatar races, (haven't completed the story missions yet), I have to say the grind was pretty enjoyable. Score: 9/10--CHALLENGES(FESTIVAL SITES)--The personal drive for overworld festival sites may factor in for you and you wanting to do them, (because there are quite a few and some require patience), seeing as how my personal drive for doing the overworld challenges involved wanting to have the best score that'll have my friends reaching for weeks, I'd imagine most people wouldn't put the time in for something like that. Which I'm not surprised by, but some of the challenges do require some SERIOUS dedication which is why I'm mentioning this.  Some challenges really confuse me on how they can be taken and improve further, which for some people is a challenge, but the way some of them operate, it's impossible without breaking the game a bit with glitches. Score: 8/10--TUNING--I can't say much for the tuning side of things, but I have to say, from what I've seen it's VERY expansive and very in-depth. It requires some pre-exisitng knowledge (obviously), but they do a pretty good job of explaining what each feature does, I'm just not a very good gauge for where things should be. I'll be working on doing my own custom tunes and trying to understand the terms themselves as best as possible in the future. I did, however, enjoy researching what cars would be best suitable for each race or festival site and finding suitable tunes other people have made. Score: (N/A) (Not enough experience)--STORY/STORY MISSIONS--This is actually kind've the main reason I haven't done much with the story. From what I've heard, Forza games aren't based on story modes so they're minimal which is fine, but it's the dialogue that makes me want to say something. It's a very "perfect-world nothing is wrong" goodie-two shoes back-and-forth. I don't have an outright problem with it but it just makes it feel soulless at times with the characters transactions to one another. The most interesting it got was with the Tristan Storyline. I won't elaborate but it's closest it comes to any form of verbal realism. Score: 5/10For the missions themselves, they tend to be fun little introductions to different types of vehicles you can drive on different types of terrains, street races that promote 1 on 1 challenges, deliberate challenges you have to complete or exploration-based expositions that give a little rough insight on car histories. They're nice and fun but some of the challenges are difficult to 3-star for me personally. It lies within the car it provides to you. Your personal cars don't get used for these missions so you're usually held back by the car you're given, and it can get a little frustrating. Score: 6/10--FESTIVAL PLAYLISTS--Festival Playlists are exclusive challenges you can complete to fill up a meter bar that'll grant you a free car based on what season you're playing in, the harder the challenge tends to be, the more points it seems to give. A lot of the challenges are based around using certain cars for festival sites (danger zones, speedtraps, etc) or race types. I have to say though, one of the most frustrating things involving the playlist I've done, have been the online matchmaking races. It forces you to play with other players, and thats where online interactions make or break things. You can't choose to play it with bots, however you almost always have to go against bots.  The car restrictions are usually insane and will have you pulling your hair out. To give deliberate context, the challenge "Going Down a Storm" was just unrealistic and terrible. Relying on other players will always be an issue. Its also for that reason I haven't done really any online matchmaking outside of playlist requirements. Score: 7/10--REGULAR RACES--These are the bulk of what you'll be doing which is why I've saved this part for last. There are different types of races that all have their own Festival zones based around them, Rally, Dirt, Cross-Country, Street, and Road. All race types are really fun to play and they push for experimentation of different cars (if you're willing, because you can also just keep going with an "old reliable" if you so choose). They provide drivatar bots based around your cars score and type range. Based on the difficulty it really is really good for a ncie casual racing experience. I won't go too in-depth on the race types, but I will say, they're all seriously enjoyable. Even the ones I thought I wouldn't like became something I was excited to complete. Score: 10/10Overall this game is a seriously good 9/10 imo.--TL;DR--From a casual perspective, this game does the realism and illogical fun in a really nice/realistic balance, the races and challenges are really fun to complete if you're willing to put in the time and effort. Story is a bit lacking, but the game isn't known for story, so I wouldn't sweat it. Overworld is nice to look at and fun to drive in. This game gets my "Game of the Year" vote for 2021 if that's any indicator on how I feel.UPDATE: Pretty much a year later and my opinion hasn't changed, but once you complete all of the regular races, the "bulk" of what you are going to be doing is weekly challenges (Festival Playlists). Some of the challenges are EXTREMELY challenging depending on the restrictions put in place, which is I guess the point, but it doesn't leave much room for error. Honestly, in a strange way, the game feels more like a virtual pet you need to take care of week by week if you want to keep being entertained by the game. If you aren't interested in doing weekly challenges to get exclusive cars you can't get on the wheelspins, good luck finding something to truly do to pass the time once you've completed the main races. After doing so many Festival playlists to general completion, it becomes droning and another chore. It's always fun, but there comes a point where getting the exclusive cars each week eats away at your soul. That being said, every now and again they introduce new Danger Signs or Speedtraps, (etc etc etc), and/or Races, but besides that, its mainly Festival Playlists, and again, they're not bad, but it becomes droning.

author: Pixel
review: The game itself is insane, probably the one arcade racing game to play if you are into racing games. I do say arcade racer but its not like NFS or The Crew which are hardcore arcade racers. This is somewhat in between arcade and sim but can be more arcadey if you want.There's a wide variety of cars to choose from so no one is left out (although could use more SUVs). Very in-depth tuning and a lot of performance upgrades for most cars. This time some performance upgrades affect the sound of the car as well.Visually, the game is insane...if it works on maxed out settings. I have a 3070 and still cannot get it to work at 60FPS maxed out at 1440P (even 40FPS is not very stable) but it looks so much better on Xbox sadly which is a weaker system. Hopefully they optimize it.I usually don't care about the single player of games like this where multiplayer is an option and in FH5 as well, I don't care about the single player. They tried for a story or dialogue but its just cringey and would be better off with just one person telling everything to us rather than having multiple characters repeating the same dialogues over and over again. But hey its a racing game with multiplayer so for me that's not a downside.The online is well, its great when it works. The leaderboards are filled with hackers so have fun trying to get a legit score on there. But playground games cannot let people use most of the custom designs because its a kids game and ban the creators indefinitely. Mind you that on kid accounts for Xbox, most of the online content is disabled unless parents enable it. Considering how big tunes, liveries and tracks are in this game its really detrimental for the community. The devs are just on a power trip on banning people.Even after the patch the performance is horrible for the game (I've reset my PC so that is not at fault here). FH4 ran much much better and looked better too (since I cannot play above the high preset very well). The roads randomly turn into rainbow and black boxes. The foliage is just TV static and tons of bugs like suddenly stopping the car and falling out of the map.TL;DR: One of the best if not the best open-world racing games but can go downhill real fast if the devs don't patch the major issues like hacking, online disconnects and performance. All they do right now is ban people randomly for sharing a spongebob like livery. I wish I could give a neutral rating on Steam but for now a negative will have to do.

author: Replon
review: The game itself is fun with one massive caveat: The AI is fundamentally broken. You will always be beaten off the line, and even on dirt tracks the AI has perfect grip. If you're miles ahead the game will teleport all the AI behind you, and if you're a bit behind the lead car will basically rocket off into Forza Horizon 6. The difficulty between races is wildly inconsistent, some races you can smash the AI even with them teleporting around, and others you'll be in last place as the entire pack of AI will finish and be done having lunch right as you cross the finish line.I wish there was a half recommend, if the AI doesn't sound like a big deal then its a good game. If you cant stand obviously cheating AI, don't bother until they fix it...if they fix it.

author: Blu
review: 1. I don't like Mexico being chosen as the place to drive2. I believe that the game is purely driven by cinematics as it makes up half the game so far3. I have yet to experience an open world4. The mouse is useless, and yes I know its made by xbox, but it shouldn't remain on the screen no matter what I do5. Not realistic in the slightest.  I was expecting a realistic game but cars and motorcycles dropping from the sky ruined it6. The only cool part I experienced was the 10 seconds where I raced the place down the runstrip7. Player customization sucks ass8.  Its 100 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ gigs and I expected more in general9. The map isn't even that big when you can go 300 mph10. Having like 15 gears ruins the immersion11.  The game was literally pixelated until I turned my graphics to EXTREME 8x DLSS12. "Literally pixelated" was not an exaggeration, the graphics were ass13. Wreckfest has better car physics and noises14. The audio is â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥; really loud during "normal driving" and extremely quiet during cutscenes (excluding the announcers voice which is was too loud)15. More on the cinematic thing: The announcer is annoying and talks too much16. Opening cutscene wasn't good17. I can drive the Hoonigan car (I hate Hoonigan) 18. Drifting sucks: I tap the E-brake and I spin out19. The planes being flown above our cars while we drove to the festival was not realistic in the slightest, literally pulling 20 g's going back and forth on both sides of the road20.  The festival setting sucks too, doing one race then going straight back there, another small race then a race back to the festival: too repetitive21. Xbox studios amirite 22. No incentive to drive if I get a 2020 Chevy Corvette as my first vehicle23. Ford Bronco's really aren't even that cool24. Vehicles don't get dirty when driving over gravel or dirt25. Minimalist hud ew yuck gross26. I cant find a way to turn down my sensitivity and its way too high27. Stick figure ass hands turning the wheel Minecraft style when I am in first person28. When racing the bikes and wingsuit guy, the entire race it said position 4/4 but when I crossed the finish line it said first place29. Black border around license plates make it hard to read

author: un
review: As of right now this game is a bit half and half with me leaning more towards it being great. They've really fixed the sounds in this game and have made the driving a lot more realistic in terms of arcade style racing. The tire smoke is also much better but I know it can be a hassle for some so they should make an option to alter it in some way shape or form. The map being a bigger is a plus and I've already been playing longer than I expected I would without getting bored. Also, you just can't beat downhill or uphill drifting on la gran caldera. If you've been a long time Forza Horizon 5 fan this game will be great, considering it's ditched Forza Horizon 4's lack of diversity and feels like a Forza game again. I won't get too in depth on the game's strong points and I'll do the same for the bad points/cons, the cons being small bugs, server issues, and others. My main tick right now is how unstable the servers are. Don't get me wrong they've been slowly improving them but it's been going a lot slower than promised. Players around you including players in your convoy will still occasionally disappear, you'll experience some game crashing when you least expect it, for some the fps on the game gets progressively worse depending on how long your session is, and playing online can sometimes be dreadful (in terms of load speeds etc). After saying all of this I'd still recommend this game to anybody. If you were somebody who's new to the franchise, or just racing games in general then I'd recommend trying it out with the Xbox game pass first. This is mainly because, if you don't like the game after a month then you really won't have a reason to play it afterwards, so save yourself the 50-59 dollars and just use 10 for the game pass to try it out, and you also get all those other games if you're interested. If you've never had the game pass before you can subscribe for 1 dollar the first time which is pretty nice, so you'd get Forza Horizon 5 for a dollar for 1-3 months depending on whatever deal they have going on.
