author: F0nda
review: It's a typical Horizon game, and that's the problem. Yet another big, entirely empty map with nothing but dirt and rocks to look at. is it an improvement over FH4? yes. However I'd still prefer the FH4 map over Mexico. Car catalog is fresh, plenty of new additions with returning favorites. Turn 10 took a page from Need for Speed and added some crazy body kit options and some new rims that weren't in FH4. that being said, why on Earth, after 5 installments in the Horizon series, can I not adjust the wheel depth? When it comes to wheels, I believe they are the defining feature on a vehicle. An RWB Porsche looks better with a deep dish rim however I am unable to get the desired look due to these restrictions. I find it inexcusable at this point and I'm honestly tired of the direction the series is headed. In my opinion, the Horizon series is the racing game equivalent of a participation award.

The big thing i didnt like is there is no support for Track IR. So thumbs down

author: Bizarro
review: I want to recommend this game, I really do. But I can't.Pros: It's a lot of fun. Driving is a pleasure and the races & challenges are a blast. The community is pretty nice too. The radio stations are fun but get repetitive after a while. The hotwheels map is a friggin blast and if my game still worked like it should, I'd still be spending most of my time in-game there.Cons: Devs seem like they don't care very much about quality control. Every update breaks something for me; the donut media update in particular straight up made the game unplayable with a controller for me, which is a must have if you don't have one of those elaborate racing sim setups for your pc. Playing racing games with a mouse+keyboard sucks. There is also a particularly tiresome grind to get through if you want to unlock everything. There are also a lot of hackers; if you want to get anywhere near the top 10% of players on any of the leaderboards, you need to cheat. It's pretty â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ up that they haven't addressed this yet.Don't even bother buying this game if you intend to play it offline. It writes home to microsoft constantly and if it can't connect to their servers, well then you're out of luck. When I first tried to play this game, back when I had disabled the windows store, it would just ctd on launch. Before the donut media update, I didn't update windows for a while and the game would also crash because the windows store was out of date. DRM like this should be illegal tbh.Here's to hoping Playground gets around to fixing things and actually adding in content that players want instead of occasionally releasing a few new cars & dropping this like a hot rock when FH6 comes out.

author: Versia
review: If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

author: bradyonly
review: So the game is pretty. I'll give it that. It's a gorgeous game. I wasn't a huge fan of the handling though. It felt sluggish and laggy and I was super weirded out by it taking my friend's names and tossing them in a race with me. I was also incredibly annoyed by the lack of skipping cutscenes for half-assed voice acting with people I don't give a damn about. I was hoping for more of a pick your car, upgrade it, drive it to different events to earn more to upgrade it and so on. I don't get why I was dropped out of a helicopter 3 times, in 3 random locations with 3 random vehicles, driving insanely fast through a jungle and off cliffs that felt straight outta Just Cause. The mouse camera control is also complete junk. The mouse isn't restricted to the window and when you hit the edge of the window, the camera stops. Maybe I didn't give it enough time. I felt an hour should have been more than enough time to make it through whatever the hell that prologue was. They're trying waaay too hard to pack action into this.

author: OfficialBlazyâ„¢
review: As a lover of racing games and simulators and after completing Forza Horizon 5 with still lots of achievements to go i'm not gonna spoil it for you so it's up to you if you want to get this game.I advise you to buy Premium Edition on sale as you get a lot of extras that you can't buy in game and also a huge  + + + that there is no microtransactions because Premium Edition does the job here. In F5 you race in Mexico and the intro was awsome and also you can pick whatever race you want to start with.After intro you will get a lot and i mean A LOT of map icons just throwed and popped at you as there is so much work.Can you play solo offline? YES YOU CAN! And that's the best part :) How big is map? Oh it's big but also if you have premium edition the map icons will just start to pop up everywhere questioning what to do first so just take your time here.Is this game hard? No it's not hard but if you think and feel that you are too good in them races you can adjust that setting higher and also the higher you adjust the difficulty the more winning % bonuses you get but AI gets harder as well. Championship races are LOCKED in very hard difficulty so you can't change that and it may take a lot of tries to win it as it took me over 10 tries or more just to pick the right car so AI is quite hard in championship but it takes time. Also championship races are timed so i take it this is more of a radiant activity if you love doing side stuff.The rewards in seasons are great and my personal fav is spin the wheel so getting credits within my time over 20h i got like over 2million and it's still stacking so fear not if you think you can go broke.Are there any bugs? Some minor bugs but fixes and patches are here and there so make sure to follow up on that so nothing serious.So if you love to drive, explore, taking photos and race around in an open world, then FH5 is for you and belive me you will not be disappointed. The only con i have is that there is no police chases but as an owner of premium edition i can tell you that this con didn't bother me at all as there are so many collectables (treasure maps) that they will pop up instantly for you go and collect them.I don't know how standard edition is compared to the others but belive me premium is worth and i'm sure the developers will give us more in the future untill FH6 is out.Rating 9/10

author: Capitan Miao
review: Forza Horizon 5 is a clear example of why having a huge map doesn't always mean it's a good thing. I have a lot of criticisms for the game, but for now, I will focus on the three main ones: map content, roads and handling model. I will also compare the game with FH4 and GTA 5 because I expected it to be better than its predecessor and older open world games. The map is huge, but boring and empty. The desert biome is just sand and cacti. The jungle biome is just trees. The farmland biome is just crops. There is only one major city - Guanojuato - but even it is small. There are a few towns scattered along the coasts on both ends but they are uninteresting. There are hardly any landmarks worth visiting, apart from Copper Canyon and... well, I can't think of any. There is a giant volcano but it serves no purpose. There's also a stadium in the middle of the map, and it also serves no purpose other than Playground Games event. Even FH4 is more urbanized than this. Street races actually felt like street races, not some country road cruising. Details are severely lacking compared to GTA V. Now, you might say GTA is an open-world game, but so is FH5. You might say, Rockstar games has decades of experience in making open-world games, but GTA V was released in 2013, and FH5 was released a year short of FH's 10-year anniversary, and 9 years is plenty of time. Instead, what we got is an empty map.Now, the roads. Boring as always. Virtually all of the roads are two-way single-laned, apart from the massive highway stretching from East to West, but even the highway looks like it was placed to satisfy players' requests as FH4 didn't really have one. Sharp corners are gone, and are replaced by long and excruciating bends. A typical road segment starts with a short straight, slight bend to the right, short straight, slight bend to the left, short straight and so on. Racing on roads like these felt extremely boring. It also looks like the roads were placed there before orogeny happened. Instead of roads that follow the contour of the terrain, sometimes you'll find them going over hills. The only road up the mountain feels like it was made for drifting.Finally, the handling model. It drastically changed from FH4's. Cars are more drift-friendly now. You can drift with almost any car now, even with FWD cars. Responsiveness is very low. I cannot recommend this game because of the lack of enough content to justify its price tag. If you value your money more, play FH4 instead.

author: Anointed With Napalm
review: The reason I bought this was in hopes of replacing my old favorite, Need For Speed ProStreet, with something more modern and less of a kludge to get working. I generally play different genres entirely, but occasionally I want to play some racing games and in the past ProStreet was my fix, it was everything I wanted a racing game to be. Just so you have an idea of where I'm coming from.I wrote a major essay and realized I need to be more concise, so here:The game starts with lots of long, annoying unskippable cutscenes.Character creation: you have to choose a name from a list. Either a list of mostly anglosaxon names or a list of nauseatingly edgy nicknames. When I went on to choose a Literally Me appearance, every time I tried to select a hairstyle, for some reason my chosen character was replaced with an EtHniCaLlY dIvErSe woman that I felt no connection whatsoever with.I was immediately showered with plentiful praise by the game despite not even having done anything yet. I pretty much kept my headphones off after it started so I can't comment on how much of that there really was.When I finally got to the actual racing part of the game, it was mostly just holding down RT. Brakes were optional, crashing into other cars and barriers had no consequences and was more effective.In terms of handling, cars didn't feel distinct. The Mitsubishi Lancer Evo that I bought as soon as I could was just a slower version of the starter Corvette Stingray despite the fact that the Lancer is 4WD and the Corvette is RWD.In order to get from one race to another, I had to drive around in freeroam. Normally I might really like that, but even with the Corvette the most efficient method was to point the nose at the destination and hold down RT until I was there. Didn't matter what was in between. A giant hill with like 60 degree slopes was irrelevant. Also gave me loads of XP for smashing everything on the path.Speaking of XP, like 90% of the time there were some kind of rewards on the screen. I was constantly being showered with XP or god knows what else for every little thing I ever did.There's more I could write but I'll leave it at that. Maybe if I played much more, my opinion would change. Maybe I'm too much judging a book by its cover. But by Lord Gaben's decision a game has two hours to impress me before I have to make a decision - and this one didn't.

author: SINEWAVE
review: Starting off with the positives, FH5 is overall a reasonably enjoyable experience for fans of open world racing games, with good car variety, a particular highlight being the inclusion of older and more "normal" cars rather than just modern supercars, unlike for example the recent Need for Speeds.The livery editor is also by far the best in the genre, with an enormous layer count available, only real issue being that a few cars have slight texture mapping issues. I do wish importing liveries as SVG files was possible, however I fully understand why in a multiplayer game it isn't.Driving physics are also generally polished and enjoyable, and strike a good balance of sim to arcade, leaning a bit towards a more arcade-y feel.And as a final particular highlight, the drivatars have a decent variety of customisation, and for the first time in my racing game history of over 10 years, I actually felt truly welcome in the game as a transgender person thanks to FH5 allowing you to choose pronouns, voice, and character model independently, huge respect to the developers for that from me.Moving onto the negative parts, to me personally by far the biggest flaw is that while the map has some variety in scenery, driving on it feels largely the same no matter where you go, and there's a huge lack of track style variety at least in road/street racing due to this, only exceptions being a couple of races in the unfortunately very tiny city area, which feels more like a small town than a city to me. This causes the map to quickly get boring to race or just cruise on. It also feels kind of lacking in a feeling of life, as so much is just desert/jungle/fields with barely any infrastructure, car meets, or anything of the sorts.Another issue, mainly if you're coming from Need for Speed games like I did, is that the availability of customisation parts is very limited, however I do understand the reasons for this as modeling parts for the large car quantity would be an enormous undertaking. Still, I would appreciate at least some more of various racing-style body kits for example, such as GT3 or DTM-style ones for more cars.As for multiplayer, I personally find it annoying that meta builds keep being so effective, and the multiplayer experience in general could use some balancing and polish. I would also greatly appreciate no-contact racing in Horizon Open, as Forza Horizon feels more like a contact sport than racing, even in road races. Only exception being at certain times of the night when I've been able to get matched with others interested in clean, proper racing instead of bumper cars.Oh and also the Mazda RX-7's 4-rotor sounds great in hood camera (which I mainly use), but really could use a better sound when heard from the follow camera.TL;DR:Pros:+ Good car variety+ Exceptional livery editor+ Solid driving model+ Great and remarkably inclusive character customisationCons:- Map feels bland and gets boring fast- Aftermarket body parts for cars quite limited- Meta builds- Ramfest multiplayer except at specific times at nightVerdict: 76/100, probably should've personally gone with FH3 or 4 for the more fun map

author: Marcia Stigum
review: This is a conditional recommendation. Long story short it's a decent game that you don't feel like playing again.  Me personally I enjoyed most of the curated content. Most of that stuff is rather enjoyable. Unfortunately the weekly challenge stuff can leave a bad taste in your mouth. On the other hand I wouldn't recommend the weekly grind system they got set up. It just gets too tiresome. Some of the weekly multi-player races and game modes can really struggle with game balance. If you happen to not have a car that fulfills the criteria of a certain race, you'll end up with a selection of eligible cars. The car selection itself is not the issue. The issue is that some players can bring their own cars which are fully upgraded for said event. The issue is that there's a big difference between let's say a lv 860 car vs a lv 899 car. No matter how good your driving skills are you can't catch up because they got better grip, acceleration and top speed. Casual online races for weekly challenges should have a fixed selection of rental cars. There's also the issue of team imbalance when it comes to other game modes like capture the flag and "zombie" mode. If you're on the losing side there's no mechanism to rebalance teams. If players on the losing team quit then tough luck turning things around. I've ended up on a team with only three players. When the outcome is already decided then why even try? Even winning under such circumstances feels dirty.Of course the game must encourage players to engage with the battle royale mode with its weekly challenge. While technically you can opt out you will be deprived of a weekly reward that should've been paired to another race or challenge. It's so annoying to have a gimmicky battle royale force-fed like this.The most annoying thing is that money rewards got nerfed hard. If you've played a previous Forza Horizon game you'll probably be a little peeved to say the least. Maybe some expansion or major weekly challenge overhaul could improve the experience down the line. The last time I played this game it still has the same issues.

author: Aegiscarr
review: As much as I love the Horizon games, this one is kind of an unstable mess. Regular crashes, random frame drops, and the not uncommon "Low Streaming Bandwidth" error. These issues are apparently known by Microsoft and Playground Games, but instead of pushing out an update that is just focused on fixing stuff, they keep adding content to the game.I wish I could recommend this, as it's an incredible game, but if you don't want a racing game that's about as polished as the raw metal these cars are made of, don't get this one. Maybe the experience is better on Xbox, but I'm not shelling out 300+ bucks to not deal with issues that should have been fixed about half a year ago.

author: Golwar
review: This is my first Forza game ever and loving arcade racers, it was a pretty obvious and easy purchase considering the stellar reputation and ravishing reviews.And by far the most parts about this game are indeed great, if not the best in the genre.But I expected more. Way more. And primarily I have to complain about the size of the map at this opportunity.  Yes, there is lots of variety with jungle, desert, snowy volcano etc.  But these are all pretty limited in their dimension. There literally isn't much to explore besides driving every single road that takes a different turn or finding some hidden cardboard.There are plenty of cars and they are great. But recent cars are rare, some car categories feel pretty barebone. Similarly, I'd judge the music library. Racing itself is fun but the difficulty balancing isn't satisfying. Either it's mostly too easy against the AI or too unrealistic.One of the greatest disappointments though is how little Playground Games seems to know about game design, despite all the experience they should obviously have. On the one hand, you gather hundreds of cars easily, on the other their constant wheelspin changes show that their agenda is more about reacting to developments than following a proper and established plan.Oh well, it's still a great raceing game -  if you keep your expectations in check and play in small healthy doses.

author: Big Nutt
review: The game itself is pretty good, but I just can't really recommend this. I can count on one hand the number of online races I've had that didn't have someone ramming people around corners or pinning them against walls in order to pass. The races and courses also seem very short, so when someone runs you off the course early, you're basically out of the race. Also even in the team races people will be ramming teammates around to the point that the whole team winds up losing. All of that is online gripes, but playing solo it just seems like there's not all that much to do, after you go through most the races a couple times there's really not much reason to keep playing unless you just simply want to collect cars. I do like the game a lot, just other players made it really not fun to play.

Then you force all of them into a basement and blindfold them all. you leave the children there and take the mother upstairs where you brutally murder her and feed her to her children. Then you wait a few years so that the children grow up so you can torture them to the verge of death into martyrs, especially the girls. martyr in this context is meant as a witness, meaning while they are in the verge of death, they might see the afterlife. thats what the myths say. if they see the afterlife, i will force them to tell me what they saw, causing me to instantly wanting me to kill myself after getting "spoiled" about the afterlife, making my life meaningless. If you really feel to do this, this game is perfect to drive with your car on a highway while listening to some music to clear your head and get rid of such thoughts.Game is 9/10 it has alot of cars and feels realistic(i dont have a licence and i have never driven a car)i'm â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ at racing so maybe this game'll be a 10/10 in the future.

author: Avion
review: I'm not usually one for racing games, not a car guy, never been super interested in anything like that but Forza is so, so brilliant. It's beautiful, it's fun, it's time-consuming and I love it. I love collectables, love the hundreds and hundreds of cars that give you a million different ways to play, love the many different kinds of races and the challenge they bring. This is genuinely the best racing game possibly ever, and with it only being 2 months old, I'm excited for the future DLC content and possible new cars, events, clothing items, songs, etc. Love the inclusion of choosable pronouns, the music is great but I will say, it's like 20 songs so it loops pretty fast and can get kinda repetitive. Like I said, definitely needs more songs, but the ones they do have are pretty solid, especially for a racing game. Love, love, LOVE this game. I've purchased it twice, once for me, once for my fiance, and ALL DLC and have 0 regrets. It is so, so worth it all.

I guess it's my fault the connectivity for this game is such hot garbage that it randomly drops your connection from Horizon Life. I guess it's my fault that they couldn't be bothered to fix the accolades. Every single case they close as "solved" without actually solving the issue. Do not buy this game, do not support this game. If Playground Games closed tomorrow and Forza ceased to be, I can honestly say that because of this experience, I would not miss it.

author: chicken burrito bowl
review: While Forza Horizon 5 is entertaining, I can't recommend it in good faith at this time. There are too many issues with optimization and the game does not run as well as it should. It is very frustrating sitting for over 5 minutes and waiting to load into a game while you stare at the menu screen on modern hardware. I originally installed the game on an 870 QVO SSD and constantly ran into issues with the game hanging because textures didn't load in fast enough. I switched to an 860 EVO and the performance issues were mitigated somewhat, but I still have to do a song and dance every time I want to play the game. I usually close and restart 3 or so times before I can actually play.

author: Einsteinium
review: This game is pretty much FH4 on an new map, which doesnt sound half bad however there are some major things that destroy the experience:- The Map: Lots and lots of Offroad opportunities but very few tracks and streets for good racing. Its lacking a proper highways and a decent city.- Seasons: While I like the storm season, the "winter" season is non existing (just the tip of the volcano). In general the seasons worked better in FH4 and provided a better dynamic.   - Horzion Open: Extremely long loading times, which are hyper annoying. Drift and Playground games have their own category, however Rally, Offroad and Race all share the SAME category. WHY? I find my self joining and existing most Horizon Open events just to search for a Racing event. Also you cant choose the performance class...- I really dont like the UI. While it may look nice with all these tiles it does not work for me. I find myself searching for certain menu entries or going back few levels just to access certain view (eg. tuning and styling). Also some loading times are quite annoying. The UI doesnt remember certain settings (like show favourite cars only - a necessity when the game is throwing all these garbage cars at you). Also WHY cant I start an event in the Festival Playlist or look at the map while I am at home? And many many more issues regarding the user experience...- Horizon Link: You may have only two static and two dynamic chat options. How am i supposed to communicate with other players in freeroam? Just some basic small talk would be nice without changing the forza link settings, which are burried deep within in the menu.- Can we have awesome music while driving? Nah- The whole festival thing feels a bit cringe (a huge cargo plane doing low passes and turning on a dime? Sure).- AI cars rubber band and lag all over the places. They drive like on rails. They crash in any Civi Car when traffic is turned on- Low streaming band width: While the game may be optimised for graphics It surely isnt for online play. What a pity... the whole game is online only.

Brilliance!Whatever happened to giving players the choice to do what race they want to do instead of randomly cycling through series until they find the road/street Open Series they were looking for. One last â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ thing, even if you join a lobby with players waiting alongside you, the game for no reason whatsoever does not throw you into the race, just sit in the lobby and rot.As of now, don't bother getting this â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ because it really is lobby waiting simulator

author: CJFIVE
review: I rarely leave reviews, so I hope this notably displays my concern. This addition to the Horizon series is just disappointing, I loved Forza Horizon 4 along with all of the new and incredible features it brought with it. Do not get me wrong, I love that Playground has brought over almost all of the features from Horizon 4 to this new game. However, I have two main problems with Horizon 5. Firstly, the overall performance has been terrible, and I have a relatively high end PC. Even after tweaking settings, I still have constant stuttering, lengthy load times, and terrible frame rates, I've never had any issues like this on Horizon 4. Secondly, I feel like so much of the "story/progression" is one big history lesson... A few facts or myths here and there is no issue, but so far it's definitely a lot more than just a few, and it feels like the game so heavily revolves around it... Like I just want to race and have fun...

author: PeteTheHeat

Every time I join convoy something is wrong. Either I can't see them or they cant see me, super annoying. I'd rate this game 2/5. If that bug is fixed this game has potential.

author: Peacebob
review: "Visual style doesn't aspire to real-world graphical fidelity (though a noble goal in itself)â€¦ it describes a distinctive look and feel that suffuses an entire game." I originally thought that I'd be recommending this game to people. The content, however, runs out all too quickly. I've just been driving around when I get bored, I was hoping that competitive would be coming back to Horizon, but it's not the case. The developers said they want this game to be social, casual, and friendly. While the second two of those qualities are well represented in the game, the social aspect is almost completely void, players disappear on each other all the time, even when in a pre-made group with your friends.

author: Cowdoy
review: Gameplay feels good, and with such a large variety of cars there is so much to do and play with. The downside is the AI in this game doesn't feel anything like previous games where they would mimic players, instead they have as some might call "infinite grip" where they seem to never lose traction and take corners at speeds that should not be possible. Difficulty is just a scale of how fast you want the AI to complete the track it seems. For the online aspect numerous players including friends of mine have received perma bans for creating decals, these bans came without warning and mean I may never be able to race them again. As such I won't be playing this game myself until the issues are addressed which may never realistically happen as they already got our money.

author: Celly
review: It's got some issues (mainly connection problems, no traffic on the road while online, lack of choice in MP racing, cheating AI on higher difficulties, and some challenge bugs), but despite all that it's still a great game. I got the $100 edition and don't regret it a bit, cuz I'm gonna be putting hundreds of hours in this one. Highly recommended for anyone who loves cars.Edit: The issues I mentioned above other than the AI have all since been fixed. More minor ones have popped up since that will probably never be fixed (an annoying echo in Forzavista for example) but none are major annoyances like there were when I left the review. Good stuff, and still playing hundreds of hours later like I said!Edit 2: The Forzavista echo has actually been fixed! Never been happier to be made to look like a fool. A full year and 500 hours later I'm still happy to jump in every week and get the new car(s).

author: DarkRye
review: I gotta say, this is the best Horizon game I've ever played. The ridiculous moments don't feel as forced as the other games, and the map is the best I've ever seen, it's gorgeous and the cars feel so real. In fact, course design is one of the best things about this title. Never been this addicted to a Horizon title in my life, usually I'm more of a track racer. So why the negative review? Game devs NEED to stop releasing games before they are thoroughly tested and the bugs / crashes are fixed. The amount of bugs and crashes, especially while playing multiplayer, is staggering. My buddy can't even launch the game and he paid for all the dlc. I definitely recommend getting this game eventually, but maybe wait for some of the bugs to get fixed, especially if you plan to play online with people because that's where most of the bugs are. If you play mostly solo and are willing to risk it, it might be worth the purchase but be aware of bugs and issues you may experience.Update: one month later and my friend still can't play the game. He's tried everything short of reinstalling Windows.... inexcusable. He has tried every single recommended solution, submitted a ticket to Forza, and there still is no solution.

author: Xierra
review: As a new player of the Forza series, I am reviewing this as a game of its own. Wheel player. Physics definitely simcade. You can treat it like a racing sim if you want to.The game is fun as a collect-a-thon, race what you want, along with some preset cars for certain events. Cars can be bought with in-game credits, some only obtained from wheelspins that you get in-game pretty regularly. The game can be played very casually by freeroaming and collecting stuff, or competitively through Open Racing (Online races) and Rivals (Time Trial Leaderboards). The game gives you enough things to do through objectives and quests in the Horizon Festival, collecting new cars and Forzathon points. However, it's not without its flaws. At the moment, a convoy is needed to PvP. Since I don't have friends to play with, it's quite a lonely game. Open Racing, the equivalent of race matchmaking, is fun, however, we cannot choose car class nor tracks to suit our desires. Also, there's no way to reach out to people you raced with to add friends, send kudos, or something of the sort for good racing, so the social interactivity aspect is... very lacking. Perhaps this is something the Xbox takes advantage of but not well implemented in Steam? Eliminator is not fun for me... just because while you try to eliminate someone, solid trees and very uneven terrain tend to get in the way. The cars in Eliminator tend to handle really bad even with TC and ABS on.As for issues with Mexico itself? There is no modern cityscape. Which means there's no big city with skyscrapers at the end of a highway, no parking lot environments to have a car meet, no familiar roads of any sort. There's a lack of "a popular place to gather" other than the old town. Mexico feels too far from home for me.Keep in mind I'm only pointing out the big flaws that is going to keep me from actively playing FH5 in the near future. The game as a whole is amazing; just that it's not exactly what I hoped it'd be. it's best to wait for a discount, you won't miss out on "exclusive" vehicles, since you can still get them in wheelspins. My thoughts may change once Ranked comes out, if it exists. The co-op team race in Horizon Open has good potential for a clan battle.

author: Khrushchev
review: One of the best racing game I've ever played. I've played it since the first one and as time goes it kept getting better and better. The graphics have gone better since the last one, really liked the new festival site mechanism and bringing the multiple festival site back. author: p0ffjr
review: I am personally a DD wheel user (SC2 Pro), the game is fun to drive with it. The physics and FFB are pretty good for an arcade title. I would prefer a stronger road sensation though, but we can't judge this as a sim anyway.As to what to avoid if you wan't to have a nice driving experience and save some time:1. Don't play online if you wan't to avoid stuttering, probably netcode is super bad - let's hope for a fix but I personally don't care much about it.2. If you have a DD wheel (or any wheel), with pedals, shifter etc. that can't make them work at all in game, download Emuwheel and vJoy and you will be able to use them.3. As for the force feedback, I recommend maxing out road feel because it's not very noticeable even with strong wheelbases and reducing off-road feel because it's a bit too strong.4. Regarding the texture popping your only solution to make it better is to increase world detail in the graphics settings.5. Avoid bots at very high difficulties for obvious reasons.

author: Dr Mantis Toboggan
review: This is a really good game, but is so horribly buggy currently that it is seriously effecting my ability to enjoy the game. There are a lot of areas that the game improves on compared to the last one however they make some weird choices that makes it feel, at least at the minute, like one step forward and one step back. Things like the fact that you cannot see the last survivor on the zombie playground game make the game mode unplayable at times meaning you have to wait the timer out and the decision to make it much more unclear as to how much money you earn at the end of a race. It will likely be fixed and become better than it's predecessor soon but at the minute I would advice people not to waste their money.Bugs I've experienced:- Memory leaks- Audio disappears- Players disappearing at random- Civilian vehicles disappearing at random- VIP disappearing at random along with benefits- Resetting what car you were last in (defaulting you to a different car)- VIP house no longer being owned sometimes- 5+ wait times in playground games- Cannot play seasonal events (races or playground games) with a convoy- Home not being set spawn- Semi-frequent crashes to desktop- Connection issues- Complete lock upsOther issues:- No audio option for turning other players mics off- No push to talk- Cannot see the last survivor in infected- Some barn finds take â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ ages to repair

author: shadowlz
review: I've played every Horizon game-- from way back when I played the first Horizon on my Xbox 360 in the eighth grade. For reference, I'm in my first year of law school (time flies).Whats fantastic about this sub series of Forza is it feels like each game is better than the last. Aspects that we take for granted in this game-- was implemented and perfected in previous games.That being said, for those of y'all that have played other Horizon games-- there is plenty of new content in this title.As it stands this is the "most complete" Horizon game and quite frankly it puts ALL OTHER open-world racing games to shame. Playground Games has out-done themselves for the fifth time.So, while I can't speak for folks that haven't played previous Forza Horizon games-- if you thought the previous one's were good-- this one is great.Performance wise-- I'm playing in 2560x1440p and I have yet to have any drops beneath 99 frames on max settings.My rig:Cpu: Intel i7-10700K CPU @ 4.21GHzGPU: RTX 3080 (Founders Ed.)Ram: 32GBInstalled on an SSD.Peripherals: Xbox One Pro Controller w/ Paddles or my racing wheel if I feel like it.

author: { RichCarThief }
review: Honestly, it's kind of hard to rate this game highly. I'm going to set aside all of the bugs that they are having on PC right now because I am confident that it will all get sorted fairly quickly. In terms of the actual game, my biggest problem is the speed of the progression. You don't really feel like you have accomplished anything after you do something in this game. There is no satisfaction when you get your first supercar, because you have probably gotten one on accident from a wheelspin, or you have already made enough money to buy one yourself. This is ignoring the fact that two of the choices for your first car are the C8 and the Mk5 Supra. You are also able to play the "finale" races within an hour or so of gameplay if you choose to. This is very broken when you look at it in terms of the story line. You are supposed to have worked your way up, becoming the best of the best in Mexico until you get to the "mega races" toward the end. Nope, you can finish three or four races and head straight to the finale ones. Even if you are like me, wanting to save those finale races until the end, it is still difficult because you can unlock the next chapter in the gameplay after only a couple races and a few PR stunts. Eventually these unlocks will stack up and you feel like you're being rushed. Also the map... yes it's pretty, yes it's big, but that's about it. There is nothing really interesting about it. Majority of this map consists of open fields and desert. It's not a bad map, but I think Playground Games could have done better. For example, setting the game in Japan like people have been asking for the past couple of games.Overall, the only real reason I'm giving it a thumbs up is because I don't think it's a bad game that deserves a thumbs down. I'm still going to play it all the time, and I'm still going to tell people it's a fun game. If I had to rate it out of ten, it would probably only get a 6.5 or 7/10. For reference, I give FH3 and FH4 an 9/10 and FH2 a 9.5/10 (I don't think any game is perfect so it's hard to give a game 10/10 imo.)

author: SirZobarX
review: NewThey fixed it.  I'm happy now.______________________________________________OldAfter the disastrous release of Cyberpunk I honestly hoped that major AAA releases would start testing their products before release date.  Forza Horizon 5 didn't seem to have learned that lesson.  The game is one big pile of garbage in its current state.  Crash after crash after crash.You can't even AFK in the menu to get a cup of coffee without coming back to a crash.  Now here's the actual big problem.  When the game isn't crashing, it's just not fun to play.  The cars feel like lifeless bricks, and the AI for solo races, on the same difficulty setting, doesn't work right between the car classes.  For example, I can come in first place and destroy the competition in a class B.  Same race, same settings, Class C, almost fail, Class A, dead last every time, class S and I almost lap the competition.  It just doesn't feel right.  It doesn't matter how good or bad I race, I win every time in a B class and lose every time in an A.The AI cars don't behave even remotely close to what we've come to expect from modern racing games.  Collisions are broken.  No other word for it.  I've tapped cars in races and send them flying off track.  I've tapped cars in races and seen them maintain speed and race completely sideways following the track for a couple of seconds before floating back up facing the right way and continuing the race like nothing happened.  I've tapped cars and both of us came to dead halt.  I've run full speed in other cars and seen one fly off and one not move.  Physics?  Who needs that in Forza 5?As a fanboy, it's really hard to say this, but I just can't recommend this game.  If you own every Forza game like me, you're going to take your chances anyhow and this review doesn't matter but if you're actually concerned about spending 60 bucks right now, don't.  You will regret that purchase.  I just wish I would have realized all this before I played over 2 hours or I would have refunded it.

author: slayingclub
review: Wow, this game absolutely blew me away in terms of visual quality. The engine sound, while better, still does not hold a candle to Forza Motorsport 4. I don't understand why some engine sounds aren't ripped straight from any of the older Forza Motorsports to be honest. The servers are still a bit iffy, but that's to be expected for this game. I did have a few game crashes as well. P.S. The game is quite demanding as I can only run it at around 60 fps on maxed out settings (2560x1600) on my 5900HX, 3080 165W so just beware of that. Also, at 2560x1600, the windows taskbar still shows up at the very bottom when running the game in full screen mode. Hopefully, that issue is fixed soon

author: Pafic
review: Looking for a racing game with beautiful landscapes, seasons, weather, that all factor on your driving? Horizon is a great game, the series has been... Fun... I can't leave this review positive. You start with nothing but super cars, aside from the 2020 Ford Bronco. I get it, its cool to get into a Mclaren or a Ferrari, but the cars available are nothing new, used again, and again. The newest slew of cars available are older than 2018. Very few cars are an option as a 2020 or newer car. The cars of 2021 have been released, and 2022 cars have been showcased. A lot of them from the popular manufacturers  that the Playground Games love to use, Ford, Honda, BMW, Audi, etc. For some reason they're not in the game. Maybe DLC?One little side note on the game world. While it may have a "Mexico" feel to it. I can't help but to notice a town or two and some roadways, specifically the highways are just a ctrl + c and ctrl + v from other Horizon games.The game runs fairly smooth, aside from the random crash to desktops I've experienced. One, putting a tail fin on the Jeep Trailhawk. Crashes every time. You'll thank me knowing this. And I've had several in the general world as well as racing.Multiplayer wise, obviously a good time. One thing that bums me out, is that the people in your convoy disappear all the time. You could be racing neck and neck in the open world and they'll disappear like a Delorean reaching 88mph. My favorite version of this (of course needs to be fixed) is when you're next to your convoy not moving, and they disappear. Where do they go? Nobody knows, lol. It's one thing if random players phase in and out of existence. You know, for the server. If you're in a convoy they should be in the world so long as the game and group is running.Is this a good time? Yeah. Will it give you a good racing arcade fix? Sure. Worth the $60? Eh, maybe if you never played a Horizon game.

author: Mumbles
review: The game is superb.HOWEVER, there are currently some optimisation issues that plague the game. Specifically, with me, I have stuttering and RAM leak issues, which cause the game to run slower over time. I imagine this will get fixed, though.All in all, a solid game.UPDATE: The game now has worse stuttering than it used to, no idea why, it's unplayable for me at this point, I've asked for a refund.

author: DeadlyMouse
review: Soo here we are again a new Forza Horizon well what can I say.. THIS GAME IS ABSOLUTELY AWESOME! Map is gorgeous, not to mention the volcano and the road to the top of it, beaches are also beautiful. Oh and yeah you get the longest highway in FH5. Cars.. they sound ducking nice but you will have to try it for yourself. Races? Well they are nice and rewarding especially Goliath which is a ~55km race btw. Story? Hmm well its not bad either but I'm not necessarily play the FH series for it's story. Multiplayer oh man.. I know it's early access but yeah coop races are a bit laggy and you will get disconnected from freeroam a lot of times. Apart from these it's fun! So is it worth it? Absolutely! But only buy the Premium Edition if you will put hundreds of hours in the game.

author: sirgeefive
review: EDIT: Do you like games that cheat? Do you like leaderboards filled with 5 mile races finished in under 1 second? Do you like racing against cheaters who blatantly cheat? How about AI that blatantly cheats? When you sit down to play a game, are you all like "Gee, I wish this game would cheat more?" Then I have the game for you: Forza Horizon 5. From the comfort of your own home, you can feel the true joy of seeing cheaters always prosper. You can feel the warmth of knowing no matter how much your skills improve, the game will definitely cheat to put you in your place. Feed that inner masochist and give Horizon 5 all your money. Don't worry that the game isn't finished, they will finish it eventually. Don't worry about the bugs, those are actually hidden features. And the cheating, oh you will come to love the cheating.This is, without a doubt, the worst racing game I have ever played. Why? Start with the AI. There is NO AI. It is a simple pathfinder with no physics. No matter what the surface is, the AI is not affected by it. You can slam an AI car as hard and as fast as possible, and it will only barely move it off of the drive path, and it will immediately return, with very little loss of speed. The physics for your vehicle change drastically, depending on the event. I have not seen built-in cheating this bad outside of an EA sports game. The multiplayer is a complete joke, and is not worth wasting your time. Really, for some nice looking graphics, and the ability to collect cars like Pork-o-mon, this game is ridiculously overpriced. Don't bother with force feedback wheels, they are likewise a waste of time. Keyboard has advantage over you on your fancy wheel, controller makes you look like a clown. Tuning cars is completely unrealistic and really does nothing for the vehicle. This is not a simulator by any stretch of the imagination, but it takes one heck of a stretch of the imagination to accept this as even an arcade racer. Don't bother unless this is on the biggest sale you have ever seen, it isn't worth the hair loss or the amount of time you will spend screaming at your screen.

author: Kalbi
review: A decent game when it works. Every update seems to break the game such as in-game bugs and server issues, launch issues like infinite loading screens, freezing on loading, completely crashing before even loading. Controller will work for a good length of time and then all of sudden stop working (keyboard will stop working as well so you have to hard quit). The recent Hot Wheels update seems to be the worst offender in regards to bugs and issues. These sorts of issues are unacceptable nine months after a game release. Ironically, I would rather have a stable game that I can at least launch and play instead of content updates. The lesson here is to just wait until the devs move on to the next game and stop updating this one if you want a reliable experience.EDIT: after doing a fresh reinstall, it looks like the game runs fine. It seems like when the updates build up, issues start happening.

author: Relz
review: It does everything FH4 did, but better.This game gives me everything I would like to get from racing arcade game - LOTS of cars to drive, lots of event to participate in, tons of customization and settings to dig into.But also it gives me this Pokemon-like feeling for collecting cars, AAA-adventure-like world exploration and quite funny (although, sometimes cringey) stories to experience.The only downside is that Mexico setting is much less compelling for me than Scotland one was and some territories feel straight depressing.P.S. Yeah, to address the elephant in the room - Forza 5 is (currently) buggy. It's absolutely playable and I haven't encountered anything deal-braking, but there quite a lot of minor to medium issues. But they are working on it.The most "broken" part is online, of course. While I'm perfectly able to ride cooperatively with my friend and participate in online PVP races from time to time, there are significant disconnection issues, sync issues and some random stuff like all other cars disappearing for you in Eliminator. If you're targeting the online play with this game - it's better to wait for a month or two. If you're more a single-player racer and explorer - go right at it, as it is excitingly fun.

author: Nethew
review: I've been playing this game for about 40 hours now and it's definitely not your typical start-at-the-bottom progression racing sim. This game is about doing what you want, when you want, and I adore it for that. It starts you off with cars of varying classes so you can choose if you want to go hog-wild with a hypercar, or have a fun race in an old beater (I am a big fan o the Datsun they still have in here from the days of Forza 3!). It is an extremely chill experience (Outside of the pretty bombastic campaign, which is great in its own right!).You won't see any iconic raceways like you do in the mainline Forza games, but you will definitely see some sights! The map in this game is pretty great both in terms of size, and variance. I had a ton of fun simply exploring the map!Definitely a great time if you're looking for something chill and pretty to play!

author: RecklessRex
review: The game is beautiful and has a great selection of cars. It's not a racing game its a car game designed mostly for children imo.  The wheel to wheel racing is horrible with a defunct penalty system. If you hit a wall you get a time penalty however you can ram others off track without penalty. Worse yet you can ram an opponent into a wall and they will get a time penalty while you drive away mostly unscathed. Then there are all the game issues. Its the most I've ever paid for a video game yet it runs worse than games i play that are in beta testing. Its been 4 months since release, and i doubt it will ever run properly. You could say its my pc but it's the only game i have that's giving me issues. The other major problem is the OP cars and the performance rating system which sucks. Of the 500 plus cars available your better off checking you tube to see which cars are OP. Really you need only about 20 cars  out of the large list, because most cars just wont be competitive. So the whole rating or points system that is designed to give some balance to the racing is defunct. Expect to have your nice truck totally annihalated in a cross country race by Hot Wheels boneshaker which looks more like something built for cruising or possibly drag racing. So if your looking for a beautiful game that is poorly thought out, maybe this game is for you.

review: FH5 is by no means a bad game, but it definitely suffers from some issues, the game is stupidly easy, the flaws in the AI are extremely noticeable, there's no struggle (everyone is always super happy and everything is squeaky clean and perfect), there's practically no progression, I preferred the map in FH4, and I wouldn't have pre-ordered this game if I knew its PC launch was going to be this buggy, and it is still very buggy for me even now (crashes, graphical glitches, etc. remain). If you're lucky, you might not get any bugs or crashes, but I wouldn't wanna gamble over Â£60 and 100GB of storage space on that, just for a game that I personally haven't enjoyed as much as 4.If the game is on sale, it's definitely worth buying, but you could also just get 4 while it's on sale (and I've seen it on sale a few times, as of me editing this review it's 67% off).(If I manage to play the game without bugs I'll still give this a positive review, since the game looks great and it's still at the least enjoyable to collect cars, but it leaves a lot to be desired)

author: LLOYD
review: Beautiful Mexican tourist guide, with stunning graphic, amazing Ray Tracing effects and heartwarming dialogs focusing on positivity, equality and accessibility.Cut content on premiere, after a year most of updates are made of recycled cars form previous Horizons, worse and worse performence after every update, boring missions, nothing to do in endgame, completly blank characters, adding... interesting?... features (no they not) instead of remodeling existing cars, adding more existing convertibles, or at least standarize tuning for every car (not every car has wheel spacers, or 4 speed drag gear), or overwhelming stories in which all you need to do, is to cut across whole map ignoring racing line, and survive dialogues full of love, compliments and awarding everyone as a winner...Every new update is a new bottom for that game, even tho you thought that we are deep enough.Beautiful tourist guide - worst Horizon game up to date.

author: Porcelain Sea
review: After attempting to put the time into this game and trying to have enough patience, this game continues to disappoint. From lackluster updates to missing entire season because of incompetent devs, I struggle to want to play this game anymore. The difficulty for seasonal stuff can be utterly absurd making some series absolutely impossible for those who don't own certain cars or get enough credits to upgrade suitably. Clothing that looks good on you always turns out to be vaulted to previous shops as well as emotes, horns, and other things that should be obtainable through normal means. Wheel spins are a whole other mess in their own right as it can make getting vehicles the most grueling thing. Another majorly upsetting feature has been gifting where I've wanted to send gifts to specific friends to lend them a hand in playing but sure enough that's not possible at all. A bitter taste has been left in my mouth by this installment with some seasons being unplayable due to graphical issues or updates (such as the most recent one) making the game unplayable and crashing on launch. I was admittedly excited for the Donut Media series but sure enough that's not gonna be happening anytime soon and knowing the team, they probably won't be extending the window to participate in this series either. Where this game has it's charm, the amount of cons outweighs the pros unfortunately and it's been wearing me down overall. Hopefully the dev team can pull themselves together but until then, I can't say anything good about this game anymore.Edit: In addition to everything said here, they've also banned me for zero good reason so that's fun.

author: Anna Rei Senpai
review: I don't like racing games that lean very heavily into the realism (I love the really arcadey racers), but Forza Horizon 5 is a ton of fun. The difficulty can be tuned to however you want to enjoy racing games. Personally I have a couple assists turned on but then increase the AI difficulty. There's tons of tracks, driving in the giant map of Mexico is fun, and the music is great.Not to mention the accessibility options are plentiful and useful. The game also runs very well on a wide range of hardware. It's great on my Steam Deck, but also flexes my RTX 3080 when I'm playing at home.I just got the base version with no addons, and had a blast.

author: a crippled goat
review: For a AAA Game asking for as much money as it is, it shouldn't freeze/crash every 5 minutes. Particularly since I have about as good a rig as there is at the moment. No other games have had this issue on my PC. I've only got to spend about 15 minutes actually playing this game and hours trying to find out what's causing it to crash so often. Verified Files, Updated Drivers, turned off all other apps, gave it priority permissions, adjusted in game video settings. No solutions so far, in fact it's gotten worse from only crashing at cut scenes to just about whenever. Looks like its not just me, there's a concerning amount of players who can't get this game to work properly to no avail. What a complete dumpster fire disappointment that's ruined my mood and taken a good chunk of my money with it.

author: ThatGuyMike
review: This game is hands down a literal masterpiece. Why? Let me tell you.Yes, of course, it's very similar to Forza Horizon 4 blah blah blah.... BUT! This game patches up all the previous flaws, making it the best flawless open-world racing game that has ever come. The scale of the map is HUMONGOUS! Not only you can drive everywhere, but the surroundings and the whole environment also is beautiful, very well colourised, and realistic. All the details will consume you into one big nerdgasm. So, what's new?The first thing you'll encounter while you play is huge weather conditions. We're not talking rain or snow, but a straight-up massive sand storm, tornados, blizzards, and deep jungle rains. You can freely drive into those and take some unique pictures! Another thing you encounter very early in the game is the Volcano Exploration as a part of a Festival. Explore a volcano in 4k? HECK YEAH! (btw it looks super realistic modelled after a real-life volcano, Nuff said, right?)We got a new creation tool called EventLab. It allows you to make custom maps and events to have fun with your friends. Only creativity is the limit here!Much deeper car and character customisations. New interactive system with players. Very easy to use, simple, and fast. What's recurring?Almost everything else that's in Forza Horizon 4.Drivatars feel a little harder, but they won't be seen as a challenge once you get the grip. Barn finds now have dedicated locations, so you don't have to drive around to find them.What's the best about all of it? It doesn't push you to do anything. You can do anything you want. Don't you like the current Festival? Drive to another one! There's like 4-5 Festivals happening all around Mexico. You can explore mountains, cities, islands, jungles, and temples to see what you can find.Or you can have fun with your friends just messing around. That all in amazing 4K. Because it runs smoothly even on the mid-tier build.

author: SirAyron
review: Fun game, good selection of cars. Simply amazing graphics. I've owned every Forza title, like any horizon game it's aimed towards arcade racers. Which is fine, it's fun. However the fine tuning of cars can bare very little results when compared to Forza motorsport.My biggest gripe with Horizon is the spoon feeding of credits, chance wheel spins etc takes you to end game simply too quickly with very little left to achieve after about 40-50 hours. Which means you're repeating the same online races again and again until you get bored and inevitably like every other Forza Horizon, cease to play. Two things that need to be fixed imo.1 : Bigger performance penalty for AWD swap. A class or above you NEED an awd car to win online, as length of races are simply too short and it is damn near impossible to beat an AWD swapped car in a fast lobby as you spend the entire race catching up after they launch from the start line while you're stuck there wheel spinning.I have had to AWD swap all my RWD A class and above cars in order to be competitive. The swap simply does not add enough PP and is an OP conversion. 2 :I think a game like this needs to put some restraint on the gifting of dozens of cars and 100,000's of credits every time you play.Maybe just maybe, it will give you a bit more sense of achievement and appreciation for your garage. As after 100 hours, I have 180 cars, 90% are just given to me in wheel spins. I don't want to be gifted all these cars, I want to race, to earn credits to buy them. For the sense of accomplishment, I want to know that other players have done the same so when I see someone rocking a 300SL or a Shelby, I know that they worked hard to get that car which creates a mutual respect. Not just everyone driving lambos and side swiping you.

author: pat_stone
review: I've played nearly 100h of this game in about 3 weeks (got it a bit after release). This is my first Forza Game. To me, it's the perfect mix of silly fun and serious driving. My joy mostly comes from the single player content. I want to win every race on the map. I want to finish everything that gives accolades. In the future I'm probably gonna be working on the achievements. This has been a lot of fun so far and that's why I've spent all this time in the game.While I had fun with the game. I still decided it's important to write this review. Currently the game is rated "very positive" on Steam. This does not reflect how broken is. Around a month after release, practically all online content and some single player content is in a nearly unplayable state.- Loading times for online races are ridiculous (longer than the actual race sometimes)- Grouping doesn't work (people phase out of groups)- People are invisible in the Eliminator but can sometimes still challenge you to a race which you then lose for some reason- Some achievements and also seasonal content are bugged and can't be completed (in case of seasonal content, this can never be fixed)- Random disconnects in freeroam...Believe me, the list goes on.I don't understand how this game can be so terrible from a technical standpoint when it's the 5th edition of a series of which all the iterations before were much better (from what I've read. As I said, I haven't played them myself). This title is definitely not worth spending your money on right now.Maybe everything will be fixed in a couple of months. But that will be a couple of months too late. An experienced video game company (Development, Publishing, etc.) shouldn't get away with releasing such an unfinished prototype of a game. It doesn't even matter that it's a AAA title. I think every indie development team would be ashamed to release something as broken as this. That's why the negative review.

author: Foxy Moron
review: ok so. i have many issues with the gameits developers are some of the most incredibly lazy â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ people i've ever seen and its insanity, literally take months to fix the slightest's bugs or just outright ignore it completely the content of the game at the start is pretty decent i'll say that i had quite alot of fun at launch but overtime i gradually started to realise just how barebones this game is, there is NOTHING to do once you finish all races on the map, can make custom tracks i guess but the editor is so barebones and â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ it takes weeks to finish even the smallest tracks, the multiplayer is kinda fun but the racing is so mind numbingly unbalanced, the PI system (the games class catagorisation system) literally hasnt been changed since 2005, along with many of the game assets also just being copied and pasted from older entries. the accolades system is incredibly boring and tedious too most things just being the same thing but done 100x more and some don't even work at allthe lack of content is just appalling, almost every update just derives of 'wow guys new car that's the ultra super duper other version of the same car we already have in the game' or just copied and pasted code from 2008 or some â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ as a "new" feature and basically nothing elsethe only redeeming thing of this game is the fact that the multiplayer is actively being played (as of 2022) and that the physics are really good, however i just cannot bring myself to play this game anymore, it bores me to death and i refuse to play it anymore, if fh6 is more of this garbage i am not buying it. thank you if you actually read this all. criticism allowed.

Insane acceleration and cornering. Stick to "Pro" or lower.Otherwise it's chill.

author: Super Gremlin
review: One of the best racing games of all time. It has a ton of cars, tuning, custom livery creation for you to have your car exactly how you want. Story and progression is fun though not required to enjoy the game. Any car can be made to handle well, so the steering is more on the arcade side but not full arcade like NFS Heat.It's still a bit rough around the edges as it just launched. One thing I wish is that they had more in depth car customization like in NFS Heat, but the tuning part definitely helps make up for it.

author: Dope Pope
review: While the game is new ( as of the 24/11/2021 ) and has some network, viusal and connection bugs, it still shines as the Forza Horizon experience, just as good as Forza Horizon 4. It suffers from some growing pains, such as odd unspeicifed requirements for seasonal events which makes them seemingly impossible and very annoying, disconnections from social events at the worst times you could imagine, random crashes, work/reward lack of balance ( not as good as Horizon 4 ), some popping textures... But I ( want to ) believe that all, or most of these issues will be ironed out in the upcoming months, and we'll be left with another smooth, serene racing utopia. The map is immense, with a wide range of sceneries from jungles to towns and beaches, the weather is diverse and beautiful. The cars are, as usual, fun to drive, look great, and with a starting roster of over 500 vehicles, there's plenty to choose from, with more coming every week, if you're willing to pay. The stories and missions are not as diverse as the last time around, some of them are underwhelming, the others are fun. The characters are a bit cheesy, like they came straight from a comedy show. You land into the show as a "superstar", and no one, especially the radio presenters, won't let you forget that. The silent protagonist is also not silent anymore.The rewards overall are pretty underwhelming, for any accolade or objective you accomplish, you're most likely to get a chat line, which you can use 2 of at any given time. And with my constant connection issues despite having an okay internet connection, on top of a ghost-town feel to all spontaneous social events, I can barely even justify them existing. The potential is there and mostly fulfilled, but the game could use a little balancing and polish. Which I believe we will get.

author: Berayin
review: My legs were severed when I was 12, so i can't drive and enjoy the wind blowing through my slick hair with the top down. Luckily Forza Horizon 5 is here to make my dreams come true. After i've had my morning coffee and my daily emotional breakdown, I power up my PC, turn on my desk fan and load up FH5. The wind from my fan simulates the wind from the outside world. Doing this gives me joy in my everyday life. If it wasn't for Forza Horizon 5, I'd probably be lying in a ditch in central Amsterdam.

author: RattusStarcraft
review: I bought FH5 because I enjoyed the FH3 game. I thought it was well rounded, fun, and interesting. Unfortunately FH5 has released with metric but tonne of bugs and unclear marketing material around the limited edition controller and the DLC. See this post about the controller issue Long story short, this is just another game that made big promises and has failed to deliver on launch. I am sick and tired of companies relying on their users to find bugs in their products (not just talking about game dev's here). We are not your Guinea Pigs to test your crap ware. We are paying customers that deserve a product to work as advertised on day 1, not on day 100.Can I recommend this game right now? NoDo I think the dev's will fix their sh*&? YesCan I recommend this game after its all been fixed and patched to the way it should of been? YesIt is a fun game, it's just ruined by a bad launch, lacklustre communication and marketing, and way to many bugs for a final release.

review: Forza Horizon 5 is an open-world racing game set in Mexico. In it you play as the superstar from FH4 to beat all the races and challenges thrown at you while also expanding your car collection.I paid 100â‚¬ for this game because I really loved FH4 and while I don't regret it on the whole because the core game is really fun, it's UNACCEPTABLE that in 2021 AAA games come out broken and unfinished, yet it has been the standard for the past few years and specially this past year where nearly ALL of the games have come out like that.This game needed 2-3 more months of development yet it was rushed out so they could make that sweet Christmas money. Doesn't help that the very few patches that have been released haven't fixed a f*cking thing and instead their efforts seem to go into BANNING people left and right for stupid stuff. FIX YOUR F*UCKING GAME, THIS IS UNACCEPTABLE!!!

author: Volkov of Batavia
review: After the recent issues I've started to have with the game, I can no longer recommend Forza 5 in good faith for as much as I've loved the past year and a half. I'm hoping that the next game in the series might be better, but I can't even wait until the second expansion drops to properly leave.Pros:-Driving is amazing and I love how it controls-The world is incredibly open and vast, lending to a lot of exploration-Menus are easy to navigate and the music is awesome-LOTS of content to get through for the casual audienceCons:-Save file is NOT housed online despite being live service. If anything goes wrong with your hardware and cloud saves, say goodbye to all of your progress. (Last time I played, this was an ongoing issue.)-Series and Season missions are repetitive, boring, and aren't newcomer-friendly AT ALL. Anyone new getting into Forza 5 will quickly find themselves irritated by these.-Online is filled with cheaters and no one has addressed it. Constant disconnects as well.-There are bugs EVERYWHERE. I have constant flickering, texture corruption, menu errors, the works, and none of them have been fixed for a year now. I've played buggy games before, but not like this.-Support is nonexistant. I have messaged them twice in my Forza lifetime and have gotten zero help.Premium edition was 100 dollars. If I'm paying that amount of money for a game to play it, I should be getting better than what's been provided. Do better, PG.

author: THE STIG
review: I can't believe that people like this game, it's a complete disaster:1) No text chat.2) Voice chat is always muted, whatever you do.So no communication at all, except 2 quick messages (hi/cool car/I don't like sand), wonder how you suppose to make friends, Playground Games.3) Absolutely no settings for the PVP lobby.4) PVP lobby loading time (~2min).5) If you got rammed then you are a loser. Always.6) You can't queue for desired car class and race type in PVP, so be ready to dodge other lobbies - basically spending 5-7mins for 3 races.7) Multiple visual bugs just check the Youtube.8) Regular game crashes.9) The game will look satisfactorily only on the Extreme preset.10) Poor performance on top-level PC (70-90fps on 3440x1440 using 3080TI, 5120x2160 is unplayable).11) Poor HUD setting considering 21:9 gaming.12) Personally, offroad driving makes me sick.13) No ranked PVP.Refund submitted. -> Rejected, because I spent more than 2 hours in-game, well true, but to get to PVP you need to spend 5 hours, plus the time for initial graphics and gaming set up, ridiculous.In my case, I bought the Premium Edition version and got a time-consuming(PVP-wise) and buggy game. Quite a good run for its money, I guess.Should've read the negative reviews.Just to summarize:- Be ready to spend extra 40mins for 1 hour of pure traditional PVP.- Maybe this game makes sense you are a casual gamer who won't be playing PVP,  but what's the point then? Collecting cars? But you can't even discuss your own car with strangers because of no text/voice chat.- PVP-wise, it feels like a downgrade even from the original The Crew game from 2014 with proper lobbies and race track settings, and text chat(LOL).So Playground Games, keep us in touch with future updates and I'm not interested in new cars.

review: As a long-time forza player, i personally think this game is awesome, It includes new vehicles re-done sounds, everything you expect. The forza developers always step up there game when it comes to forza games.There's multiple issues with this game, You have a good chance of crashing, getting glitched of the map and its almost unplayable And its been a couple of days and nothing got fixed. Current Muscle car's don't sound good at all, they sound like they have a v12 in them. The engine upgrading menu is probably the worst part of this game. like 10 speed race transmission? makes no sense and its not realistic at all for cars. I expected to have 4 speeds and 6 speeds but no. we get this unrealistic pile of garbage transmissions that make no sense. I personally think this game should be redone. Seeing that half of the stuff isn't realistic then the other stuff is realistic is really annoying. I may have 2 hours but i know forza games well enough to give a proper review. Do not buy this game I recommend buying Forza Horizon 4 Save your money for something more valuable.

I bought it at release and it was quite buggy, with crashes and weird "GPU Memory limit" messages even playing at full-hd with a rtx 3070?? Also, in some roads when it rained the textures/water on the floor was completely messed up. Overall not a bad game, but I find it boring I am sure if you are into cars you may like it more?Refunded

author: KoKoKo
review: So, I  love FH 4 and was very excited about FH5. After playing a while, I can`t recomment this game, because of:1. I have a feeling like I am a beta tester right now. Game crashes, random fps drops, stutters, even when I have +/- 100 fps on ultra.2.  constant disconnects. There were few hours that I`ve played online without disconnects, but it`s an exception. 3. Graphics is not much better than fh4, it`s ok.4. Online is broken. They made only one entry point to it, so you are not able to choose which type of races you want to play.5. No ranked - RIP competition. In online 95% of players are too slow, inexpierienced. it`s boring to play solo with random guys.6. Meta is on (hello to boneshaker etc.)7. It`s in 60% same FH4. What is really good:1. Map and tracks. They are longer and more interesting.2. Slightly rebalanced tuning.

author: AdrianL
review: I highly recommend Froza Horizon 5 over other racing games with 4 out of 5 stars rating:Pros:- I bought 4 and 5 Ultimate Editions together and I refunded 4 because 5 has way much better graphics- Ray Tracing supports make this game and cars shine- 5120 x 1440 DQHD 32:9 screen resolutions support- Great frame rate (50+ fps) with max quality settings on 3080 (16GB) Max-Q laptop GPU (Razer)- Nice interior details and rendering for houses- Out of the box PXN V9 steering wheel supportsCons:- Lack of split screen local 2 players support with two controllers (Dirt 5 has it)- Need DLSS 2+ and/or FSR support- Need more maps as DLCs instead of installments- I can't get out of my car to interact with the world and people from other cars nor NPCs

author: Deurmeus
review: Well, it took awhile for me to come to this verdict and I'm sad to see it the way it is.This game has many flaws. AAA games have a high standard to which FH5 did not meet right out of the gate. Immensely frequent crashes being the biggest catalyst to my disliking of the game. (I run a 3070ti and a R7 5600X for reference)THEN, just then, when they released some hot fixes and I was finally able to play for more than 20 minutes at a time, they reset all of my progress. Right back to the intro. I am completely unable to get out of this loop despite having made my way to rank 25 with a few decent super cars. (X rated)This game has many great things about it. Truly, I love it. But I'd wait at least 6 months before purchasing so that they can get all the kinks and bugs out of the game first.

author: Quartzzz
review: This isn't what I wanted to expect from the brand new FH5. Yes, the devs did a really good job on improving graphics and on adding new "biomes" *BUT* they didn't even managed to optimise the game for high specs pcs, like cm'on, im driving on the highway, enjoying my life surrounded by 240p png image from paint "sandstorm" at 120fps and BOOM, guess what? Exactly, game crashes with the terrific sound of car's engine equivalent to the weirdcore soundract worth of 10+ hours. Okay, nvm, lets go on. ROAD WORKERS NEED TO BE PAID MORE! ROAD WORKERS NEED TO BE PAID MORE! ROAD WORKERS NEED TO BE PAID MORE! Like wtf is wrong with highway? Maybe I don't get it, but is it common routine in mexico to steal asphalt from the 6 lane highway??? Why does my bugatti is driving on a green grass instead of the road??? Okay okay... Have you ever heard about fields? Do you know what colour are they? I personally started to questioning my knowledge, in fh there are 3 types of them. First one: "La field covered in gas". Second one: "La extreme exotic field covered in every texture in game". And finally, third one: "Abyss" ...At least they have some really good cars *BUT* the interiors of those are from toyota corolla 1997 with 400k miles on it.Anyways, the game is really really raw, too many bugs and glitches (exactly the same ones we had in fh4). They made the game feel more arcade, little to no new features. And mostly important, 50Â£ for the standard version of the game. At this point, microsoft is making fun of us. Do not get fooled by the pictures, I do not want to change your opinion of the game, I only gave you my point of view that may differ from yours.3/10
